tei:div.ab: The town of Corunna is placed on a peninsula Coarse Granitewhich joins a high knoll to the main land The port is very secure. The ancient name was Adabicum. About 5 miles up the river which falls into the port Ssouth of the town is a bridge of 13 arches & near it was the town of Brigantium
The Country though rocky seems to produce figs grapes melons capsicums &c in great abundance in September.

decreasing daily as that of Madrid will at length entirely supersede it. The soil is sandy (and the rocks entirely of coarse granite) like that of Falmouth This passage does not follow on from the previous page, though they are recto and verso of the same leaf. Perhaps WG had a loose sheet, to which the symbol + presumably relates. It does not link to any obvious passage in the notebook.

tei:div.ab: North of the Town in the way to the tower of Hercules or new light house is a fountain ornamented like those of Greece. The base seems Roman upon which some statues or other modern additions have been placed, now destroyed

tei:div.ab: The Church of St Yago at Corunna. The Saint is represented driving the Moors before Him. The Church contains several altars & a large organ but is not handsome. Thermometer 76 Sep 22d.

tei:div.ab: Quitting Corunna at 6 in the morning of Septr 24th in a coach drawn by 6 mules, Our passports from the junta were examined at the gate. At 20 minutes before 7 reach PalaviaPalavea, where we had dined the day before, landing at the mouth of the river of PaçajeWG seems to mean the Ría da Coruña (Estuary of A Coruña), the mouth of the Mero river.
Our mules were called Valerosa ‘Ortolana Palagrina Gagliarda Platena & Cahona or Cajona.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: house
figure.label: Venta de OrdinesCountry inn at Ordes

tei:div.ab: and ascending among vineyards chestnuts & hedges of Baytree. Our host was named Don Juan de Barila and treated us magnificently at his Villa. Each course consisted of 18 dishes
Pass a kind of Barrier but no toll was taken. At 10 minutes to 7 the road to Madrid by BetancosBetanzos turns off LLeft. The country is very well cultivated. Maize in abundance. Some Pines.

At 7 past 7 in a bottom a stream running to the left. Pretty Villas & vineyards, Chest nuts Walnuts & Oaks. The cloaks of the peasants going to market very becoming. At 35 p 77.35 after a steep hill in a bottom, a river runs to L. A fine valley with a MtMountain in the centre

A high mountain bounds the vale on S.south At 5 to 8 pass the 2 league stone [drawing: league stone] . At 10 to 9 stops at the village of Carral – 10 past 9 proceed. At 20 p 9 the 3d League stone. the valley delightful with gardens & orchards. Black sheep. Chestnuts. At 25 past 9 cross a clear stream running to L. many houses. 18 p 10 cross a ravine [drawing: ravine] after a terrible ascent from the stream. The road always good

figure.label: Villa Boa
figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: woman

tei:div.ab: At 25m to 11 pass the 4th10.35 stone on the top of the mountain which is bleak & like a Westmoreland Moor.
tei:div.note: rainy & cold
tei:div.ab: Maize. At 15 p 1115.11 the streams run toward the South. Several poor Inns or VentasCountry inns in the way. A Village & at 18 to 12 the 5th stone [drawing: league stone] . The country is very poor in appearance but does not want habitations even at this elevation. At 15 p 12 the Venta di OrdinesCountry inn at Ordes on the road side where we stopped to refresh. The house is entered by a porch, next a passage appears on Rright of which is the stable the mules eating with their heads towards the kitchen which is on the L.left Above the stable is a room with 3 windows, 4 beds of straw on wooden frames, two tables, a chest & some chairs to sit upon, A deal cross & two pictures of the Virgin.
tei:div.note: The whole or nearly all the country is enclosed but the mode of tillage seems to be to cultivate each field once in 5 years in which interval it becomes full of high furze & heath & appears quite neglected. It is then pared & burned.
tei:div.ab: 24 often rainy in

Eggs wine & bread were to be found & they made us an excellent omelet. Many soldiers were on the road to join the Galician army at Coruña. At 25 minutes to 2 proceed. 25 p 22.25 Xcross a stream running to Rright, a Village before it. 3 to 3qui.e. WG is asking himself whether it really was nearly 3pm. larger stream & house. 7 p 3 X
[drawing: arch bridge] river runs R [drawing: map] 45 p 3 7th League. 7 to 4 a VillVillage & church +. in a Valley on R a river is seen. 15 p 4 X [drawing: arch bridge] runs R. a village & X a great [drawing: arch bridge] TambraTambre (river) to L.left 25 p 4 a grove on R full of men women & oxen, making a very picturesque appearance, probably a fair where oxen were sold for the people were leading them home in every direction.

45 p 4 VentaCountry inn 8 leagues. At 6h a few houses & place like an encampment on a hill R. X a [drawing: arch bridge] running R. A Venta. 5m to 65.55 9 league stone cultivation improves. At 6h on a hill see St Yago de CompostellaSantiago de Compostela one an eminence & ornamted by 6 spires – At 20 p 6, enter

the city & lodge at the Casa de Portugueses Portuguese House – where the people were very civil – The bill for 3 persons & two Servants for Lodging 2 night 2 dinners & two breakfasts, was 198 reals or about 10 dollars. The Napoleon was on the staircase & the performer was subject to the inspection of passengers – Our passports were examined with an apology for the times which made it necessary. On walking out to see the Cathedral we asked the way & a person shewed it us. A second joined us & then a third who introduced us to the JuntaProvincial government in the College. They were very civil & much pleased with the head of the king on a halfpenny. They complained that more money had been sent to Corunna instead of to the central JuntaPerhaps of Galicia, but probably the Supreme Central Junta (central authority during the Napoleonic occupation).. The view from the court of the College of the
tei:div.note:
25 Sep at St YagoSantiago de Compostela rain almost all day Verses handed about at Dn Don Juan Berillas dinner
Por Pracmatica sancion
Se ha mandado publicar
De que el vasa de cagar
Se llame: Napoleon:
Y, por la misma razon
Por esta Ley, se decreta
Se publique en la Gazeta
En un capitulo à parte
Que se llame Buonaparte
Toda comun ou secreta
By Pragmatic sanction,
It has been ordered to be made known
That the crock of shit
Is called Napoleon:
And, for the same reason
By this Law, it is decreed
That it be published in the Gazette
In a separate chapter
Called Buonoparte
All common or secret
Mandase publicar pra. qe. el language sea general. Ordered to be published so that the language is widespread.
It was plain that no money was wanted in Spain for none of the English money had ever been sent from Corunna to the army.
tei:div.ab: towers of the Cathedral was striking. We visited the Plaza Mayor on the N north side of the cathedral. A very small part of the ancient building remains of the W west end of the Cathedral, more Saxon than Gothic. [drawing: building] but within at this end is a very fine screen with [drawing: arch] arches round which the heavenly choir are carved, with harps &c. The Cathedral is not more than two centuries old & besides being very large is the finest pile of building in the style of Inigo Jones I ever saw. The roof is entirely of fine white uncoloured stone with [drawing: arch] arches, sometimes not quite regular. It is very lofty so as to have the proportions of a Gothic church. The Shrine of St JagoSt James is entirely of silver, the body is buried below. There is a very fine organ. St Jago was seen in a vision driving the Moors out of Spain.

figure.note: Pen and ink plan: Santiago de Compostela
figure.label: Free Stone a building in which the metopes are windows

tei:div.note: Encima la sacristia de la catedral de Santiago y sobre un arco toral de la obra vieja. Para gloria de Dios acabó esta obra Miguel de Bozllar natural de S. Miguel de Areno. Año de 1245. Above the sacristy of St James's cathedral and on a central arch of the old work. For the glory of God, Miguel de Bozllar, a native of San Miguel de Areno, finished this work. The year 1245. Spanish text abridged from Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, p. 52.
tei:div.ab: as represented over the door of his church at Coruña in the 8th century as we were told – Almost every building in the City is in the same stile of architecture, all very massive but some highly ornamented. The humidity of the climate has taken much from the beauty of many of the edifices. Upon the whole perhaps there is no provincial town better adorned with fine buildings. The Seminary Nnorth of the great square is very magnificent & regular, an academy makes the Eeast side the splendid cathedral the Ssouth & an Hospital excellently provided with beds & assistance for the sick, has a very noble front to the E of the Square. We heard music in the Cathedral from the Archbishops tribunal, with
tei:div.note: Alhagib captain of KgKing of CordovaKing of Cordoba entered Galicia & sacked St YagoSantiago de Compostela & took the great bells to the mosque at Cordova but in 1236 D.Don Fernando retook them & made the Moors carry them back on their shoulders.
tei:div.ab: his Sister, a good humoured old Lady who never ceased talking during the whole Service. [Pen and ink drawing: woman] The people were astonished at our dining at five, and came before we had finished to conduct us to the Cathedral to hear singing & .. Un CaponA Capon, i.e. a eunuch. We saw the convent of the Benedictines near the cathedral a very magnificent building of the Inigo Jones doric order. It had several courts & a very fine library in which were the books forbidden by the Inquisition about 150 feet long. The stair case to it was the most solid I ever saw. There are 100 monks who have immense revenues & 100 servants. The church is large, very lofty & not handsome. The roof vaulted & there is a perfectly flat arch [drawing: arch] of 14 yards across over one part.

The Plaza is full of Posadas Posada della Cruz. del Sole. de la Aurora & ours of L’Estrellafull of Inns: the Cross Inn, the Sun [sol] Inn, the Dawn Inn and ours, the Star Inn, a very good house where they killed 2 chickens, scalded off the feathers & made a very good stew with potatoes, & an omelet with Tomatas for which 2 of us & 2 servants paid 2 dollars & about 6 pence; There is a building

40 p 11 steep ascent Village ConstantinProbably Constantín, though WG has crossed out the 'n'. . 10 p 12 very long ascent curious Gothic Rock very like a ruin*. Small vill near it R. 3 Villages R & pretty Valley. still ascend. 20 to 112.40 top Glen & houses L. 10 to 1 League 20. The river in the new valley runs back 9m 9 miles to Asturias; perhaps into the Minho. 20 p 1 arrive at Santa IsabellaSanta Isabel. A very wretched VentaCountry inn with only one room a travelling hurdy gurdy man, very civil drivers of oxen. hens cat dog & pig all in the room. A great caldron on the fire boiling potatoes greens &c. for the pigs.

At 15 p 4 quit St Isabella. very fine Mountains A high cold place on getting into next valley. The hills very lofty but up to the top cultivated, the bottoms full of chestnut trees. descend, Vill L.Better climate

tei:div.ab: The country like Achaia, but valleys green. uncommonly fine and awful descent from the road to river. 30 p 55.30 a pretty church & sycamore L left with magnificent views each way, a house R. right descend. 40 p 5 + church L near the river at bottom. 5 to 65.55 22d league, 5 p 6 Vill X Village cross the river of the valley by a [drawing: arch bridge] . a toll bar. after this a little [drawing: arch bridge] yethe stream of which joins the great river of the valley. 25 p 6 arrive. decent PosadaInn of Los NogalesAs Nogais. A small village like a welch town very wet & dirty. The host a great sportsman. His gun made at Ribadeo cost 60 Dollars & was very neat. Sepr 30 quit Los Nogales at 15m to 87.45 X [drawing: arch bridge] over the stream of the valley 15 p 8 a Glen runs up to L up which 13 intersections of the mountains are seen. Very steep ascent. 30 p 8 23d League. Very steep. chestnuts. 36 a Village called Conco qu? DoncoDoncos. WG is not sure if the village is called Conco or Donco.. 15 p 9 a poor Village another valley R the stream of which runs all the way to Villa FrancaVillafranca del Bierzo. 10 p 10 a kind of top but still there is a higher. at 15 to 11 descend. At 12 to 21.40 Village 27 p 2 28th League, soon after a thatched Village TramoreroTrabadelo. 20 p 3 pretty Village. 20 to 4 24th 9 League. 15 p 4 Villa FrancaVillafranca del Bierzo, the stream falls under a [drawing: arch bridge] into a great river from L over which a bridge conducts you into the town, Old ugly narrow streets 4 or 5 handsome convents. The Inn or Posada comfortless ruinous very large & prison like with iron grates. The people too not very attentive. quit the Mountains A stranger came into our room praised the English smoaked & spit about – The town looks deserted, so many of the buildings are in runs. People not so handsome in this Vill as before. 20 p 10 31 Leagues. The river joins the VF river & runs with it into Minho. tei:div.ab: At 10 to 3 in another fine vale at the head of which is BembibresBembibre. 10 p 33.10 Xcross a [drawing: arch bridge] River runs to Rright a Village called San Roman. About 10 minutes to Bembibres little town with a castle of mud now ruined. Tower of it entirely composed of unbaked earth proof of the dryness of the climate, even arms remain upon the walls – Good PosadaInn – Many recruits. Very civil – ammunition waggons apparently English – Another coach & 7 came to the Posada.

5 p 2 X [drawing: arch bridge] . 25 p 2 see Astorga. Ugly parched corn country no trees. 43 p 2 41st League 15 p 3 Astorga.

Large town old X a [drawing: wall] Towers walk on them. Roughstones & mud. Castle called Moorish but with a latin inscription arms a Saint & other Figures. a Cathedral of Gothic appearance with Inigo Jones twisted pillars & [drawing: arch] arches – In the Square there is a building in which two figures in the habits of the Maragotes a people

of this place are made to strike the hours which is esteemed a curiosity. The country very ugly a small river runs in the plain – The people called Maragottes are the most excellent figures for a Sancho or a Hudibras i.e. Sancho Panza, Don Quixote's squire, or Hudibras, the knight errant from Samuel Butler's eponymous poem of the 1660s and 1670s. in the world

tei:div.ab: Astorgas is walled round so as to have only one entrance from the West for carriages. The towers are entirely solid the interior being equally mud & stones.
tei:div.note: An officer who was taken prisoner at the battle of Rio Seco Battle of Medina de Rioseco, 14 July 1808 said the French lost 2000 men that day.

Quit Astorga 3d of Octob at 8h fine clear warm day a few poplars & a [+ in box] on the S South side of it. the road very bad, but being a plain country it is not ncessary to have a better. Stony corn country. At 10h
Vill & + L Village and church left . several ugly farms, about. & + on R church on right . 25 p 10 10.25 a Vill & a Vill L. At 11h a fount R. 10 p 11 large Vill & Castle. 1 p 11 X cross

a
[drawing: arch bridge] wooden over a river running to L. Alders & poplars a few English poplars. the bushes of a southern climate not seen here. 10 to 12 11.50 Vill L. 5 to 12 Vill La Baneza La Bañeza X cross
[drawing: arch bridge] over a River running Rright to it a Gate at entry of La Baneza a town of which the M deMarquis of Miranda is patron. Stop to dine here. the posada inn very decent, the people of the town & posada both civil, We found here a very good red grape with red juice – Quit La Baneza by a gate of 15m p 2 2.15. 35 p 2 Vill L. At 3h Vill R. 10 p 3 Vill L.

Avisana 7 leagues. a decent inn close to it the bridge over the river Orvigo Órbigo the centre arch of which spans 24 steps – just across it is a grove of poplars in which the Spanish peasants were collected before the affair of Rio Seco. All the rivers of this plain seem to rise in the Ms N of Leon & S of AsturiasMountains north of León and south of Asturias. The plain bounded by hills on Wwest but unbounded on Eeast.
tei:div.note: At La Baneza La Bañeza the French entered after the battle of Rio Seco Battle of Medina de Rioseco, 14 July 1808 with 18 men only. General Blake was in the Mountains & the people of the town thought the whole french army was coming.

figure.label: Lady of Benevente Benavente
Peasants at Benevente

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: arch bridge

tei:div.ab: Quit PUENTE DE ORBIGO i.e. a bridge over the Órbigo [not the modern Puente de Órbigo, which is off WG's route] at 5m to 7 Octob 4 Fine hot day Xcross the bridge. Ilex common. 2 p 7 7.02 the wood Rright where the Spanish army halted previous to the affair of Rio Seco Battle of Medina de Rioseco, 14 July 1808 ends. A house beyond it. 3 Villages at foot of hills R. 25 p 7 VillVillage. 37 p 8 large convent & trees Lleft. 10 p 9 Vill R. across the great River Orvigo Órbigo. A woody country R of that. Road in forest of Ilex. 10 p 10 the town of Benevente Benavente surrounded by a mud wall. On Eeast side mud stones. a College & some convents. The streets very wretched the Posada Inn tolerable. The French staid 15 hours in the town & got some money from the College. Quit Benevente at 15m to 1h poor place. 25 p 1 long & dangerous [drawing: arch bridge] because ruined. Large river under it flows to R & joins the Orbigo & Douro &c &c Enter Sandy country, no stones. Toll gate. 5 to 3 Vill L. 25 p 3 distt Vill L. 10 p 4 2 Vills Serazino de los Varios & next Serazin de la Ordin Cerecinos de los Barrios and Cerecinos de la Orden (now jointly Cerecinos de Campos). Cellars cut out of the bank in sand here.
tei:div.note: Benavente of the Duchess of Ossuna Osuna – Her Son Prince of Anglona in Naples. Their Castle very curious & old. The French spoiled it. Armour in the hall old & said to be fine –
Believe the river is the Esla –

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape with arch bridge
figure.label: FROM THE INN AT AVISANA

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: cellars
figure.label: wine cellars in the bank at Serrazin Cerecinos de la Orden

tei:div.ab: The soil is so firm that cellars are made at Sarrazino de Ordin Cerecinos de la Orden merely be excavating. Some of the doors are so handsome that they appear like habitations. Here the carts have real wheels instead of [drawing: wheel]. sandy so that wooden not iron pullies are used Mules are used here in plowing. At 25 p 5 5.25 over a very ugly country, arrive at Vilalpondo Villalpando. 8 leagues Appearance of poverty the mud wall being in ruins. The convent spires only looking well at a distance. The Posada Inn just out of the town. Many Priests. No made road. The drawer of the table where we write at the Inn broken up by the French in hopes of finding money – Rain in the night.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: woman
Pencil drawing: arch bridge

tei:div.ab: Octob 5 misty rain abt 6 in the morng. . 6 leagues to M d Toro Mota del Toro (now Mota del Marqués)

Octob 5. At 5 to 6 5.55 quit Villalpando bill 3 dollars 6 reals. At 25 p 7 we were told Rio Seco Battle of Medina de Rioseco, 14 July 1808 where the French beat Genl General Cuesta was 6 leagues L left . The maps all wrong in this part 9 or 10 leagues. Plains. 10 p 8 8.10 forest of prickly oaks. 30 p 8 X cross a bad road but the only Xing crossing I remember to have seen in 50 leagues. 8 to 9 X a brook, a town & castle L 5 miles dist. 35 p 9 Vill Village called Villa de Frayles(frailes: friars). Vill R right distt. 15 to 10 a castle L seen long before & its Vill. 10 p 10 Vill, Inn & church, a steep bank to another plain, a flat Forest. 10 to 11 quit forest cistus & .. & stone pines. Vill R. The Forest was said to be called Monte de Torolto Probably Montes de Torozos. 10 to 12 Vill & grove & many little hills [drawing: hills] . Vill is called La Mota del ToroNow Mota del Marqués. good Posada Inn. opposite it a large house belonging to a great duke de Hixa of Híjar. The inn built of earth plaistered & painted below with white & red thus.
[drawing: lines] Rather a pretty effect. The French did no mischief here except that a drum major ravished a girl for which the people killed him. A round tower ruined on a hill. Quit the place at 25 p 2 to go 3 leagues to Tordesillas. 30 p 3 Vill R. Vill L. 35 p 3 a Vill called

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: house

label.rs: HOUSE AT MOTA DE TORO Mota del Toro, now Mota del Marqués

figure.label: Duke of HixaHíjar

tei:div.ab:
La Vega de Tronco Vega de Valdetronco ugly ploughed country. 37 p 4 Vill. 10 to 5 Vill L 4.37 Village. 4.50 Village left . At 5h Vill vines & a wood of stone pines. No stones in the fields, a caravan of wool carts Merino wool. See Tordesillas at 15 p 6 arrive there. The Posada Inn decent the town very wretched looks better at a distance. Not very small. On the SE south-east the Douro runs under the bank, under a [drawing: arch bridge] rather a large river even here. The Plaza small but upon wine bags wooden Pillars. Octobr 6 fine day but misty till 9h. Quit Tordesillas at 15 to 9 Xing crossing
[drawing: arch bridge] 15 to 11 the town of Rueda good brick churches & convents & houses. The bricks in Spain all like Roman.

time of the vintage. People very civil everywhere offered us grapes. Sandy flat. vineyards everywhere At 10m p 12h 12.10 see the Castillian MtsMountains . 4 p 1 arrive at town of Medina del Campo fount large Town houses on wooden pillars. a river nearly dry many brick +s & [+ in box] s churches and monasteries . A very large rather handsome Plaza. Ruined castle at NE north-east end of City. SE south-east of the town the AlcazarFortress fine in point of size, a kind of barrack. 5 p 2 sand & Italian pines. Tilled carts here with 5 mules. 7 p 3 vill L. 8 p 3 X 3.07 village left. 3.08 cross
[drawing: arch bridge] the rivulet runs L. The mode of sowing wheat is to throw it on the ground & then plough it in

Meet a coach & 7. Wine cellars. 30 p 3 Vill San. VicenteSan Vicente del Palacio.. 30 p 4 TaquinasAtaquines where sleep. A large Village houses very neat, of mud all on one floor. good brick + church . people asked us to eat as we walked by the door & the boys were playing at ploughing & at Soldiers.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Orbita
figure.label: Specimen of Villages on the plains of Leon
& old Castile.

tei:div.ab: Octob 7. a fine hot day quit Taquines AloquinesAtaquines at 7h. 20 p 8 Vill R 8.20 Village right . At 9h Pines. 10 p 9 Vill R. 10 to 109.50 ArevalosArévalo town with towers ruined castle. X cross a glen to it [drawing: arch bridge] walls 2 towers Another [drawing: arch bridge] over a glen 17 p 10 stream Runs to Lleft but turns & runs under +church. An inscriptn of Carlos IIII. 10 to 11 Vill L. Pine forests R & L. 25 p 11 Vill, meet a Calesh. 40 p 11 Vill Orbita where dine, bill for 4 persons less than a dollar. 15 p 2 quit Orbita 35 p 3 Vill. flocks of Bustards like geese. 33 p 3 Vill AranieroAdanero. Vultures black in the fields. 40 p 4 large Vill San CyrianSanchidrián. Road made & a stone 15 leagues to Madrid. A small vill called AlmorzaAlmarza at 10 p 5. Road to Salamanca turns off here R. Real Port Asego. descend into a better & roughly wooded plain. 15 p 5 X [drawing: arch bridge] River runs L. Qu a chase i.e. WG wonders if it is a hunting ground. 5 to 6 ascending. 14 league stone. 7 p 6 8 crosses La cruce cruz del Calvario The cross of Calvary [probably the name of a village] 8 p 6 Vill.. Alabaxos LavajosLabajos Bill not 3 dollars
Quit Alabaxos where a decent PosadaInn Oct 8, at 6h. a fine day but colder as we ascended. High Bushy plain. 4 to 7 League 14. 8h Vill Villa CastinVillacastín.

Granite. 11 p 88.11 League 12. Rocks of granite like Cyclopian walls R & L right and left ascend, enter the Sierra 36 p 8 stony glen Xd crossed by [drawing: arch bridge] brook to L. Cardenia Riv River At 9h a stone but not a league Paso del MonteMountain Pass shrubs & rocks. 25 p 9 11th League Las Navas del Rey qu Sn Antonio Navas de San Antonio [WG is correct] large Village, meet a coach & 6. steep hill. pass of GuaderamaGuadarrama. 10 p 10 meet 3 coaches & 6 NBnota bene (take note) larger coaches & very like ours. 15 p 10 house on a top, descend, to a Mtainmountain valley. 40 p 10 [+ in box]monastery El Christo en colloquio de calloco The hermitage of Cristo del Caloco. 40 p 10 10th League a brook runs L. A VillVillage R El Espinal El Espinar large, at 5 p 11 – At 12h 9th League & Vill Fonda de San Rafael the inn at San Rafaelstop to dine, a good, house. a fount. MtsMountains covered seen in View with scotch firs & pinastres. a +church. Segovia road turns off here. ascend steep winding road among pines wild & often beautiful several sorts of thyme. well watered. The Puerto or pass of Guaderama. On the top after a very long ascent a pedestal of Stone Fer VI Fernando VI of Spain (1713-59). a lion at top of granite done when he had finished the roads. On the top see as far as the plains of Leon one way & to Madrid 8 leagues & as much beyond, the other. Distinguish at Madrid the casa del ChinaThe Real Fábrica del Buen Retiro (Royal Factory of Buen Retiro), the porcelain factory, known as 'La China'.. L at bottom a Vill & gardens.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: view of Escorial
4 stories & 1 in roof 52 windows 18 ft dist by 31
EEast front 240 steps long. 52 windows abt 18 ft dist by 31 windows

tei:div.ab: The court seem to have quitted it entirely as it is much neglected but the monks say the Royal Family resided there 3 months in the year.
tei:div.note: Escurial length 600 feet
tei:div.ab:
25 p 1010.25 quit Escurial Octob 9. descend. 35 p 10 the mean Vill of Baxo EscurialVillage of El Escorial de Abajo. 6 leagues ½ to Madrid. 11h 6 leagues. 15 to 1211.45 pass [drawing: arch bridge] & gates of demesne. very hot. 10 p 12 5 leagues. + Rchurch right. 18 p 12 GalapagasGalapagar Vill & [drawing?] R is the Posta del ReyKing's Post a post house. join the GuaderamaGuadarrama road. 17 to 2 Xcross
[drawing: arch bridge] stream runs to R. ugly country 10 p 2 3 Leagues to Madrid. 20 to 3 2 leagues & ½ Vill Lleft La RotaLas Rozas & a Vill R. 3 to 3 a bad road from L joins. see Madrid plainly. 10 p 3 2 leagues. Woody country L. bare near the road. A Royal chase L. ArbacaAravaca? R at 10 to 4. Turn R quitting the greatest road. A fount Fuente del ReyKing's Fountain at 4h. 20 p 4 enter an enclosure by gate. gardens L. R [drawing: hills] where the french had batteries &c 15 to 5 pass 2d barrier. ½ league. A toll. X River Manzanares. Poplars & gardens, water 6 inches deep bed sandy but broad. reenter great road elms & poplars. Foot path, meet a carriage & 2 mules. meet a 2d at 5h. pretty spouting fountain & walks enter gate under an angle of the palace. give a dollar to the custom house officer. Puerta St VicentePuerta de San VicenteSt Vincent's Gate very handsome only ornamental. Palace very

figure.note: Pencil drawing: map
Pencil drawing: fountain?

tei:div.note: at Madrid Oct 10 Thermom = 62 & varying from 62 to 66 till Octob 24, when a very hot day, too hot except in the wind.
tei:div.ab: handsome but upon a very high basement of 3 or 4 stories the rest beautiful. drive to the Cruz de Malta Cross of Malta a pretty good but dear FondaInn where we staid 2 days & then took a lodging. Italian opera very good SraSignora Marchesini& SaSignora Fineschi the singers & two very good men. Opera a ridicule of Gli Orazii e Curiazii. the after piece Filandro e Carolina. On the morning of the tenth Oct 1808 a bull feast Corrida de los Torosbullfight (or 'bull feast', WG's term shared by most British contemporaries) 6 bulls killed 4 or 5 poor horses cruelly gored to death. In the afternoon 8 bulls & many horses besides a man fell. The amphitheatre is at least 100 yards in diamrdiameter & the seats have 15 rows besides 7 in the boxes behind & the upper story where the private boxes are hung with silk of all colours. It is exactly except in being a circle on the plan of a roman amphitheatre. The palace full of fine pictures – A court in the middle – Our Lodging cost a dollar a day. 2 bad bed rooms, a good sitting

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: bull-ring
figure.label: Section of the Colliseo de los TorosBullfighting arena [coliseo]

tei:div.ab: room, a bad dining room, servants rooms & kitchen. Cloth & every thing which requires labour very dear. The people we knew. The CondesaCountess Altemira
tei:div.note: Thermometer from 62 to 66 from 10th to 20 of October
Bill for us & Servants at [drawing: Maltese cross] 18 dollars & ½. 2 dinners. 2 nights. 2 breakfasts for each. 4 rooms.
The language of Madrid seems very impure. InfantadoDuque del Infantado (Duke of the Infantado) is always pronounced Infantao. Valladolid Vaioi &c
Eating for 2 & 3 servants for a fortnight cost 105 dollars
Music by Señor Sor.

DUO

figure.label: Hill & Church of StaSanta Maria de los Angeles.

tei:div.ab:
Quit Madrid at 9h Octob 24 very fine hot & clear to bridge of Toledo over the Manzanares, very fine strike off from it. Turn L. 38 p 9left. 9.38 Toll. At 10h a
[drawing: hill] hill X cross the river L. At 15 p 10 a road turns R right to Villaverde & beyond it a Vill Village & palace of the Duca de InfantadoDuque del Infantado (Duke of the Infantado). A Vill left under [drawing: hill] . At 11h Getafe large vill R & the hill & +church of La VergineVirgen de los Angeles L. 25 p 11 2d league. Post house Angeles Olives scattered & vines. 15 p 12 Vill R Pinto. 32 p 12 League 3d. 20 p 1 Val de MoroValdemoro, General Cuesta has a house there. large Vill or Town. 40 p 1 4th League. 15 p 2 League 4 ½. Post house Olives – 15 to 32.45 league 5. 15 p 3 at bottom of the hill & in the vale of MancanaresManzanares, having seen the vale of the Tagus from the top. on each side the road, rows double, of Trees. League 6. turn L. 35 p 3 X a great bridge over Manzanares, vale about 2 miles wide. Deer Trees of Royal Demesne begin. Very long avenue turning again R from the bridge. 20 p 4 L is an aquaduct & a wheel of 30 feet diam~diameter which throws up the water for the grounds. Enter thicker woods. 34 p 4 league 6 ½. 15 p 5. cascade of the Tagus a white muddy river and the palace. Gardens very shady. The town of Aranjuez very regularly laid out. wide streets. rows of trees in them – A large Inn full of people & Carriages. We met many on the road from Madrid.
tei:div.note: King Wamba of pueblo de Bambatown od Bamba. his body translated from a +church he built there to Toledo. King Recesvinto built at at Pisuerga in 610 as an inscriptn yet says on a stone.
Wamba in 674 built walls & Towers round Toledo. with stones from Circus maximus &c.
Erexit fautore Deo rex inclytus urbem Wamba &c.With the support of God, the illustrious King Wamba erected the city etc.
Bridge of Alcantara at Toledo impassable in time of Ervigio successor of Wamba. This King sent a Duke or Governor Sala to repair it. Verses of Eugenius 3 archbishop confirm this.

Gothic monuments of Spain. DDon Juan Cean BermudezJuan Agustín Ceán Bermúdez collaborated with Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola on Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829).
Arabs in 713 came & copied from Egypt pointed arches. pretence of media luna for arcos de herradura.half-moon (or crescent) for horseshoe arches
Friezes called Almocarabes o ajaracas.
frisos enriquecidos con lazos cintos plantas y letras floreadas. Con moldes y yeso.
Tarbeas high & great salones.
Alfagias o patios. en vez de grades tenien ranques.
friezes enriched with bows, cinctures, plants and flowery letters. With molds and plaster High great rooms & great salons. Alfagias or patios. instead of grades they had ranks.
Alhamias = dormitories. Alcoves in walls.
Kings Dairy very fine in the way.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: Palace on the Tajus between Aranjuez & TOLEDO

tei:div.ab: At AranjuesAranjuez the houses almost all of one story and very regularly built with very wide streets. Plaistered with a coat of mud, next mortar & then paint. the streets & squares generally right angles. The whole is surrounded with wood & delightful avenues which extend eight or 10 miles in length up & down the TajoTagus, and 3 or 4 in the opposite direction. The palace is very like all the other palaces of Spain. Great staircases of stone, balls pyramids, obeliscs, &c.... The Tagus is cut into 2 streams or runs so naturally as to leave an island for a private garden which is shady & pretty. The Casa de Labrador or gardeners house a folly of King Carlos IV is about a mile distant from the town up the Tajo. the outside is ugly but like everything at Aranjuez surrounded by trees. A moat is made round it with a wooden bridge. Urns of marble &c. The inside is painted & ornamented very prettily. In some parts no expense has been spared. One small room has pilasters covered with arabesques uncommonly well executed in solid gold & Plateriasilver. Every thing is well finished, & the best specimens of Valencia silk & cloth of Gold are seen on almost every wall. The floors are not all good, some indeed of inlaid marble & some of Tiles glazed & prettily painted but many are of brick & of the common kind not baked sufficiently or of bad materials which fill all Spanish rooms with red dust – The imitation of marble in Scagliola is here in the
tei:div.note: Great No of Arabic M.S.S. at Kgs Library Great Number of Arabic Manuscripts at King's Library shewing that there was a great College of Physicians at Toledo –

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: woman on mule with man
Pen and ink plan with watercolour: interior

tei:div.note: We dined at Sir Chas Stuarts Sir Charles Stuart, future 1st Baron Stuart de Rothesay (1779-1845), then on an intelligence-gathering mission to French-occupied Spain (1808-10). Afterwards minister at Lisbon (1810-14). at Aranjuez with Ld. Wm. Bentinck Lord William Bentinck (1774-1839), army officer and later governer-general in India.. Ld Walpole Lord Walpole (Horatio, future 2nd Earl of Orford, 1752-1822), politician. & Sr Thos Graham Sir Thomas Graham, future 1st Baron Lynedoch (1748-1843), army officer.. The last was getting supplies for Sr John MoorsSir John Moore (1761-1809), army officer famous for his retreat to Corunna (and his death at the subsequent Battle of Corunna). Army the others amusing themselves.
Arsenal. Casa de los MarinerosThe Sailors' House, cannon. frigates. real Sailors. sham fights. Kings boat very fine.
Court comes here in April & in dog days goes to La Granja St IldefonsoThe Farm, San Ildefonso thence to the Escurial & in Novr to Madrid. & Prado

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Toledo
figure.label: AlcazarFortress
Cervantes
TajoTagus River
approach from Aranjuez

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: cathedral
figure.label: gallery of Kings

tei:div.ab: highest perfection, even white marble & so well done as to appear fully equal to the rest. The Tajo joins the Jarama & the MançanaresManzanares near Aranjuez. Near the casa del LabradorGardener's house the King has built several ships of the line & frigates on the river. In miniature. In these ships he took great delight & went often on board. There is a theatre in the hall of the pit & boxes is square & the actors were most wretched – The weather beautiful & so hot as to scorch the skin of the face

Octob 26 fine day but a fog in the morning quit palace of Aranjuez at 15 to 98.45 – Road in an avenue. 35 p 99.35 a Casa de Campocountry house like a monastery on the bank, planted wih olives, near on L. left
Puerto de Flaminges. ¾ of a league. Tamarisks in forests. Fine pastures on which the royal horses &c. grazed. A second casa del Campo R. right 8 leagues from Madrid. About a league from Aranjuez the Royal avenues cease. 10 to 10 X cross a river, on R across the Tajus on a bank high is the Village of Anoure del TajoAñover de Tajo. 10 p 12 Villa MejorVillamejor two large houses, an Inn the made road ceases. 15 p 1 X [drawing: arch bridge] over a stream running R. 20 to 2 X [drawing: arch bridge] . Plain covered with Liquorice. 20 p 2 X [drawing: arch bridge] . 20 to 5 Toledo, All the way is an uncultivated heath or Thyme common. R the bed of the Tajo is always marked by trees. miles of Tamarisks. Entering Toledo is a ruined castellated garden house. some pretty Fountains. A fine Statue of King Wamba Kg of the Goths. The entrance to the city a fine [drawing: arch bridge] over the Tajo very rocky deep bed very picturesque. steep ascent to
tei:div.note: As much as I could sketch before the Archbishop entered
Specimen of Spanish wit instead of D-n Damn Pitt. Wm William Wilkins is a fool &c –
En una secretaIn a privy
“Aqui cago Dn Josef Guttierrez"Here shat Don Josef Gutiérrez
“dia 1mo de Junio 1792”."First day of June 1792"
Not content with this the author proceeds with his title “Empleado en les Reales salines de Pinilla en La Mancha.Employee in the Royal saltworks [salinas] at Pinilla in La Mancha.
Don Vicente Gomiel de Daymel follows his example. –
tei:div.ab: Toledo capital of Carpetania. Here was the table of the shew bread taken from the Temple of Solomon. Hyacinths & emeralds. Taric took it.

Toledo taken by Xtians Christians
1085. In 17 century 200 000 souls, now 20 000.
Alonzo el Sabiothe Wise & Carlos V here.
There is a Fonda del Arzobispo The Archbishop's Inn.
Adam first King of Spain of which Toledo the Capital. Tradition.

the market place, where the houses have a very grotesque appearance 5 or 6 stories of wooden galleries – The Cathedral is a most magnificent gothic edifice, about 450 feet long, the central Aisle abt 14 yards wide the pillars 5 yds. the side Aisles 7 the pillars again 5 & the next aisle about 7 more. The windows are richly stained.
The Archbishops Palace is joined to the cathedral by an arch thrown over the street.

In the cathedral a compleat dress for the holy image of gold cloth of which very little is seen being covered with pearls and every kind of precious stone, the riches of the church are immense in silver diamonds gold rubies amethysts emeralds &ccccc. The clock has a curious method of construction for the palates which seems very good & the clock itself is of beautiful workmanship. The gothic work of the shrines in silver & painted wood the great altar the carving of the wars of Granada on the stalls in the choir 3 organs gold cups &cccc are well worth seeing. In the sacristy pictures. The church is said to be of the 12th century, but not that now standing. On the church of St Francis built by Ferdinand & Isabella after the conquest of Granada are the fetters of the Christians the King found or pretended to find imprisoned at Granada. The Palace of that Most catholic monarch joined the church and was a very moderate edifice. The palace of Rodrigo.

Of the Castillo de CervantesCastle of [San] Servando. the romance says
“Castillo de san Cervantes
“Tu que estas par de Toledo
“Cercote el Rey don Alfonzo
“Sobre las aguas de Tejo”. &c &c

"Castle of San Servando
"You who are opposite Toledo
"King Don Alfonso walled you in
"Over the waters of the Tagus". Etc etc ('Cercote' could also mean 'besieged you', but Alfonso was a benefactor of the castle)

WG may have taken this from Romancero general, en que se contienen todos los Romances que andan impressos, ed. Pedro Flores (Madrid: Juan de la Cuesta, 1614), p. 435. [Introduced as 'Otro Romance', worded exactly the same and on page before 'Letrilla', noted below.] There are many editions of Flores's collection.

tei:div.note: After Swilla it became Gothic capital
It had 150 Towers to landside 1083
Moors took it 714. Alphonso VI in May 1085.
He styled himself Emperor Magnif of Toledo.
Cid Governor in 1089 built Castle of San Cervantes. Title Imperial.

lg.note: Letrilla [Spanish poetic form, often satirical] "Good urine and good colour" "And two figs to the Doctor"

tei:div.note: The Alcasar is 80 Toises 6 480 feet above Tagus. This is a sum: 80x6=480 One toise divided into six feet.

figure.label: VENTA DE SANT ANACountry inn of Santa Ana NEAR TOLEDO
figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: landscape with building
figure.label: Moorish

tei:div.ab: last King of the Goths is now a convent near Sn Francisi.e. the church of St Francis. The college is a beautiful Ionic building, the court entered & surrounded by very handsome Ionic columns of Granite. The Church & college of the ex Jesuits is also handsome. The Alcasar or Palace is now a kind of barrack, on the highest point in the city a magnificent edifice on the site of the Moorish palace built by the Emperor Charles V as the Eagle over the door seems to indicate. It is very handsome within as far as the courts staircase. A fine gallery overlooks the deep glen of the Tagus. The Market place is called SocodoverPlaza de Zocodover. There are two bridges over the Tagus one from Aranjuez & one towd the South both handsome & picturesque. out of the Gate towd N Wtowards north-west is the church & tomb of Santa Leocadia very ancient, has been converted into a mosque & back again is of the earliest style. Council of Toledo held here. Little Brick arches. one of Sn Vincent in the town of the same architecture. The sword factory a square palace about ½ mile NW of the city, the trial of them is not so severe as in England [drawing: sword] They are begun by a piece of iron between two pieces of steel proportion 12 to 23. The work does not go on very briskly but the few workmen clever. Visited his Eminence the Cardinal Archbishop of Toledo & Seville Metropolitan of Spain Nephew of the King & aged 28.

circus Roman

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with coffee: street scene
figure.label: with Coffee

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape

tei:div.ab: Either by nature or education he seemed very humble, quiet & inoffensive, as well as rather unused to strangers. His sister the Princess of the peace was in the house with him after she fled from the mob & her husband who used her ill. The palace is by no means fine. He had the nose of the family and did not seem very lively – The canonicoi.e. canónigo: canon Don Diego de las Torres y Arze of the Order of St. YagoSantiago (St James) was very obliging & took us to all the curiosities of the city. The streets are narrow & the houses high but the town has a very interesting appearance – Saw one Arabic inscriptn. much ruined on a pillar of marble. The town contains more than 20 000 souls. Below it on the banks of the TajoTagus are gardens & country houses. once 200 000.

Now at Toledo 100 religious estab’establishments. 600 persons connected with the Cathedral. Archbishops rent before revolution 600 000 dollars. now 200 000. in 6th. Century a +church here, it became a mosque, then a + though guarrantyd to Moors Alfonso had given his word but the Queen contrived it when he was absent. The Moors alarmed sent an Alfoqin to meet him on his return in fury as it remained a Church. In Cathedral tombs of many Kings – Moorish Shepherd who guided Alfonso VIII through Sierra Morena to Las Navas de Tolosa. Painting of Jews crucifying a boy. the Quemadero The place for the execution of heretics by burning the consequence. Alcazar Fortress now existing built by Alfonso X. Church of San Juan de los Reyes has the chains, some say taken from XtiansChristians at taking of Granada? Ferdinand & Isabella.
Abu Abdallah Ben Said Mohamad ben Said chief Judge of Toledo wrote Encyclopaedia of all Sciences.

figure.note: [Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: man]
figure.label: The Archbishop Himself

figure.note: [Pen and ink drawing: man]

tei:div.note: Castille
Bill at the FondaInn sleeping 2 nights & taking 2 dinners & 2 breakfasts 12 dollars

figure.label: TOLEDO TO VAL DE PEÑASValdepeñas
figure.note: Pen and ink map with watercolour: Toledo to Valdepeñas

tei:div.ab: Helvas was فحص البلوط Albasch.
قلعه حماد Hosnalzahr or Peñaflor
حصن الزهر Calathhamad or Alamedilla
البش FahSalballuth or Llano de la Bellotas
غزوة عقاب proelium Acab or of Las NavasBattle of Al-Uqab or of Las Navas

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape with two buildings
figure.label: Nuestra Señora de ConsolacionOur Lady of Consolation
Venta de Avertura.Country inn at Avertura

tei:div.ab: Quit Toledo Octob 28 fine day at 9h. pass [drawing: arch bridge] & ascend behind the Moorish castle of CervantesSan Servando very steep ascent. On top a moorish building now called St Santa AnaCountry inn.. Venta. has a well & moorish door & garden & olives. The air scented with very aromatic Thyme. Little cultivation. 30 p 1010.30 VillVillage ½ league R hill 1 league Rright. some cultivation. Olives. 35 p 10 Venta BlancaWhite country inn. one house. L & R trees ½ mile distn. 5 p 12 pass between 2 hills, town & castle of Almonacid ruined castle Lleft 8 miles. 17 to 21.43 Villa aminayaVillaminaya probably Amin aga name of the Moor who built it. Houses round courts & wells as in greece. On one an inscriptn AMA A DIOS SOBRE TODAS LA COSASLove God above all things. it is a ruinous place. enter a dry country the people call all this side of the TajoTagus La Mancha. A road L to Mora Town & ruined castle on a hill. 5 to 4 Vill & ruined castle with arms of Castile but Turkish battlements [drawing: crenellations] or [drawing: crenellations] called MANZANIQUEManzaneque. poor village very poor Inn the Alcayde Governor (alcaide). WG has indicated 'de Manzanique'. a very poor man & the curate came to learn the news & offer what they could – The room had no windows bill for 2 & 2 servants 4 dollars & 3 shillings

Octob 29 quit ManzaniqueManzaneque at ¼ p 9h delightful day. At 10h + R & house L of Filistera large old +. a fount at it which seems the reason of building it. 15 p 10 Xcross the river running from it. 10 to 1 Las Carboneras a few
houses & well some Valencians & Murcians exactly in the common Greek dress. Some people of La Mancha with leathern doublets & the rest brown looking exactly like a rusty suit of armour. At 2h = to Consuegra town &[drawing: castle] moorish castle R. 5 p 3 fields of Saffron, blue flowers & enter Madridejos
tei:div.note: WG's translation of the Latin in Miguel Casiri, Bibliotheca arabico-hispana escurialensis..., 2 vols (Madrid: Antonio Perez de Soto, 1760-1770), vol. 1, pp. 208-11.
Ezzeddin Abdelaziz Ebn Abilcassem Babasri in the Library at Granada writes of Samarkand سمرنقدSamarkand thus or rather Amet Ben Vadeh

Lofty Samarcand deserves to be called the glory of Chorasan. the paradise of regions. Are not its towers hung so high that they elude the sight. Like the moon in a grove of trees shady. Like the full moon its rivers are the milky way & its citadels shine like Stars.
Its walls also says Hassan Ben Almonder are like the sun for roundness.
Gothic church of los Reyes Nuevosthe New Kings next after Cathedral. Many little churches built for mosques remain little altered
The AlhajasOr treasures more generally or robes of great ceremony in the cathedral invaluable.
summer hot at Toledo winter mild.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: church
figure.label: church at Madridejos

tei:div.ab: Madridejos a large mud village with a large old church not built in the form of a cross, more like some mosques but that the top has arches like the churches of Constantine.

The Bill here was 6 dollars of which waiting & beds came to 3. The Inn was kept by Gipsies. The woman who waited at dinner launched out in praise of English handkerchiefs. I got up to give one to her which was placed in the top of a trunk. She had already stolen it which produced that eulogium on the manufacture. She was going to carry off my night shirt when she had made my bed & in the morning my servant set down my shoes while the barber shaved him. The Barber managed to keep the razor at his throat while his wife stole the shoes. The servant saw her, knocked the barbers hand away & caught the woman putting the shoes into another womans pocket. The hat of one of the coachmen was also stolen –

Octob 30 fine day hot 15 to 98.45 quit Madridejos pass a +church & [drawing: arch bridge]. Abt 1 mile out is a + of wood, the stones of an anathema i.e. a votive offering & aqui murio por Violencia .…here ... died by violence a murder. A few houses L.left 15 p 1111.15 Venta de LapicheCountry inn at Lápice hills begin. Olives bear well. 15 to 12 VillVillage & pass a mile wide La Puerta de Lapiche. Don Quixote. Puerto Lápice, the site of the inn at which Don Quixote is knighted. see 40 miles of plain & the tops of a Sierra. At 10 to 2 X causeycross a causeway reeds & river running into Guadiana VillahertaVillarta de San Juan. mud village poor inn.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: man
figure.label: Boy of Mengibar

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: courtyard
figure.label: Court & Corrida de los TorosBull-ring at Church of Nra Sra de Consolacion Nuestra Señora de Consolación Our Lady of Consolation
figure.note: a very great want of consolation throughout.

tei:div.ab: Octob 31 fine but cold & white frost till about 9h. 15 to 98.45 quit VillahartaVillarta de San Juan, small place. a plain without end. sometimes uncultivated some: part of it bushy, had been woody. At 18h Casa nueva del ReyKing's New House, Post house, single house, thought unsafe to sleep at because single. Many soldiers on road. country very uninhabited from Madridejos. Qu?i.e. WG wonders is this the Venta de QuesadaCountry inn at Quesada. The Guadiana here runs underground 7 Leagues. ploughed country. The curve of the earth plainly perceptible here, first the church & then the houses of Manzanares seen. 25 to 1 a castle qu Alhambra [drawing: castle] seen Lleft distant. 30 p 11.30 MancanaresManzanares town large mud walled said to be the best town in the country. The people ugly. Saffron blue flower &c .. A couple of mules & 2 men drew two ploughs here. soon after see another country descending very little to Nuestra Señora de La ConsolacionOur Lady of Consolation: the village, Consolación, between Manzanares and Valdepeñas where arrive at 5 to 4. The place called Venta de l’ AverturaCountry inn at Avertura, consists of one miserable VentaCountry inn & the +church joined to a corrida de los TorosBull-ring & an Anchorites cell. EremitaHermit. No other houses near. A well Alarm of thieves being a single house. No appearance of any real danger but forced to watch during the greater part of the night –

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: ploughing
figure.label: Making 2 furrows

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: well
figure.label: well
VentaCountry inn of Averturas
figure.note: Pen and ink plan: interior

figure.label: PASS OF THE SIERRA MORENA
figure.note: Pen and ink map with watercolour: Pass of the Sierra Morena
Pen and ink drawing: view of Santa Cruz de Mudela

tei:div.ab:
Novr 1st a cold rainy morning but not perpetual rain, quit Nuestra Señora de Consolacioni.e. Consolación at 20 to 98.40. the pass at N.S.i.e. Consolación 4 miles wide. 25 p 1010.25 olives vines & small hills. 20 p 11 Val de PeñasValdepeñas famous for wine large ranch Vill Village . 5 to 1 X cross
[drawing: arch bridge] . 15 to 2 2 Villages L dist.t left distant 30 p 2 Santa Cruz de Mudela large Village. church picturesque. 20 p 4 a + church & Ventacountry inn dreary hills. 20 to 6 VisilloPossibly Viso del Marqués village & large inn. great stables. Bill about 5 Dollars. Visillo
N north side of the Sierra Morena Novemr 2 A rainy cold morning quit at 5m to 98.55. descend 20 to 10 X a [drawing: arch bridge] stream runs S south . 32 p 10 X [drawing: arch bridge] over the glen in which descend enter the Sierra. 30 p 11 Venta de CardeniaVenta de Cárdenas [country inn there] single house said to be a good inn [drawing: bridge] X the [drawing: arch bridge] soon after more houses or another inn. picturesque descent. Mountains seem higher as road descends & more abrupt. plenty of trees. 20 p 2 the pass tremendous trees & rocks. A place where the French lost many men. 15 to 1 more open modern ruined aquaduct. Casa or Puerta del ReyKing's House or Gate. 12 p 1 X [drawing: arch bridge]
whence leaving the glen of the river ascend much till 15 p 2 Village of St EllenaSanta Elena on a high top. Small Vill, soon after a +church & more houses L. fields & scattered
[drawing: tree] s on top. Arbutus. Andrachne &c.flowering plants 15 p 3 Venta Nueva whence a fine view over the valleys at the foot of the Sierra & beyond the vale of the Guadalquivir the high Sierra Nevada of Granada. Hence descend. Wild pears or Gall trees people were said to make ink of the fruit. 4h a Village

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: man
figure.label: Bearded Priest with a Moorish face at the ferry of the Guadalquivir Nov 3d. 1808.
section of road over the Sierra Morena
figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: road

tei:div.note: The common idea of the defence afforded by the Sierra Morena to Andalusia by the road is very strong but the mountain is passable in almost every part.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: PASS OF SIERRA MORENA
figure.note: DispeñaperrosDespeñaperros – Pitch of Dogs – made by Charles III – Le Meur french engineer

tei:div.ab: Las Navas de Tolosa, with its ruined castle a mile R.right Aloe hedges. In the village this inscriptn on a cross. EL TRIUNFO DE LA SANTA CRUZ EN MEMORIA DE LA BATALLA QUI SE DIO EN ESTE SITO DE LAS NAVAS DE TOLOSA EL AÑO DE 1212.The triumph of the Holy Cross in memory of the battle which took place on this site of Las Navas de Tolosa in the year 1212.
Hence a plain cultivated country to La Carolina a German colony placed there

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
الكتاب
الكاب
book
why called by Moors El Korb

tei:div.ab: by Carlos III consisting of a long street in the centre of which is a Hexagon 40 p 44.40. The town full of troops & the people really unconcerned as at a German Inn. Pretty fount & avenues of trees. Mulberries for Silk worms, & olives close to the town. Quit Carolina ½ p 5. many people of the Sierra speak German. Established 30 years as some of the people said. a country covered with vines & olives with aloe hedges pass a square village & through two of this shape [drawing: plan] & at 25 p 8 reach GuaromanGuarromán 2 leagues from Carolina where a large inn. pretty good, people civil. infinitely warmer than on the other side the sierra though it often rained, On the whole the Sierra by no means a precipitous mtmountain. Might be passed by infantry without touching the great road, where the pass is very dangerous.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: Venta Nueva on the top of the Sierra Morena.

tei:div.ab:
37 p 99.37 Nov 3d quit Guarroman, rainy day but not perpetual, nor cold. Guarroman a small place. X Cross
[drawing: arch bridge] & turn L left from main road beautiful woody country. Enter a very delightful glen full of trees & Rocks. Evergreen oaks & acorns good to eat 1 inch ½ long.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: Baeza.
coming down S. south side of Sierra Morena

tei:div.ab: 20 p 10 recross river, mastic & oleander bushes. Asphodels white 9 feet high. Geranion Lavender a greek thyme. holy holly – Pass through this lovely valley till 12h when a few huts. Battle of BaylenBattle of Bailén, 16-19 July 1808. 30 p 12 X [drawing: arch bridge] de Linares i.e. the bridge of Linares. in plain House R right Village JARALQUINTOJabalquinto a league L on a hill with a castle which the French before the battle of Baylen had when driven from the ferry of MenjibarMengibar by the forces from Jaen 15 to 112.45 X a road. to Jaralquinto. 10 to 2 inn & well. name like Merigivo Bones of the french. Woods in the plain very large, a road comes in from R. 40 p 2 at top of a hill ruined castle R. Gen’ RedingTheodore von Reding (1755-1809), Spanish general

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Mengíbar
figure.label: GUADALQUIVIR & MENGIBAR FROM ye the FERRY.
Here the french were beaten previous to the battle of Baylen

figure.note: Pen and ink map with watercolour: Mengíbar
Pen and ink map with watercolour: Bailén

tei:div.ab: in fact conqueror of BaylenBattle of Bailén, 16-19 July 1808. CastañosFrancisco Javier Castaños (1758-1852), Spanish general’s plan of attack was for the day after, when WedelDominique Honoré Antoine Vedel (1771-1848), French general would have arrived. See Mengibar across Guadalquivir & vale. descend to plain a river. bare corn fields. 10 p 33.10 ferry boat. the Village about a mile off Capers & the flowers of the Cephisus blue. Olives turning brown Novr Aloes. 30 p 4 uphill to the Village. We were met by a kind of Don Quixote who was very (because we called him Don Quixote) civil & shewed us two inscriptions. The town has an old tower, one church 300 houses & sent 80 men to the army for the Kingdom of Jaen. 4 leagues from Guarroman. Perhaps Mentesa of the Romans.
Hence
Elmanzor, khasara Tablahu fi Calcanasser
Was it here that a Moor saw a Spectre on the banks of the Guadalquivir which said “Almanzor has lost his drum at __? I forget the names? Where is this story.
Drum at Kalkanasor. Vid p 40.See WG's page 40 (pag 165)
tei:div.bibl: 543 Vol 1 Conde Kalat AnosorJosé Antonio Conde, Historia de la dominacion de los arabes en España, sacada de varios manuscritos y memorias arabigas, 3 vols (Madrid, 1820-1), vol. 1, p. 543: chapter 102, 'De la batalla de Calat Anosor y muerte de Almanzor' (On the battle of Calat Anosor and the death of Almanzor)
tei:div.ab: Moorish Atalayas or watch Towers
tei:div.note: غزوة عقابBattle of Al-Uqab or the battle of Las Navas [de Tolosa, 1212]
Proelium Acab or la batalla de las Navas
غداف raven

figure.note: [pencil drawing: raven]

tei:div.note: Bridge of Alcantara at Toledo built by Halaf son of Mahomed Alameri AlcaideGovernor of Toledo by order of Almanzor Aboamir Mahomat son of Abihamir alguacilsheriff of Amir Almomenin Hixem 387 years before it was repaired by D. Don Alfonso son of D Ferrando & of Queen Donna Beatriz of Castilla 1258.
tei:div.ab: INSCRIPTION in latin on a house wall in Mengibar
tei:div.note:
WG seems to have noted this inscription on the spot. His 'SEPTIMUS' is a misreading of 'SEPTIMIA' and his '[symbols] ET [symbols]' a misreading of 'TAE FILIA'. He has missed out the 'A' in 'BENEMERENS A SUIS', as well as two lines of the inscription. See photograph and transcription in Martín Jiménez Cobo, 'Las inscripciones romanas de Mengíbar', Boletín del Instituto de Estudios Giennenses, 193 (2006), pp. 17-42, at p. 32:
D.M.S.
SEPTIMIA SEPTIMI
SABINIANI MILES COHOR.
VIII PR. ET AEMILIAE IUS
TAE FILIA ADVENTA
BENEMERENS A SUIS Dedicated to the Manes [spirits of the dead] Septimia Adventa, well-deserving daughter of Septimus Sabinianus, soldier of the eighth Praetorian cohort, and of Aemilia Justa, by their friends.
tei:div.ab: Cork Hives here

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Mengíbar
figure.label: Ford of Guadalquivir or Betis

tei:div.ab:
Novr 4 no rain, fine warm day. quit Mengibar at 30 p 88.30. 5 p 9 X cross
[drawing: arch bridge] . 3 to 109.57 casa del Campocountry house InfantasLas Infantas. 4 miles L left X the river see AlmenharaAlmenara
Vill Village . 20 p 10 R close Mansana casa de campocountry house. 30 p 10 Casa Blanca 3 houses L by river. X a rivulet. 10 p 11 very fine view of Mt Mountain & castle of Jaen, over another hill. river of Jaen very pretty here a castle across it. 25 to 12 X rivulet convent L GrangeñaGrañena near. stop to draw. X a very fine rivulet 2 miles from Jaen. X 2 more after. Olives & 5 casa de camposcountry houses in them L. nearer very picturesque town & castle. Trees & woods of mulberries from the base of the town over which see the houses. Arrive at 10 p 2 4 leagues from Mengibar after stopping half an hour. Very singular town bishopric, old Houses with galleries in the Moorish taste at top. Priests much too kind. Officer took us to the Duca de Monte MarDuke of Montemar & a TertulliaTertulia, a social and/or literary gathering similar to a salon..

The whole town waited upon us so as to be very troublesome and we have great dificulty to prevent them from paying our bill at the worst Inn in the world. Jaen 20,000 inhabitants, few or no Moorish remains but their style is visible in the buildings. Visited by 5 inundations of Priests, Officers, & Peasants. The priests left the services in the cathedral to shew us the place. The cathedal fine in its way being
over door of mosque Cordova “o true believers come not to prayers when ye are drunk.”
tei:div.note: Andujar next stage. pretty place. cross river there fine meadows. Rich. Cordova = Colonia Patriciae. Seneca & Lucani.e. the Roman name for Cordoba, the birthplace of Seneca and Lucan.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: gate

tei:div.note: The Campiña or plain Cordova on R right bank of Guadalquivir Abderahman last of Omeyan dynasty 755. His great garden of Azarak. moedinos shepherds undewhence merinos. Cordova then 600 mosques, 50 hospitals 80 schools, 900 public baths. Seville had 400 000 souls, Cordova had they pretend a million. Granada 400 000. now Cordova 54000. Palmtrees. Mosque with Caaba & the Alaska of Jerusalem famous. had 39 naves by 19. 1093 columns 19 gates. Central plate of gold rest bronze 4700 lamps. Now outside 620ft by 440, walls 50ft high. 29 rows of col’ columns remain above 400. serpentine porphyri jasper granite. The 2d row of arches modern a new gothic choir

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: casa blancawhite house
Road from Mengibar.
Masana.
Kingdom of Jaen.
casa blanca

tei:div.ab: a species of Inigo Jones Greek or Roman. One of the holy faces. Santo Rostro of XtHoly Countenance of Christ [the cathedral of Jaén has a copy of the Veil of Veronica, said to bear an image of Jesus's face] preserved here & cannot be seen without many of the priests being present. fine organ. Sacristy. New & elegant Capilla del SagrarioChapel of the Sanctuary. Visit the President of the JuntaProvincial government, a little man Duca de MontemarDuke of Montemar but descended from Don Manuel Ponce de Leon. Mengibar & the Campillo de ArenesCampillo de Arenas where the Bishop defeated the Moors who were to attack Jaen under Reduan belong to him. A very well bred Señor named Aranda visited us & carried us in his coach to his Brothers, & very good house, &

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of square
figure.label: Specimin of building in towns. PLAZA Jaen. once possessed by the Moors

tei:div.ab: to the Dukes. The people played a game called viŝ a viŝ. The Duchess said she was descended from the house of Lancaster. The battle of BaylenBattle of Bailén, 16-19 July 1808 being fought so near makes this people particularly sanguinary. One youth of 16 with a mild & very good countenance had killed 11 frenchmen with a knife which he shewed us. The great houses have a court or pillars as in Moorish times. Jaen 400 years under the Moors.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: Castle & Sierra of Jaen
KINGDOM OF JAEN

tei:div.ab: The Provisor offered us rooms as indeed did many of the other Priests. One sent us two couple of fowls per force & would have sent wine. Our remonstrances against the paying of the bill succeeded, so we paid abt. 8 dollars for a very bad dinner & set out before breakfast, fearing more civilities. Indeed Don __ Aranda sent us the gazette of the battle of BaylenBattle of Bailén, 16-19 July 1808 just as we quitted the inn. The French took nothing from the cathedral. We saw a fine silver Gothic shrine for processions. But no riches like those of Toledo. Above the town on a high Mountain is a ruined castle very like a Turkish fort. The place has an interesting appearance & is not often visited by Travellers. Baeza a capital city of this kingdom is now reduced to a small town Ubeda is another but [blank space] was long the capital of the Kingdom of Jaen.
In the direct mountain road to Granada is the Campillo de Arenas.
The people of Jaen were so little accustomed to see strangers that the priests quitted the service in the Cathedral to escort us.
tei:div.note: at Seville the GiraldaThe bell tower of the cathedral now only 100 000 souls. 2,500 silk looms The AlcazarFortress is Gothic Arab & modern Cathedral 420ft by 260. high nave 82 altars 500 masses a day. Giralda built by Algeber 280 feet high on it a large iron globe guilt [drawing: globe] Spiral ascent no steps 2 horsemen abreast Spaniards added the small tower above now it is 364 feet high. on it a brass statue of faith. on the ball Alonzo de OjedaAlonso de Ojeda (c. 1466-c. 1515), conquistador stood on one leg to amuse the Queen

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: woman
figure.label: Woman of Alcaudete

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: KINGDOM OF JAEN.

tei:div.ab: Novr 5 gloomy but not cold the middle of the day fine & warm. Quit Jaen at 15 p 99.15 return on the road we came for ½ a mile then in a very bad road skirt the foot of the mountain, there being no carriage road through it. About 10 p 11 tower & olives L on Mt left on mountain foot. 10 to 1211.50 house & gardens, 20 p 12 large village & on hill castle of Torre del CampoTorredelcampo, where a decent PosadaInn Stop to breakfast. Bill with our own tea 23 reals eggs & bacon of the house. The country well spotted with wood. A fine view towd the Sierra Morena. No reason why the french should not have escaped on the left of the high road unless the Mounts of Guadalupe could have intercepted them before the battle of BaylenBattle of Bailén, 16-19 July 1808 go abt SW about south-west on base of Sierra de Jaen. Olives & fields. Ruined castle of Martos on a Mt insulated, high point. On R are the large Village of TorreximenesProbably Torredonjimeno 2 miles distt. at 35 p 2. This village is on a post road. 15 p 3 + church L qu Nra Sra de la ConsolacionWG wonders if it is Nuestra Señora de la Consolación [Our Lady of Consolation] & gardens & a [drawing: arch bridge] . 20 to 4 Martos town & castle the entrance very romantic, the castle being very much elevated & the town on the side & foot of the hill. The boys in the places on the road fond of slings. Martos has a manufacture of cloaks called Punchesi.e. ponchos - see sketch below
tei:div.note: Martos says Abul Casimi.e. [Miguel de Luna], Historia Verdadera del Rey Don Rodrigo ... Compuesta por el Sabio Alcayde Abulcacim Tarif, de Nacion Arabe (first published in 1592).True History of King Don Rodrigo... Composed by the Wise Governor Abulcacim Tarif, of the Arab Nation. As WG notes on pag 168 (his page 37), the work had long been proved a forgery by the morisco author Miguel de Luna. p 187 very strong but small. of King of Granada. 8 miles from Mentesa or Jaen. The XtiansChristians call it Mentesa.
Castillo de HicbinCastle of Hicbin.
near Martos a castle Hizn Alhicbin. taken by King Abencotba. Castillo de las AgilasCastle of the Eagles [Águilas] p 188 Abul Casim

Betiz Abenhabuz K of Granada came out against him with 2000 foot & 500 horse. Not succeeding he built near on mountain a castle Heznalquilah or Castillo de las pendencias now Castillo de AlcalaCastle of the Quarrels, now Castle of Alcalá.
Hozonal = Castillo de dizensionesCastle of dissensions [disensiones] 4 castles against Cordoba & one called Hezntar – del dueloof mourning towd the sea.
Sevilla = Hispala = Medinat Himz. from an alcaydegovernor (alcaide), Roman ruins are found at Martos, & Corduba. & at Toledo.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: man
Pen and ink drawing with watercolour: poncho
figure.label: A man of Jaen, in A Ponchei.e. poncho

tei:div.note: Woman of Alcaudete dressed like Turks

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: VIEW NEAR ALCU[DETE]Alcaudete

tei:div.ab: Nov 6 cloudy but warm. bill 6 dollars but civil people. South of the Guadalquivir, the beds are made on the ground as in Turkey, & the chairs are not in general above a foot high. People at the PosadaInn very civil. Some of the inhabitants of Martos which is a large town called upon us to offer any thing we might want. quit Martos ½ p 88.30. 30 p 9 covered with olives & woods of prickly oak, fine country the Sierra de Aguilla Lleft a peaked mountain whence the nameáguila: eagle. 14 p 10 house L. descend & Xcross river then a hill. recross branch of same river 32 p 11 by a ford & [drawing: arch bridge] with a large cavern in the rock. hills very fine. a castle R.right Oleanders. Ascend very steep hill till 1h. fine view both ways. under the peak woods & fields, like the Nomian MtsMountains. descend. 20 p 1 fount & posadaInn of AlcudeteAlcaudete a town on the post road with a very picturesque castle & +. Turn L still keeping the Aguilla L. Olives, Women in Turkish dress red gowns & white shawl veils, At a garden some very fine cypresses & a summer house. X a [drawing: arch bridge]. 30 p 2 descending [+ in box]monastery & cypresses. A tower on hill R. having passed another watch tower before, At 3h a few houses CortejoProbably Cortijo (farmhouse) de los Señores. X 10 p 3 a river to them the Algodone & ascend. R 2 more watch towers. 20 to 4h3.40 Vill & ventaVillage and country inn
tei:div.note: Ferdinand IV K Castille & Leon ordered 2 Carvajals to be thrown from Rock of Martos suppose not Peña de los enamoradosLovers' Rock No, for having murdered a Courtier. Benavides. They dying summoned the King to appear in 30 days before God, which he dying did. An English Play in 1832 made on this –

tei:div.ab: The road as bad as where there is no post. or worse. very steep & bad hill. 30 p 55.30 after a very steep hill houses. After this a moor* with the castle of Alcala la Real at the other end, at the other side of which is the town which reach at 10 to 76.50. A good PosadaInn but the people had no money to buy eggs & bacon. At Alcala houses made of good stone & strongly built. There is a very pretty garden with walks & trees at the SEsouth-east entry of the town. the castle is in ruins in it is a +church. Many stone crosses about. The fount ornamented with arabesques almost five feet high. griffins & men. The streets good & people civil. Jalousies or lattices as in turkey, remains of Moorish custom. 30 p 9 quit gate trees & [drawing: triangle] chapel. At 10h fount soon after Xcross a brook very bad or no road, a road turns R qu to Alloraright. WG wonders if it is to Álora., brook runs with road. corn & spotted trees. 10 p 1 descend after steep & muddy ascent among fine Mountains & trees. see a magnificent cap in front in the MtsMountains 30 p 1 through which the VegaFertile Plain & city of of Granada. & 3 Atalayas castles or watch towers. the scenery quite beautiful, Road turns R. 15 to 2 X [drawing: arch bridge] in the vale. 35 p 2 Vill Puente de LopezVillage Puerto Lope. small Vill. good posadainn civil people. rather cold people say never snows 3 leagues from Alcala beautiful country.
tei:div.note: *It being dark the road was rather dangerous. passing 2 or 3 streams.
VIEW 118pag 079 (WG's page 118)

bill 6 dollars. At Alcala the beds on the floor. even at Jaen beds on legs were particular “camas de madeira”beds, either Madeira-style or (more likely) wooden (de madera). A blanket of cotton softer than Indian shawle & very warm said to be made at Granada & to cost 6 dollars.

tei:div.note: The King broke his lance on passing thro’ it against the Arch. Omen. Taken Prisoner.

tei:div.ab: 15 to 98.45 Nov 8 a gloomy day with some rain quit PUENTE DE LOPEZPuerto Lope. Bill abt 5 dollars. ascend. steep. pass between two towers abt 2 miles distt & at 20 to 10 see vill of YLORAvillage of Íllora & its ruined castle R.right descend, uneven uncultivated ground. spotted Trees. 30 p 1010.30 see the Sierra Nevada & the VegaFertile Plain or vale of Granada. At 11h. a Tumulus artificial R. 10 p 11 Xcross [drawing: arch bridge] over the muddy river of Velilla quWG wonders if the river is called 'Velilla'. It is the Velillos.. Houses L. 20 to 2, Pinos Puente a large mud village houses painted pink church doditto (i.e. also painted pink) with pilasters. 15 to 12 the [drawing: arch bridge] high canes perhaps 15 ft. Juego de Cañas?A game, supposedly of Moorish origin, played on horseback in the main squares of early modern Spain (literally, the 'reed game'). Gardens. 20 p 12 ruined tower in wood R. Turn Angle of Mt Elvira close out. from which < between a low peak on the hills R of valley & StSanta Elena above the Alhambra 51o. 30’. <angle between St Elena end of Sierra Nevada about 41o. 20 to 1 stone 1 league ½ from Granada. < 56o. 30’. from Alhambra to peak R. < 93 from peak R to a peak [drawing: hill] L.
tei:div.note: in Puerto LopezPuerto Lope pass

Temp. ImpIn the time of the emperor Carlos V. he came to pass a summer at Granada. was making a severe law against Moors but they sent him 80000 Ducats on which he moderated his edict. gave them leave to wear los trages moriscosMoorish dress. Of the 80000 ducats he gave 18000 to build his palace in the Alhambra. Covarrubios was the Architect?.
Sr Piedro Machucha maestro major de las obras de GranadaMr Piedro Machucha [Pedro Machuca], chief master of works at Granada
Built the new & fine Palace

Village Atarfe & the pointed rocky peak in line L, in line, Vill abt 400 yds dist L. Canes. 40 p 11.40 a house L. one league stone. L from St Elena to peak R 70o30’. St Elena to peak L 44. At 2h enter olives a house L & a Kiosk. XCross a [drawing: arch bridge]. 5 p 2 ½ league stone & house L. olives & Kiosk, one on left quite pretty with an avenue of Cypresses to a house. 20 to 32.40 X [drawing: arch bridge] over a dry bed & enter Granada. Palm trees. Gate of Elvira & CalleStreet leading up to Plaza Nueva & Alhambra Amphitheatre or CorridaBull-ring. Sole PosadaInn not very good.

tei:div.ab: The women asked whether we liked our beds made on the floor or upon bed steads. The town seems very flourishing. houses very neat. on the outside, several of the old ones have galleries at top as at JAEN.

The town of Elvira no longer exists, but the Sierra at PuentePinos Puente del pino retains the names. CaparsenaCaparacena a village belonging to the duke of Gor has many moorish antiquities such as sepulchres found there. The pass towd MochlinMoclín, the E point of Mteast point of Mount Elvira & Alhambra in a line. The Fuentesic, not Puente as above. i.e. Pinos Puente del Pino probably one mentioned to us as two leagues on the road pas’t the CartuxaCartuja Monastery towd Albolote.

looking Back

tei:div.ab: The Alhambra at Granada is upon the lower step of a Mountain, with a deep ravine to the Darro on the Lleft another on the Rright & a third which divides it from the Generalife a Moorish Kiosk & garden, higher up the MtMountain. The Gate & Calle deStreet of Elvira the Plaza Nueva & the Calle de Los Gomeles lead to the gate of the Granadas betwen the Torre de la Campana or Vela or watchTorre de la Vela [Watch Tower] & the Torres BermeijasTorres Bermejas (Vermillion Towers) The last house in the C de los Gomeles evidently of Moorish construction, it has fountains & a court with arcades. & is built like the Alhambra [drawing: brick] several summer houses with cypresses in this street retain their original appearance. some of the jalousies are quite Turkish. The town is full of Moorish houses, consisting generally of a tower or moorish arch a court & 4 or 5 stories of galleries [drawing: galleries] within which are rooms. The plaza de Bivarambla is abt long & broad the houses from 5 to 6 stories of these galleries & except the custom house & the Archbishops palace just as it was. in it is the fount of the LeoncilloYoung Lion the lion of which may be Moorish. Even yet the place is used for great
tei:div.note: Spiders are said not to pass over the plaister work of the Moors. while over that of the Kings of Spain in the Alhambra there are many webs. –
Subterraneous passages in the rock of the Alhambra, said to lead to all parts of the City.

Near the Darro above the PaseoPromenade opposite to the Puente de CarbonPuente de Carbón [literally, Coal Bridge] on Passeo a Moorish house compleat with a door in a tower like the Alhambra equally good. gold red & blue the house a square court. 3 stories high [drawing: galleries] The horse guards of the Moorish Kings

The Plaza de BivaramblaPlaza de Bib-Rambla or Bibarrambla is except the Archbishops house as it was in the time of the Juego de CañasA game, supposedly of Moorish origin, played on horseback in the main squares of early modern Spain (literally, the 'reed game'). &c. being abt 6 stories high & all in galleries. Exept also the Custom house which is new. The Tocador de La ReynaQueen's Boudoir is in a moorish tower though painted afresh by the King of Spains painters. KI Carolus imperatorEmperor Charles is painted on many parts of the adjacent buildings.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Atarfe
figure.label: in Vega de Granadain the Fertile Plain of Granada

tei:div.ab: functions & religious processions. the magistrate retaining their gallery on the top of the Custom house, where probably was the Royal Mirador El MirabMirador: balcony/oriel Mirab = mihrab: a niche indicating the direction of Mecca.. The houses opposite the sun have had shades. In some the Turkish lattice work yet remains perfect. The famous calle de ZacatinCalle Zacatín runs from the S.E.south-east corner of the BivaramblaPlaza de Bib-Rambla or Bibarrambla to the Plaza Nueva & is abt 12 feet wide. The Calle de Elvira may be about 18. that of the Gomeles wider. The Cathedral was a mosque but the court is now filled up by the nave. the circle of the Mosque is still preserved at least the form, & is very handsome with rich windows, & is entirely gilt. The place much subject to earthquakes, & the Cathedral has lately suffered. They say scarcely a fortnight passes without a shock. The houses seldom fall but the Moorish towers often fail. The moors had a way of building with earth & gravel in appearance & brick on the outside which seems to stand wonderfully well. Every house in Granada has one or more fountains.
tei:div.note: The Spanish Kings have in many parts spoiled the open Moorish Galleries by filling up the intercolumniations. particularly near the Tocador or peinador della ReynaQueen's Boudoir or Dressing Room & the apartments of the mad queenJuana I ('la loca': the mad) of Castile, 1479-1555, wife of Filipe I of Castile. who was literally confined toward the court by iron bars. Wherever the Spaniards have touched the building it is ruined, both in taste execution & durability – They have imitated the tiles azulejos of the Moors ill & their plaister work worse. besides tearing up, the moorish pavements of green & white tiles with the colours of different patterns chiefly blue yellow & green, to place among the dusty Spanish bricks. The first court has a cistern, all is entirely a white marble pavement throughout the whole court.
Gold fish, now muddy water.
The gilding of the moorish roofs remains in many parts but the delicacy of the ornaments
