tei:div.ab: Every street is also supplied with water as the Sierra Nevada never fails in winter or summer. Almost all houses are built round a court & many have marble pillars of Arabic workmanship. Oranges & Lemons flourish here. An American fruit called Chiremolias yas looking like an artichoke but with a continued skin & containing seeds & a white pulp like good butter & sugar grows at Granada. One of the gates near the plaza de BibaramblaPlaza de Bib-Rambla or Bibarrambla is called the
tei:div.note: is wonderful. The arabesques consist in patterns of flowers & fancy meanders very sharply executed in very white & hard plaster on grounds of blue & red & sometimes gold.
An inscription seems very often repeated as are indeed the flowers &…
Court of the Lions pillars diminish little if at all. About 8 feet high, white marble.
tei:div.label: Granada to Malaga Novr 28. 1808
tei:div.ab: 28 Novr.

At 30 p 1212.30 quit the Puerta de ElviraThe Elvira Gate in two Caleshes. price 30 dollars. misty morning, clear in the middle of the day & a cold wind afterwards. 30 p 1 Xcross the river XenilGenil over a wooden bridge. little water, being all consumed in irrigations. In 1h & 50m1 hour and 50 minutes reach 2 leagues? Santa Fe, the camp & town of Ferdinand & Isabella. still a square in form. 2 churches. flat. The Soto de Roma of Kings of Granada, now of the Duke of WellingtonThis is a later addition, as Wellington was made a duke in 1814. belonged to GodoyManuel Godoy (1767-1851), Spanish minister who+ had a district entirely independent of the ChancilleriaChancellery [cancillería] of Granada, with a house & an officer of his own. In 2h & 40m from Granada pass Rright Tchaouchina VillChauchina Village. a castle or house 2 miles Lleft on hills. Pinos Puente which we had passed through is on the R abt 3 miles. Its river comes from a gap in the MtsMountains 3h, 30m from G a vill R & old tower. hills on L approach. 3h 40m from GGranada, Village of LacaLáchar Xenil R near. 15This [15] may be smudged out The plain ends. 15 p 7 Venta de Casina CacinCountry inn at Cacín a good river of same name.
tei:div.note: white marble columns of MachelMacael.
Granada 1173 Varas of Castille high above sea
Sierra Nevada top 4254 Varas 3 inches & 5 lines high
Muley HassanMulhacén seems the highest top from the VegaFertile Plain
there are two tops
A vara 3 feet each foot 10 in 7/8
Veleta other top of Sierra
Alhambra 150 Varas above the Darro.
Xenil in latin Sirgilis
it has more water in summer than winter & in the evening more than in the morning from the Sun of the day.
Comares sometimes Comaresch
Anciently there were fine courts -+ qu PaseosWG wonders if this is in Juan de Echeverría, Paseos por Granada y sus contornos..., 2 vols (2nd edn, Granada, 1814), or Echeverría's 1764 original. .
Moorish Kings property
Public audience in the great Hall called Mexuar. the King sate on a carpet Alcatif the council round him. The guard were african Moors.
X a river from L.
Allah acbar. great almighty Gd the war cry.
Their telegraphic towers.

Hernando dal PulgarHernando del Pulgar (1436-c.1492), Crónica de los Reyes Católicos (1545, and many later editions). says in tempin the time of Juseph Abulhagiageh in 14th century Granada had 70 000 houses. In 1311 there were 200 000 inhabts about 500 were real full Moors &c… 50,000 rengadoe 30000 captives in the Kingdom
at most 350 000 souls
A road turns L to Alhama not far off

ao 1476 marmolLuis del Mármol Carvajal (1520-1600), Historia de la rebelión y castigo de los moriscos del reino de Granada (Málaga, 1600; Madrid, 1797) says there were 30,000 vecinosinhabitants. 8000 Knights 25000 slinges. & in 3 days 50,000.
tei:div.ab: XenilGenil runs near the road R. right At 15 p 99.15 Venta de PulgarVenta Del Pulgar [i.e. the country inn there], a decent place – People very civil bill 46 reals or abt 11 shillings.

29 of Novr a grey day threatened but did not rain, in the evening abt. sunset the thermometer about temperate 55o. The Xenil runs in a valley with rocky hills on sides & a cultivated valley with olives. something like entry of Llangollen but not so rich.

The sierra de Alhama
L. In 1h 25m left in 1 hour 25 minutes reach Loja having xd crossed a stream. a gate & fount. Very turkish appearance, & cypresses. More of the town R of the river Xenil. Narrow streets still galleries on tops of houses.

About a mile beyond Loja or Loxa the Xenil turns off R towd Guadalquivir by a rocky pass with caves called “Los infiernos de Loja”The hells of Loja. Ascend then down to a river running to Xenil in 2h. 20m. Ascend steep hills. Greek thyme Geranion lavender squills & cistus. 5h 15m on a top prickly oaks Belotesbellotas: acorns, the acorns very good for men & pigs men whith long poles to beat them down.
tei:div.note: BELOTES

In the 130 water-mills. & 300 pleasure houses. Masdew Juan Francisco Masdeu (1744-1817), Storia critica di Spagne e della cultura spagnuola in ogni genere (1781-4); Historia crítica de España y de la cultura española (1783–1805)..

Devastation of the country Pulgar says in Mala alone the Spaniard destroyed & burnt 300 towers & houses & in Alhendin a league of olive gardens Panes & vines. In 1491 near Padul 15 places & 9 hamlets were burn’t.From Hernando del Pulgar (1436-c.1492), Crónica de los Reyes Católicos (1545, and many later editions).

Commerce between Moors & China cause of the fine vases & tiles. Silk cotton wood leather. Velvet. silk worth its weight in gold, cloth, glass. mining. Arabs traded to Qüantory & had a factory & Cadii.e. qadi, a judge of Islamic law.. Mines of gold & silver or rather washing sand, but copper lead iron marcasite & zafilica'zafiro' would be sapphire.

Musical instruments 31 in number but a doctor in ao 618AH 618 of Hejira called Ramaleddin Giafor proved from the Koran that music & shews were improper among the names of four who wrote treatises of music Avicena in the library of Escorial

figure.note: Pencil drawing with watercolour: man

tei:div.note: The fatimite Library contained 1000 suppose 100000 M.S.S. in Cairo. but the Omniades of Spain had 600,000 with a catalogue of 40 Vols. The Arabs had 70 libraries in cities of Spain Ali Beker Mohamad says this –. A Female poet at Granada Naschina in the 5th Hegira and Mosada in the 6th century Moghia & Leila 2 others. Some greek works only preserved by their translations.This is similar to David Brewster (ed.), The Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, 18 vols (Edinburgh, 1830), vol. 18, p. 445, and his main source, William Jacob, Travels in the South of Spain, in Letters Written A.D. 1809 and 1810 (London, 1811), including the spelling of 'Omniades' (i.e. Ommiades, the Umayyads), but WG also has some extra detail so must be drawing on another text.
Zenith Nadir Azimuth &c. arabic names.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: ploughing
figure.label: 9 Peasants Ploughing each taking a different furrow

tei:div.ab: a great deal of ploughed country. 9 couple of oxen & 9 men with ploughs in one field. People all travel armed in this country. the top of the Sierra at 30 p 6 or 6h & 30min 6.30 see the [drawing: hill] hill near Loja but R right of the XenilGenil remarkable from Granada backwards & a very fine Rock near Antequera more remarkable than the Acrocinuttros forward peña de los enamoradosLovers' Rock. descend steep hill always trees, whole country prettily spotted with prickly oak. 7h all but 15m 7 hours all but 15 minutes a ventacountry inn. Aloe hedges. In 7h reach the Venta de ArchidoneCountry inn at Archidona a clean place. VideSee View 2 leaves back. No Spaniard knows anything about the small inns on the road.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: townscape

tei:div.note: The royal fortress of Alhambra 2690 castille feet long 630 wide the wall 2 varas thick about 10 & ½ high. 2 great gates & one less & communicatd with GeneraliphGeneralife. Tapiale of chinarroMud wall of large pebbles & Earth of the place & a very little lime. different durability.

The Alhambra begun by Mahmet abu Abdallah Benjusuph Ben Ahmed Naserita (a family name) or Elgaleb Billah or Vencedor por diosVictor through God. died 1273. Alhamra or the red city – the 3d king of the NaseritasNasrids Muhamed Abu Abdallah built a mosque all painted with mosaic with columns with bases & capitals of silver.

The gate of judgemt between 2 towns 24 varas high & ½ each 6 varas broad altogether 18 varas. the arch 11 varas & ½ high from ground on the key stone the arm & hand.. the [drawing: arch?] Drawing shows arch is 6 varas high arch is 3 varas ½ broad. marble of MachaelMacael. Praised be god there is no God but god & Mahmet his prophet & there is no strength but gods. an inscript Arabic says AbudHagex Yusuph son of King Abulgualid aben Nacer April 1349.
Vide Vara measure in page of the Scoldi.e. See measurement of Spanish vara, perhaps on a page that includes a drawing of a woman. WG's measurement is on pag 190 (his p. 13), which is otherwise blank.

figure.label: The gigs from Granada to Malaga
figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: horses and carriages

tei:div.ab: In verse in the hall of Comares

From the rising to the setting of the sun all Arabia the happy salutes thee, & all the universe. This is the high conclave & we are its daughters. truly I have preference & the Glory in my race or species & I am the members of the heart without any division among them, for in the heart the force of the body & soul (spirit) originates.This seems to be WG's attempt at the Spanish given in the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando’s Antigüedades árabes de España. Parte segunda (Madrid, 1804), [hereafter, Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2,] p. 12: 'Desde que amenece hasta que anochece te saluda toda la Arabia feliz y todo el universo. Este es el alto cónclave, y nosotras sus hijas; bien que yo tengo la preferencia y la gloria en mi género, y soy los miembros del corazon, sin que haya entre ellos division ninguna, como que en el corazon tiene su orígen la fuerza del alma y del espíritu.'

another. “Y aunque sean mi adorno los signos de su cielo, con todo se echa en mi de menos el resplandor del sol que hace entre ellos. Cubrióme mi glorioso senor Juseph con vestida de alegria y primor sin necesitar de otro vestido; y me hizo trono regio, cuya altura iguala con verdad a la luz al talamo y al trono celestial.”From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 12.And although the signs of his sky are my ornament, yet I miss the radiance of the sun that shines [AA: 'luce', not 'hace'] between them. My glorious Lord Jusef covered me in clothes of joy and beauty without needing other clothing; and made me a royal throne, whose height truly equals the light, the marriage bed and the celestial throne. the iron balconies placed in 1632. Inscription mentioning the beauty of this hall of the EmbaxadoresAmbassadors. Antiqüedades arabes. 1604. O hijo de Rey e descendiente de Reyes y à quien las estrellas en alteza no igualan, si a te se comparan! Si edificaste e ilustraste este tan rico alcazar, que es singular y de aventajada hermosura; palacio donde se demuestran las singulares excelencias de esta gobernacion, que en las escrituras se aclaran. Con el la ley de la salvacion ensalzaste en tanto grado que no se puede significcar, ilustrandola y a sus sequaces con extrema ventaja de seguridad y honor; por lo qual te son a cargo; pues con todos sus vasallos demostras amparo miserecordia justicia liberalidad soalzacion clemencia e ninguna crueldad e injusticia” From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 13Oh son of a King and descendant of Kings, and whom the stars do not equal in highness, if they are compared to you! If you built and illustrated [or improved?] so rich a fortress as this, which is singular and of outstanding beauty; a palace where the singular excellencies of this government are shown, which become clear in the scriptures. With it you extolled the law of salvation to such a degree that [to say] illustrating [or improving?] it and its minions with the extreme benefit of safety and honour, cannot capture it, for which reason they are in your charge, since with all your [AA has 'tus'] vassals you show [AA: 'demostrais'] protection, mercy [AA: 'misericordia'], justice, liberality, solace, clemency, and no cruelty or [AA: 'ni'] injustice.Translation of 'soalzacion' as 'solace' based on Juan de Echeverría, Paseos por Granada y sus contornos..., 2 vols (2nd edn, Granada, 1814), vol. 1, p. 121, which suggests 'consuelo', 'alegria' or 'alabanza' as synonyms for what Echeverría recognises as a rare word–

On another. “Es el Rey Nasere el mayor de los Reyes; de cuya corte salen las grandezas de los triunfos, es el adestrador leader con poderio y valor, que a todos las naciones pone espanto. Es el que, si en el hemisferio se presentase, serian excusados en el los luceros. Es el que a los Reyes admira la limpieza de su nacimiento, e a quien los grandes imitan, viendo xFrom Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 13.The Nasrid King is the greatest of Kings; from whose court come the grandeurs of triumphs; he is the skilled one with might and courage, who terrifies all nations. It is he who, if he appeared in the hemisphere, the stars would be dismissed by him. It is he who provokes admiration among Kings for the purity of his birth, and he whom the great imitate, seeing... [how admirably he has dispensed his rigour and his clemency with those to whom he owes it]WG has corrected to 'adestrador', which he translates as 'leader', but Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 13 does have 'el adestrado' (skilled one).

note.rs: Patio de los ArrayonesCourt of the Myrtles

tei:div.note: Inscriptions of the first court God alone is the conqueror. other inscrip in same court. The omnipotence of God Give glory to our lord & King Abulhagiagi whom god preserve. In the upper gallery an arch of 3 varasUnit of measurement, explained on pag 190. ½ lead to a chamber over the vestibule before the palace of Carlos 5 was built
The walls of cistern court 24 feet high Castilian. The cistern 124 feet high 27 wide 5 deep. the doors of this court are 4 feet ½ broad 8 high. above the 2 windows God alone is the conqueror.

Aben Hut Almayars arms says Bermudes de Pedraza. Argt on a band Sa There is no conqueror but God. sometimes a red hand.Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 6: 'Aben Hut Alnayar'. Antigüedades Arabes here cites Francisco Bermudez de Pedraza, Historia de la antigüedad y excelencias de Granada (Madrid: Luis Sanchez, 1608). Aben Hut Alnayar's arms were a black band on a silver field, with letters saying 'There is no conqueror but God'. The antechamber roofed [drawing: arch]
the kind of work called Comarragia, Niches alternate gold blue white & red.

on targets Dese alabanza a solo Dios y. de consiguiente dense gracias al mismo DiosFrom Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 10.Give praise to God alone, and therefore give thanks to the same God [or God himself].. The hall 40 feet square by 68. iii. The tiles 1 vara ½ high above this in ovals “o god to thee be given honour for ever. & o lord to thee incessant thanks. Give honor & glory to the King our Lord Abu Abdallah Elgani Billah

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape
figure.label: Peña de los EnamoradosLovers' Rock near.
The Moor had a Castle on the top. Peña de los Enamorados Lovers' Rock near.
Story of the Moor against whose caslte the Queen came by a miraculous road. He leaped down.

tei:div.ab: The Venta de ArchidoneCountry inn at Archidona rather a good house. bill 5 dollars all but 2 shillings – quit it at 12h. L Left a large town called ArchidoneArchidona with a ruined castle. The plain Arcadian that is the mts mountains rise at once from the flat. Robbers said to be deserters in the country one taken up at the corner of our ventacountry inn this morning. In about an hour, at the end of the plain ascend from it leaving the Peña de los EnamoradosLovers' Rock L & the river of the valley left again of it. Story of an inhabt of Antequera running away with his mistress faster than the Justice could pursue on horseback. They threw themselves at length from the top. the rock really overhangs. A fine view at the top of the vale of Antequera very large, & the town of Antequera. the VegaFertile Plain very flat several trees. rich in corn. Abt 2h X About 2pm cross the river from Archidone. at 3h 40m3.40pm Antequera. in the way stones ancient Roman mark the road in the plain. Antiquera Anticaria large.
tei:div.note: + quan admirablemente ha dispensado su rigor y clemencia con los que debe; entendiendo que en dispensar sus tesoros en esto era la posesion que de ellos hascia. Perpetuamente quede sublimado en alteza; a la qual todos los Reyes se humillen e teman el furor de la execution de su shoulder espadla espalda ansi los naturales Moros, como los de otra qualquiera nacion.” From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, pp. 13-14. [It is he who provokes admiration among Kings for the purity of his birth, and he whom the great imitate, seeing...] how admirably he has granted his rigour and his clemency to those to whom he owes it [hascia=hacía]; understanding that the possession of his treasures lay in granting them. He remains perpetually sublimated in highness; before which all Kings humble themselves and fear the use [AA has 'execucion'] of his sword, native Moors like those of any other nation. AA has 'espada' (sword), but WG has confused this with 'espalda' (back or sometimes shoulder), which he has itself corrected from 'espadla'.Another

“Soy estrado carpet de esposo de linda hermosura y cumplimiento. Y si quieres ver la razon de lo que digo mirad la hermosura desde mi caliz e avertid en mi corona y tiara; y vereis como es semejante a la de la luna. Y Aben Nasëre es el Sol de mi orbe, de rutilante hermosura e ser resplandor, luce en alteza de estado, seguro de toda ausencia y apartamiento” From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14. I am a husband's carpeted room of beautiful loveliness and accomplishment. And if you want to see the truth of what I say, look at the beauty of this [AA has 'deste'] my chalice, and notice [AA has 'advertid'] [the beauty] of my crown and tiara, and you will see how alike it is to that of the moon. And Aben Nasere is the sun of my world, of glittering beauty and radiance [AA has no 'ser']: he shines in highness of status, safe from all want and isolation. Another

ornament Soy decoration aseo de magnificencia señal y hechura que sobrepuja surpasses a la felicidad: entendereis ser en este mi atavio ornament, este precioso caliz, alguno que esta en pie cumpliendo su oracion. Y todo lo que de el se vacia conviene que luego se le reitere; e con mi Señor Aben Nasere ennoblecio dios sus criaturas que procede del senor Alhazragi Zahade Aben Obeda.From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14. I am a washroom of magnificence, a sign and a work that surpasses happiness: you will understand that in this my attire, this precious chalice, is one who is on his feet fulfilling his prayer. And all that is drained from it should later be replaced; and with my Lord Aben Nasere, God ennobled his creatures, who [Aben Nasere] proceeds from Lord Alhazragi Zahde [according to AA] Aben Obeda. WG has corrected an apparent printing error in Antigüedades árabes, which gives 'rodo lo que...' rather than 'todo'.
tei:div.ab: Antequera taken 1410 from Moors. Juseph Kg of Granada succeded Mahomet who died of a poisoned shirt. Ali sent by Juseph to Valladolid to Kg Don Juan, brought horses, velvet, raisins, figs almonds but the Queen prevented more truce, for he would not say Joseph was vassal of Spain in 1409.

InfanteA son of the king. In this case, the future Fernando I of Aragon, younger son of Juan I of Castile. came to Cordova in feby. & besieged Antequera with 10 000 foot & 2500 horse. Sancho de Rojas Bishop of Palencia & Ct Count Martin Velasquez. Kg of Granada sent 5000 horse & 80 000 foot & his 2 Brothers Cidi Ali & Sidi Hamat but they were beat off, but Martyn Ruys de Avedaño killed by poisoned arrow.
A Real at Antequera.

ill placed old moorish looking town with a ruined castle. Some remains of moorish walls. Town composed of high tumbling houses ready for the first earthquake. Gardens before it well watered – There had been a Castle & a Royal Palace. It is a venerable old ruinous place. Stop about 2 hours for 3 guards there being thieves in the way. The people quite ignorant, took us for french which they knew was impossible. Hence a very uneven road with some picturesque mills & then a very steep ascent with a poor ventacountry inn, arrive at the top in a cold misty rocky place 1 league & ½ see the sea & descending a little a ventacountry inn, Venta Nueva a poor place the poorest we had seen where sleep. Quit Venta Nueva Decr 1st early cold strong wind & mist. Hence 7 leagues & ¼ to Malaga of which 6 are a steep & winding descent. In the course of the first hour the climate changed. A bridge & custom house in about a league it became warm, dwarf palms thyme in flower & all the shrubs of the Mediterranean coasts. In a short
tei:div.note: In hall of comares 6th “Sutilizaronse las manos del artifice di me tez e lustre, despues de ser adornadas las perlas de mi corona e tiara; e parecen en semejanza de aseo decoration e tribunal de esposo, al qual y demas en mi, hay ventaja. porque en mi esta segura la felicidad de mi esposo – El, que a mi se allegare con demanda de quitar la sed, en mi hallara hartar con licor claro e puro, sin macula ni comistion alguna, E ansi soy semejante al arco de la oscuridad que aparece; y el sol de ella es mi Señor Abulhagex: siempre luce su palacio seguro como el palacio divino durara abrigo e amparo de los bienaventurados.”From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14.The hands of the architect of my [AA: 'de mi'] colour and lustre were made subtle [AA: 'Subtilizáronse'], after the pearls of my crown and tiara were adorned, and they seemed in likeness to the washroom and the husband's court, to which and so forth there is an advantage in me, because in me the happiness of my husband is assured. He who approaches me with a desire to quench his thirst, will find in me plenty [AA: 'hartura'] of clear and pure liquor, without any taint or mixture. And so I am like the arc of darkness that appears; and its [the darkness's] sun is my Lord Abulhagex [AA: 'la obscuridad que aparece, y el sol della es mi Señor Abulhachex']: his safe palace always shines as the divine palace will last, shelter and protection of the blessed. There was perhaps a fount in this hall – PaseosJuan de Echeverría, Paseos por Granada y sus contornos..., 2 vols (2nd edn, Granada, 1814). WG may equally have been using Echeverría's 1764 original..

figure.note: Pencil drawing with watercolour: man
figure.label: Jew

tei:div.label: Hall of Comares.
tei:div.note: “llevo ventaja à los hermosos con mi amicto y tiara; e ansi se declinan a mi los rutilantes luceros del cielo en los signos. Parece en mi el agua en manera de religioso, que puesto al medio dia del lugar de su oracion se pone a orar: seguras estan por la sucession del tiempo, mis ventajas: mi deseo es hartar al que esta sediento, en manera que parece haber yo demostrado esta obra liberal de la mano de mi senor Abialhagex. Siempre dure en mi orbe lucero espléndido ansi como los luceros del cielo fueron ilustrando la oscura tiniebla.From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14.I outmatch the beautiful with my amice [vestment worn around neck and shoulders] and tiara; and so the glittering stars in the sky decline to me in the signs. Water seems a kind of devotee to me, which, put at midday in the spot of its prayer, begins to pray: my benefits are safe against the passage of time [AA: 'la sucesion de los tiempos']: my desire is to satiate those who thirst, in such a way that I seem to have demonstrated this liberal work by the hand of my lord Abialhagex. May a splendid star always last in my world, like the stars in the sky light up [AA: 'fueren ilustrando'] the gloomy darkness.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Málaga
figure.label: AT. MALAGA C: Camera Lucida

tei:div.ab: time we came to olives & a burning red soil the mountains very steep sometimes covered with vines in terraces, sometimes with broom. A clear River ran on the right the road made with care & very good, sometimes conducted zigzag up a rocky point to avoid the circuit of a very long peninsular Mt Mountains . Stop to water our horses at a VentaCountry inn where is an oil mill. Prickly fig hedges & aloes. A monastery with cypresses and oranges. At length in a broiling day Dec 1 come in sight of the plain of Malaga, bare but cultivated, with farm houses but no trees Better about the town, the descent becomes less rapid half a league from the city. Pass a Monastery with a fine walled grove of oranges & lemons R. right See a fine Casa de Campocountry house & oranges L left once belonging to the Jesuits. At Malaga the climate Dec 1. 2. 3. & 4 quite delightful, much too hot in the sun & the nights not cold. In the sun the Thermometer rose immediately to 95 & in the coldest situations was about 65 Dec 4. Green Pease cauliflowers &.. plentiful. Almost all the walls built by the moors. but not now walled round. A good moorish gate near the Alameyda or parade. Fine cathedral & organ. the port made by a natural projection & a pier. The sea & sky equally serene. The Thermometer from 70 to 76 & 78 from Decr 1 to 20 & only one cold wind during that time from N.W. north-west The number
tei:div.note: The venta de GalvesGálvez country inn a large inn on the road close on R

In 1364 when Kg Don Pedro held his court at Sevilla “mandò facer estas alcaçares e estos palacios e estas portadas que fue hecho en la era de mil e quatrocientos e dos” He ordered these fortresses and these palaces and these façades to be made, which were finished around [in the era of] 1402 WG seems to have corrected Llaguno y Amírola's 'fecho' to 'hecho'.Inscription on frize. This by Arab architects

The sala llamada de Embajadores del mismo alcazarThe hall known as that of the Ambassadors in the same fortress.. But Jalubi of Toledo first built the palace as says inscripn in Arabic. “Jalubi fue el arquitecto di mi obra y maestro mayor. Fue venido de Toledo con los demas maestros Toledanos a mi palacio y maestranza de Sevilla. Yo el Rey Nazar por la gracia de Dios.Jalubi was the architect of my work and chief master. He had come from Toledo with the other Toledan masters to my palace and armoury of Seville. I, King Nazar, by the grace of God.

Two inscriptions possibly taken from Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, pp. 66, 238. Idiosyncratic spellings (e.g. 'e' rather than 'y' where not necessary) match. Would also fit with WG's more cramped hand, which he tends to use in notes datable to 1820s-30s, and fact that text is squashed around existing sketches. Clear elsewhere that WG used Llaguno y Amírola.
Sidi Achmet Elegacel Ambassador from Morocco to Carlos III translated Arabic inscriptions in SpainLlaguno y Amírola, Noticias, p. 238, n. 1.

tei:div.ab: of inhabitants notwithstanding the yellow fever said to be 70,000 Granada 80,000 but the people of Granada say Malaga has only 30,000 inhabitants. The rage against the french here, much less violent than at Madrid. About the 12th of Decr the Madrid post
tei:div.note: On the shields of the vestibule of the Lions court “& the beauty of which you possess emanates from God – the court 126ft long 73 wide with cloister. 22½ high, corridor 7½ wide 128 columns 10 ft high 8 in ½ diamr diameter . dos cenadorestwo alcoves or arbours (garden alcoves) of 15 feet square 25 high
The TazaBasin of the great fount 10½ feet in diam. the lions 2ft½ high & all the font 8o. 6”. the whole 12 agoni.e. 12-sided.

Verses on font “Bendito sea el que dió al Principe Mahomad una habitacion, que con su hermosura sirve de adorno a todas las habitaciones. .
2o Y si no ahi está ese vergel en que hay maravillas, que no ha permitido Dios haya otras que les igualen, ni aun en los dos santuarios.”
3o Y un heap monton de transparentes perlas, cuyo brillo resplandece con los saltos del aljofar, continuamente agitada.”
4o Y no sabemos qual de los dos es el que mengua imperfect. –
5o No ves con qué confusion corre el agua y sin embargo caen de nuevo sobre ella otras corrientes?
6o a manera de un amante que se deshace en lagrimas, y que las reprime por miedo de que haya quien las haga manifiestas.
7 imperfect –
8o Y quizá no es en realidad mas que una blanca nube, que se desprende sobre los leones. From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, pp. 7-8.Blessed be he who gave Prince Mahomad a room, which with its beauty serves as an adornment to all rooms.
2nd And if there is not that orchard in which there are wonders, to which God has not permitted there to be equals, not even in the two sanctuaries.
3rd And a heap of transparent pearls, whose brightness shines with the leaps of the [aljófar = seed pearl, aljofaina = washbasin], continually agitated.
4th And we do not know which of the two is the one that wanes.
5th Do you not see the confusion with which the water runs and yet other currents fall on it again?
6th in the manner of a lover who breaks down in tears, and who fights them back for fear that there may be someone who makes them obvious.
7 imperfect
8th And perhaps it is in reality no more than a white cloud, which is shed over the lions.

figure.label: Andalucian Arabs

tei:div.ab: ceased. The next account was that the French with 40,000 men were there, but no official news had arrived on the 20th. Report says the french had lost at least 10,000 men, had not succeeded in entering Madrid and had encamped at the Pardo where they were surrounded, why then no post. The order for enlisting all persons between 16 & 40 years of age only begun to be put in force in Malaga Dec 18. No kind of communication either to Malaga or Granada when the central junta fled from Aranjuez to BadajosBadajoz. nor indeed had there been any regular communication between the army at the frontier & the junta at any time. The juntaSupreme Central Junta (central authority during the Napoleonic occupation). are said to have examined all the letters in the post office at Madrid to find out Traitors, & the Marquis de los PerralesPerales was in consequence torn in pieces by the mob. Genl General De Juan also by his own soldiers whom he had ordered to retire from Somosierra, on the approach of the french.
tei:div.note: inscriptn on fountain

9o De tal modo se extiende la mano liberal del Califa, que quando franquea sus beneficios, alcanzan a los furiosos leones de la milicia.
10 o tu que miras esos leones, a quienes la falta de vida impide exercer su furia.
11o o heredero de la Sangre de los Naseritas! no hay gloria que se iguale con la de haber heredado ‘èl poder y grandeza que tu hará despreciar à los mas encumbrados magnates.
12o La paz de dios sea contigo perpetuamente, teniendo en sujecion a tus subitos y domando a tus enemigos. From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 8.
9th In such a way is extended the liberal hand of the Caliph, that when he opens up his benefits, they overtake the furious lions of the art of war.
10 oh you who look at these lions, whose lack of life prevents them from exerting their fury.
11th oh heir of the Blood of the Nasrids! There is no glory that equals that of having inherited power and greatness that will make you despise the most exalted magnates.
12th The peace of God be with you perpetually, keeping your subjects [AA: 'subditos'] in subjection and taming your enemies.

a great repair of the alhambra in the 17th century the canals either made or repaired then but the court once paved with blue & white PaseosEcheverría, Paseos por Granada. Green not blue. In 1575 the Alhambra was repaired.

Private mosque, is under Governors house. now a chapel, Moorish columns gilt capitals shields of Moors & Spanish Kings. latticed gallery for Harem. Abul Hagig the Kg who finished the Alhambra died there. Abul Hagig King in 1333. He had a very long beard died Black. defeated at battle of Salado with the Kg of Morocco by Kings of Portugal & Castille. built schools. All villages of 12 houses had a mosque.

Gate of Justice built by Yusef, in 1348. Built the AlcazarFortress of Malaga. now crumbled. very great decoration. Houses had fountains & Towers. The arabian poets called Granada a silver Vase filled with emeralds & hyacinthsi.e. jacinths. Alonzo XI Kg Castilla King of Castile .

tei:div.ab: besieged Gibraltar but died of the plague. Yusef made a lamentn for his enemy. Moors put on mourning. Moors besieged at Gibraltar attended enemy’s funeral in respect. This all the way to Seville. Yusef in 1354 in mosque of Alhambra a maniac from behind ran a dagger into side. The murderer cut in pieces & burnt to satisfy populace. Buried in a Tomb of white marble “Here lies a King & Martyr of an illustrious line gentle learned virtuous, renowned for the graces of his person & his manners, whose clemency piety & benevolence were extolled throughout the kingdom of Granada. He was a great prince, an illustrious Captain a sharp sword of the moslems, a valiant standard bearer among the most potent monarchs &c &c &c. – Tomb no longer exists – This in Marmol.This appears to be a summary of Geoffrey Crayon [Washington Irving], The Alhambra, 2 vols (London, 1832), vol. 2, pp. 296-9 - WG follows Irving's topics and word-choice closely and the quotation exactly, save for punctuation, but Irving does not cite Mármol. It might be possible that WG and Irving are both reading Mármol, but elsewhere WG certainly draws on Irving and the similarities are extremely close here.

tei:div.label: To Granada by Alhama.
tei:div.ab: Malaga to Velez Malaga on horseback 4 Hours. Turn Left into Mountains. Velez to Alhama 7 Hours. Alhama to Granada 7H seeing in way the baths.

Granada to Jaen by the direct road thro a pass. Quit Granada at 5H. leaving the VegaFertile Plain a Village at 9 where stop 45 minutes. At 4 p M4pm a Village in MtsMountains. Next day set out at 5 Jaen at 1.

tei:div.ab: Quit Malaga Jan 1st 1809, no certain news had arrived of the french at Madrid though they had entered the city on Decr 4th. Sail to Gibraltar with Captain Fleming in the Bulwark 74.

Zagri p 237 Guerras CivilesGinés Pérez de Hita, Historia de los bandos de los Zegríes y Abencerrajes (1595–1619), better known as the Guerras civiles de Granada brings news to El Rey ChicoMuhammad XII of Granada, nicknamed Boabdil or 'El Rey Chico' (the Boy King) by the Christians. but he had a “Marlota negra”A black Moorish-style jacket he fell half dead at end of speech
This messenger has green mantle.

figure.label: AY DE MI ALHAMAWoe is me, Alhama - the cry of Abu'l-Hasan Ali ibn Sa'd (d. 1485), Sultan of Granada, known in Spanish as Muley Hacén, at the loss of the town of Alhama in 1482.

figure.label: NOTICE.
figure.ab: WEdnesdayAll apparent errors in this passage are in the original. the 30th January 1811 at the Royal Theatre of S.t Carlos the following entertainment will be exhibitat for the benefit of John Baptista Gianini chief composer of ballets of said Theatre to commence with a grand Symphony, which will be followd by a ballet in three Acts entitled
figure.label: The whimsical party, or the end of importunity.
figure.ab: After which one of the mast pleasant farces hether to laid before the Publich will be performd, the whole to terminate by a grand serwies Dance entitled
figure.label: The Templ of Death.
figure.ab: Inwich Laurence Lacombe is to dance a grand Solo. His composition is the production of said Giannini who will consider himself truly happy should this small specimen meet the same encouragement which he has so repeatedly experienced from an enlightend audience, for the space of fine years, during which he has had the honour of submitting his compositions before a Nation which a mongst other distinguishd qualities, is admired for its indulgence & for encouraging the feeble effort of those who submit them solves to hs criticism.
The Theatre will be brilliantty lit. & the performance will commence at 6’ o clock.
figure.label: NOTICIA
figure.ab: QUarta feira 30 do corrente mez de Janeiro de 1811 a Sociedade do Real Theatro de S. Carlos representará a Beneficio de João Baptista Giannini, legitimo Compositor do dito Theatro, hum agradavel divertimento : abrirá a Scena com huma grande Synfonia, finda esta se exporá huma Dança de meio Caracter dividida em tres Actos, que tem por titulo
figure.label: La conversazione ridicola o sia La fine degl impertinente.
figure.ab: Depois se seguirá huma das melhores Farças que estão em Scena, e terminará todo o Espectaculo com huma grande Dança fabulosa, que se denomina nova
figure.label: Il Tempio della Morte,
figure.ab: Na qual Lourenço Lacomba dançará hum grande Solo A referida Dança he composta pelo mesmo Beneficiado : elle se reputará assaz feliz se esta sua fraca producçao não desvanecer o conceito que este illustrado Público lhe tem patenteado pelo espaço de sinco annos, em que elle tem tido a honra de compôr para huma Nação, que tem por base animar aos que se expõe sobre a Scena.
O Theatro estará todo illuminado, e principiará ás 6 horas e meia.
Na Officina de Simão Thaddeo Ferreira. Com Licença.

This action & translate the leafs the Courier the London narration steril that the leafs we to say this glorious event that done so many the honour for Nation Britich, it appear that no give pleace the to fill the time that owe, to last one action pantomime, reasoa for that the Compositor had that to be worth the speech of the, when no let him be true to serve for to enrich this action & to shew sometime the no humanity the men, e the generosity she men other.

figure.ab: SExta feira 28 de Dezembro de 1810 no Real Theatro de S. Carlos em Beneficio de Rosa Lourenzani, primeira Bailarina do dito Theatro, se ha de representar pela Sociedade do dito a bem acceita Butleta intitulada
figure.label: LA TESTA RISCALDATA.
figure.ab: Finda que seja haverá huma pomposa, e nova Dança da composição de Pedro Maria Petrelli, cuja tem por titulo
A Conquista da Ilha de Bourbon pelas Armas Britanicas.
Será adornada de scenario, vestiario apropriado ao character, e terá tambem hum grande acompanhamento de Tropas.

Esta acção he extrahida do que nos referem as folhas do Correio de Londres. A narração esteril que as ditas folhas nos dão deste glorioso acontecimento, que faz tanta honra á Nação Britanica, parece que não dá lugar a prehencher o tempo que deve durar huma acção Pantomimica; razão porque o Compositor teve que valer-se de episodios, os quaes quando não sejão verdadeiros, serviráõ para realçar esta acção, e demonstrar ao mesmo tempo a inhumanidade de huns, e a generosidade dos outros.
Dará fim ao divertimento o III. e IV. Acto da agradavel Burleta
figure.label: O BARBEIRO DE SEVILHA.
figure.ab: Este he o Espectaculo que a Beneficiada tem a honra de offerecer ao respeitavel Público de quem es[…] protecção.
Principiará ás 7 hor[…]
Na Officina de Simão Thaddeo Ferreira. Com Licença.

tei:div.ab: El ReyThe King Don Jayme went with a silver hammer & mucha genta to knock down the Mosque & destroy all traces of the Moors at Valencia. No ruins therefore left there –
AlcazarFortress of Granada in Alhambra built by Pedro Berruguete for Charles V. Colonnade of Breccia. 1537.
The bridge at Ronda 300 feet Chasm – 600 feet deep.
Zahara citadel with town at foot of rock – in Moorish history near the Guadalete.
Torre ViejaTorrevieja scene of Earthquakes in 1829.
Murcia. pure Moors yet
Purchena seat of Rey ChicoMuhammad XII of Granada, nicknamed Boabdil or 'El Rey Chico' (the Boy King) by the Christians. at foot of Sierra de Filabres eastern shoulder of Sierra Nevada
perarwait
Ruined Castle. Had trees. had 7 000 houses now only 400.
Macael – Antonio Vicarro Maestre de CanterasMaster of Quarries or quarries.
Quarries a league above Village. Pines. 7 blocks ready cut for London White marble of Macael

tei:div.ab: Sala de las dos HermanasHall of the Two Sisters Alhambra. the eastern chamber of the lions court is the Abencerraxes hall on the crest the Sala de las dos Hermanas –
Marble of MachaelMacael. 4 varasUnit of measurement, explained on pag 190. & 21 inches & 2 varas & four inches wide.

Enter by an arched gate the side of which ½ marble ½ stucco. Inscription “aid o God our lord Abulhagiagi. Give glory to our King & lord Abulhagiagi whom God assist. And the beauty which thou hast emanates from God. God is our the help in all affliction, In another place is in entry inscribed “Hapiness.” & again “God alone is the conqueror”. The alcoves called Alhami. The Mirador of the garden of Lindaraxa. Among the azulejos the arms of Mahomad Abu Abdallah. Among the inscriptions “My structure disposed with exquisite art has passed into a proverb, & my praise is current in every ones mouth.WG's translations from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, pp. 10-11.

Another Alli’ tambien los obscuros marmoles ya desbastados y bruñidos despiden su resplandor, y convierten en luz las tinieblasAntigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 11. WG's 'desbastados' is correct, but AA has 'desvastados', suggesting that WG might not be using the 1804 published version.There too the dark marbles, already smoothed and polished, give off their radiance, and turn darkness into light.. Other “Te pareciera que los orbes celestes apresuran su curso para hacer sombra a las columnas de la aurora porque sale mas temprano.Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 11. AA has 'pareceria' and 'colunas', but WG's 'pareciera' and 'columnas' are right interestingly. Another suggestion that WG might be using a different source to the 1804 published version.It seems to you that the celestial orbs hurry along their course to cast in shadow the columns of dawn, because it [i.e. dawn] comes earlier.

Other “Quantas asperas y toscas piedras se han empleado en este Alcázar, resplandecen en fuerza de la luz que reciben del mismo regio palacio.Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 11.How many rough and coarse stones have been used in this Fortress, they shine in the strength of the light they receive from the royal palace itself.

Another “The stars themselves obey & serve this King, In truth those who are employed in the service of his princes merit the greatest honours. another “and if they stood at his side they would haste to serve him while the bystanders would rejoice at it.WG's translations from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 11.

Other. “Oh quanto desean los mismos astros el esplendor si en ella tuvieran fixo su asiento y no tuviesen que recorrer al hemisferio.Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 11.Oh how the stars themselves [would] desire splendour if they had their place fixed in it [reference unclear] and did not have to travel across the [AA has 'el'] hemisphere
tei:div.note: باسمك اللهم من عمرو هند الي الكعبر * كتابي هذا *By the name of Allah, from Amru Hend (name) to Al Kahber (name) [unknown word] my book [unknown word]
tei:div.ab: These inscriptions are in medallions ornamented with shields & other inscripts – in which Dese Gloria perpetuamente al Señor de ella. Sea el reyno perpetus al Señor de el Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 5.AA has 'sea el reyno perpetuamente del Señor de él'.Give Glory perpetually to her [or its] Lord. May the kingdom belong perpetually to his [or its] Lord“The omnipotence of God” other. “Give glory to our lord Abu Abdallah. – In the mirador of Lindaraxa also “give glory to our King & lord AbuabdallahWG's translations from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2. p. 11.. Verses “El que me viere me tendra por una muger que habla con aquel aguamanil, manefiestandole su vivo deseo de conseguirloAntigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 7.He who sees me will take me for a woman who speaks with that water jug [or washbasin], showing [AA has 'manifestándole'] her strong desire to obtain it.. Other verses Quando el que mira considera mi belleza su misma imaginacion desmiente su vista.”Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 6.When he who looks considers my beauty, his own imagination denies his sight. other Solo Dios es vencedorOnly God is victorious God give perpetual help & victory propicious to our lord Abuabdallah, emperor of the faithfulWG's translation from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 12.. Again S D es Venced Solo Dios es Vencedor only God is victorious give honor & praise to the King our lord Abu Abdallah, son of our lord Abulhagiagi, Solo Dios &. WG's translation from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 12.'Solo Dios es vencedor': only God is victorious.– Other “Este es un alcazar de cristal. Ele que lo mira lo tiene por un pielago que rebosa y se derramaAntigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 7. Antigüedades árabes has 'el' rather than 'ele'.This is a fortress of crystal. He who looks at it takes it for a sea that overflows and spills.. – other. God is in himself goodness itself. He is above all merciful & His truth is great.” other – HapinessWG's translation from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 10.. Above is a frieze of fine carv’d wood.

P72 Arab libraryi.e. Miguel Casiri, Bibliotheca arabico-hispana escurialensis..., 2 vols (Madrid: Antonio Perez de Soto, 1760-1770), vol. 1, p. 72.. Tarph & Motalmesus [Arabic] wrote a poem against their protector King Amrun. Motalmesis suspected a letter of recommendation from the King, but Tarphe went. The letter. In nomine tuo Deus. Ab Amru Ebn Handa ad Alcabaram Ubi ad te literae nostrae per Motalmesum pervenerint, fac ipsum manibus & pedibus truncatum vivum defodiasIn your name, God. From Amrun Ebn Handa to Alcabara. When our letters come to you through Motalmesis, mutilate him alive in the hands and feet.

CONTRABANDISTASmuggler
BEGGAR

tei:div.ab: otra tal, que siempre les dexa: con la qual el autor de la hermosura excedió los limites de su perfecton, E ansi quando la dulce aurora de la mañana espira con el resplandor del sol, se demuestran perlas clarisimas que no se pueden significar. E con esto entre mi (id est) entre esta alcazar y la felicidad; hay notoria similitud, é la similitud emana de mi proprio ser.Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 15. G begins copying here mid-sentence, but his possible reference (+) does not lead to the first half of the published sentence anywhere in this notebook.another such, which always leaves them: with which the author of beauty exceeds the limits of his perfection, And so when the sweet dawn [AA has 'aura'] of morning exhales with the radiance of the sun, the clearest pearls appear that cannot be conveyed. And with this between me (that is) between this fortress and happiness; there is obvious similarity, and the similarity emanates from my own being.
In other inscriptions. excerpta

“all is the work of the great Aben Hacere may god preserve his state among Kings.WG's translation from Spanish in Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 16. Antigüedades árabes has 'Naçere' rather than 'Hacere'.

Another “Glory to the most noble of all the ages expugnador de las ciudades nuestro señor Abu Abdallah gozo y contento de los NaseritasAntigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 16 (WG's partial translation of Spanish).Glory to the most noble of all the ages, conqueror of the cities, our Lord Abu Abdallah, joy and contentment of the Nasrids.. Above the Hermanas an aparttapartment. ascended by a stair on Rright In this chamber Solo dios es VencedorOnly God is victorious.. ornamented with leaves & flowers, & “The omnipotence of God”.
An Idea that this was the queens apartment, PaseosEcheverría, Paseos por Granada,

tei:div.ab: Tarifa seems a very poor place having the ruins of an old Moorish Castle behind which is a little bay The country round it is not promising – There is an island of the same name. qui.e. WG asking himself a question. the tower on it.

The Wrath of God on Christians pour’d
They perish by Thy fatal sword
While Victory hails by heavens decree

Pen and ink drawing: view of Gibraltar

tei:div.ab: Roads on the West side of the hill of Gibraltar to a great height. On the top of the rock magnificent views on all sides, & the precipices of the rock itself uncommonly steep and bold. Pretty cottage of the Governor on East side. Near Europa point a flat place entirely covered with stone & uncultivable. Some pretty situations for houses. The Commissioners is a beautiful place & beside a large garden has green fields within an enclosure, & well wooded.
The English took possession of a small rocky island called Parsley isld near Apes hill which they have now quitted.
tei:div.note: MIRADOR OR TOCADORBalcony/oriel or boudoir, ALHAMBRA

In it views of ports very bad but the Arabesques of Bartolomé de Ragés & Alonzo Perez & Juan de la Fuente in 1624 are good, some call the place the PEINADORDressing room. it was repaired & adorned for Philip V & Dona Isabel. In the 16 century there was here an inscrip Arabic. “In the name of God gracious & merciful. God be with our Lord & Prophet Mahomet. & to his people & friends health, & salvation infinitas veces. God is the light of heaven & earth & his light is like himself. It is like luminar which having many says is himself alone & is lampara de lamparas, as if it were a shining constellation, & burned with holy oil neither Western nor Eastern, & which burning shines (alumbra) & without being touched (sin tocarlo) Es luz sobre luz. And God guide with his light Him that seeks it. God gives Proverbs to the nations & God is omniscient in every thing WG's partial translation, apparently from Spanish in Juan de Echeverría, Paseos por Granada y sus contornos..., 2 vols (2nd edn, Granada, 1814), vol. 1, p. 144. WG may equally have been using Echeverría's 1764 original. WG obviously found this passage difficult. Echeverría's text is: 'En el nombre de Dios, que es misericordioso, y tiene misericordia. Sea Dios con Ntro. Sr. y Profeta Mahoma; y á los suyos, y sus amigos salud, y salvacion infinitas veces. Dios es la lumbre del Cielo, y de la tierra, y la lumbre suya es como él; es como luminar, que siendo muchas las lumbres suyas, es uno él: y es lámpara de lámparas, como si fuese constelacion luciente, y que arde con óleo santo, no Occidental, ni Oriental, y que encendiéndolo alumbra y sin tocarlo es Luz sobre luz. Y Dios guia con su lumbre á quien él quiere. Y Dios es dador de los proverbios á las Gentes. Y Dios es sábio en todas las cosas.' A full version, incorporating WG's translations where possible but correcting errors or omissions, would be: In the name of God, gracious and merciful. God be with our Lord and Prophet Muhammad. And to his people and friends health, and salvation infinite times. God is the light of heaven and earth, and his light is like him; it is like a star, which having many lights, is yet one: it is a lamp of lamps, as if it were a shining constellation, and burned with holy oil neither Western nor Eastern, and shone once lit without being touched[.] It is light on light. And God guide with his light him that seeks it. God gives proverbs to the nations and God is wise in all things. – Supposed to have been a MIRABi.e. mihrab, a niche indicating the direction of Mecca. in the time of the Moors, or a kind of ORIEL. The hall of Fruits &cc on old foundations says PaseosEcheverría, Paseos por Granada: The prison of the Sultana a Inner bay, it might be of the mad queenJuana I ('la loca': the mad) of Castile, 1479-1555, wife of Filipe I of Castile., but the grating made aoin the year (anno) 1639 as appears from a paper in the ContaduriaPalacio de la Contaduría (the Accountant's Palace, within the Alhambra complex)..

tei:div.ab: At CartieiaCarteia, a Phoenician and Roman town in the Bay of Gibraltar. the building on the highest point is Moorish. There is one tower of the Greek wall + [indicating drawing above] remaining but not perpendicular, at an angle which was the upper point of the city – The style of this is similar to that of Mantinea & Ithome, without mortar, but the blocks are not large – The Theatre may be on Greek foundations, but the superstructure is evidently Roman. The mouth of the river is now very shallow, & even small boats can scarcely pass the bar at low water. The site is covered with unhewn stones & broken tiles

tei:div.ab: This view is taken from a spot near the Governors summer cottage Eeast of the rock. Lleft are seen some walls said to be moorish. High up toward the peak is seen the powder magazine

tei:div.ab:
From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 95. Casiri gives both Latin and Arabic, but WG probably translated the Arabic (given his pride and the very loose relationship of his translation to the Latin). In the Granada library are poems of Abu Baker Mohamad Ben Abrahim Almari Alcarschi who had This on his Tomb. I translated this so
As God ordains my death foredoom’d must be
Kings, Prophet, Adam all preceeded me
Go Thou prepare who glories in my death
For soon shall Fate require thy latest breath.
Born at Silves 28 miles from S. Maria

From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 106, including Arabic and biographical detail. Valadata Dau’rdaughter of King Mohamad Almostakphi Billah born at Cordoba wrote verses of which translation. “Aspectus noster vestra vulnerat corda: vester & aspectus nostras ferit genas. Pro Vulnere vulnus: jam pares ergo sumus. Attamen genarum vulnus acerbius semper erit.Our countenance wounds your hearts: and your gaze strikes our cheeks. Wound for wound: now, therefore, we are equal. The wound on the cheeks, however, will always be more severe. لحاظنا تجرحكم في الحشا ولحظكم يجرحنا في الخدودOur looks [women’s looks] hurt you [men] deeply and clearly show on you. However, your looks [men’s looks] barely hurt us [women] and only show on our cheeks. Abdusi a noble of Cordoba in love with her.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 107. Some poems end in a letter as [Arabic] whence called Siniat. one of Ebn Badis of Cordova commented by Ahmad Ben Alhagi of Granada. Hegirae 759AH 759 (Anno Hegirae, the Islamic calendar).
Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 118. Mohamad Abi Baker Altalmasani of Granata

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. 161-2. Ebn Alkhatib Mohd. Ebn Abdalla Chronographus to Kg of Granada wrote History of Granada & Bibliotheca Arabico Hispanae. Ebn Alkhatib Mohamad Ebn Abdalla, Chronicler to King of Granada, wrote History of Granada and Arabic-Spanish Library. & of اسطبون قمارش اسطبونه مربيله Estepona Marbella Sahil Velez قمارش Vera Schalubania Salobrena

Al Algeciras is a better place than it appears from Gibraltar, There are two squares or plazas – Behind the town is an aquaduct & some gardens. On the whole however very miserable. A tolerable inn for Spain.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 120. Mohamad Ben Alhassan ben Makhluph Alraschedi. Granatensis wrote Comt on “de arte metrica” of Kathiri ben Abdelrahman ben Alasuad Alkhazai of Corduba. Mohamad Ben Alhassan ben Makhluph Alraschedi of Granada wrote Commentary on "On the Metrical Art" of Kathiri ben Abdelrahman ben Alasuad Alkhazai of Cordoba.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. 125-6. Salaheddin writes in Lacrymae queribundi & impatientis Amantis Thus. Me rapit elegantia et pulchritudinis amor. neque mirum nam ille viros fortes. Rapit et molles. Jam me delicias inter atque lusus perditum cernis. Salaheddin writes in The Tears of the Complaining and Impatient Lover Thus. Love of elegance [Casiri has ‘elegantiæ’] and beauty seizes me; no wonder, for it seizes strong men and the weak [Casiri has no full stop between ‘fortes’ and ‘Rapit’]. Now you see me lost among pleasures and games.
Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 133. “Tot tibi sunt dotes virgo quot sydera coelo”.. Isa ben Mohamad ben Isa in Granada library. You have as many gifts, O Virgin, as there are stars in heaven.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 135. In Hegirae ao. 588 or 1192 Xt. Margaritarum series ac Apparatus Vestis elegantis & laneae & others collected by Mohamad Ben Abdelhac Algasanita Granatensis ao Heg 571. Laudativa amatoria et moralia. In AH 588 or 1192AD. A series of pearls and an elegant woollen outfit and others collected by Mohamad Ben Abdelhac Algasanita of Granada, AH 571. Laudatory, amorous and moral.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 136. Dhilvazratin Abi Abdala Ben Alkatib of Granata wrote history of Spanish events & his travels to Africa & return to Spain & congratulations on it. 3d day Saphari ao Heg 748AH 748.
Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 144 (though mentions 51 professions). Mohamad Ben Md.Mohamad Albalisi ben Ali of Velez wrote dialogues of 50 professions.

Authors of Cordoba numberless. Gardening &c & all the sciences.
CAPITAL. COURT OF LIONS

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Cádiz
figure.label: PORT
LIGHTHOUSE

tei:div.ab: Cadiz said to contain 60 000 inhabitants The houses are high, & well built, but are disfigured by grates of iron at every window. Solano’s house not yet repaired Jany 23d 1809. The whole story of his Treachery said to be fabulous at Cadiz. The streets very narrow but almost all in right lines & generally at right angles to each other. The Theatre fine but being too deep [drawing: plan of theatre] very bad for hearing. The best places seem to be almost all taken by the year, so that a stranger is ill accomodated sic. Saw an excellently acted comedy there El Si de las Niñas The Maidens' Consent, by Leandro Fernández de Moratín (1801; first performed 1806). – The house full every night a thing very rare in Spain. The cathedral a fine building unfinished like all the great buildings of Spain, of white marble heavily ornamented in bad taste corinthian pillars in groupes of 10 &c &c..

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: tile
figure.label: Alhambra Azulejos

tei:div.ab: The sea rages so violently against the walls as to have destroyed a sentry box at the angle of a bastion. The houses very damp the air being filled with the spray even when there is not any wind. The fortification toward the isthmus strong & not wide. The isthmus occupied by a road on each side of which seats of marble & beyond these gardens. The road is perfectly straight for some miles. A new cut is now making about a cannonshot from the city from the sea to the port, by way of defences the whole island being only separated from the terra firma dry land by a narrow channel in some places not deep at low water though dangerously muddy. There is a bridge over it. It is said 25 000 men would be necessary to defend the whole. The two points of St Catalina & Castel Gordo on the main land are within the reach of shells.
tei:div.note:
because You would live in The Because you would English part of the town. Adm FlemingsProbably Charles Elphinstone Fleeming (1774-1840), though only rear-admiral from 1814, when appointed commander-in-chief at Gibraltar. live in the English part note of the Town
500 yards wide 500 yds wide
was only a flat sand till Count o ReillyAlejandro O'Reilly, 1st Count of O'Reilly (1723-94), Spanish soldier and administrator. executd it

figure.label: Torre de los siete suelosTower of the Seven Floors gate here

tei:div.ab: Tangiers is said to have 2,000 inhabitants about 50 christians 500 jews the rest Moors – The streets dirty & full of stones. The shops little square places a cube of 6 feet flat at top as are the houses. The jews industrious & make slippers, sell morocco leather chiefly red & yellow & very fine. The sheep very fine cost from about 2 to 4 dollars. Oxen about 25 dodollars. Provision cheap. About 80 french in the town with a consul only 50 french allowed to reside there More horses seen in Tangiers in two hours than we had seen in all Spain together. A tolerable one costs about 20 dollars – The people generally wear a white mantle of woollen or cotton few have the turkish coloured dresses & those use them for foreign countries.
tei:div.note:
Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias, vol. 1, pp. xxvi-xxviii, translating or paraphrasing in exact order.
Heschamo Ben Adelazri restored the walls of Ubeda in 886. & Lebi Ben Obaidallah built several public works in the Montes de CazlonaMountains of Cazlona. Llaguno y Amírola actually says he restored Ubeda and surrounded it with strong walls. In 1238 Valencia conquered & Mosque destroyed. A Miramolin Son of Mahomad built walls & castle of Talavera de la Reina. Bridge of Toledo Mahomad Elimen called of Alcantara. Kg Alonzo el Sabiothe Wise restored it & Phuto Ben Abraham built 2 mosques. Jucef Abu Jacub built in 1171 the great mezquitamosque at Sevilla. walls on NNord en el patio de los Naranjosnorth in the court of the Orange Trees are his. Aqueduct from Alcalá de Guadaira to Seville. made bridge of Boats over Guadalquivir. His successor Almanzor jacob finished the Alhama & the Tower Giralda, begun in 1000. Then Architect Gever or Hever A Sicilian Abu Alayth placed on it unas manzanassome apples of gilt bronze of great diameter, value 100 mil doblas de oro100,000 gold coins. He built Hasnal Faragh on river now S. Juan de AlfaracheSan Juan de Aznalfarache with towers & walls. Many other things at Seville the Torre de OroGolden Tower on river. el alcazarthe fortess which Don Pedro afterwards rebuilt by Arab architects. Also various houses for his heroes some of which have left no traces. At Zaragosa a mosque burnt in 1050. Palace of Salobreña with hanging gardens. Walls of Jaen, Baza & Guadix restored by Suario Ben Hauduin in 898. Vide page following on backSee WG's page 89; taccuino 6 pag 122.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Tangiers
figure.label: SAND
RUINED MOLE

tei:div.ab: The garden of the Sweedish consul just beyond the walls, very pretty. walks under orange trees with hedges of Geranium & passion flowers. A fence of canes reeds half living and spliced with others – Consuls of Portugal, America, Spain & England here. A mole now ruined might easily be repaired & would defend even large vessels. The sea here clearer even with a strong Eeast wind than at Cadiz. Hedges of Prickly figs. Country covered with brush wood. A FondukHotel/inn in North Africa or Arabia or Khawni the town consisting of a court under the arches of which horses stand, & above a gallery opening into the rooms. The
tei:div.note:
Pen and ink drawing: building Part of the Alhambra
From Barthélemy d'Herbelot, Bibliothèque orientale... (Maastricht, 1776), p. 88. WG may be using another of many editions since 1697.
WG uses same spellings as Herbelot, apart from 'anvuar' for 'anovar', and same observations in same order (translated from French). Ali called Assad Allah Algaleb The Lion of God victorious Haidar also Lion also Faiz al anvuar Distributor of favours or lights.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Alhambra
figure.label: Sillai.e. Silla del Moro hill [Moor's Seat]
Alcasabai.e. Alcazaba: citadel
figure.ab: doors all [drawing: arch]like the Alhambra. A mosque (see view) consisting of a gate into a square court of 3 arches [drawing: arch] covered with green glazed tiles made at Tetuan. The interior consists of 6 parallel roofs supported by arches, altogether very low. At an angle is a square tower on which is hung out a white flag at the hours of prayer. several of the Moors speak a little English. One of the best houses had a small court paved with brick, from which a very clean whitewashed staircase ascended to a little gallery which had a large door into a very clean long narrow room covered with a mat. at each end was a bed. & the whole was very comfortable. The door shut like the doors of the Alhambra & the fashion little changed. Many guns on the batteries at the landing place. The walls towd the land in
figure.note: Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias, vol. 1, pp. xxviii-xxix. Granada. Alhambra cuyas zanjas para los cimientos mandò abrir el Rey Mahomed. or Elgaleb Billah natural de Arjona despues del año 1231.Alhambra, whose foundation ditches King Mahomed ordered to be opened, or Elgaleb Billah [Victor through God], native of Arjona, after the year 1231. Juzeph o Bulhagix at length finished it in 1346. Walls of Albaizin also & the Generalife arches bridges &c. 50 mosques & colleges built by Mahomed ben Abdelrahman 1200. Also a Basilica for judges. a great mosque in Alhambra with baths, at expense of jews & XtiansChristians. La Casa MarmoreaThe Marble House near mosque built by Mahomad Ben Said of Alcala la Real monastery of Supleitas, moros austeros contemplativos y grandes escritores.austere, contemplative Moors and great writers. Termas de Abdelrahman Ben MahomedBaths of Abdelrahman Ben Mahomed & secretary of Kg Ali in 518 of hegiraIslamic calendar. – Colegio maximoSpanish term for religious educational institution by Kg Juzeph in which Aba Adala taught natural sciences history Rhetoric & poesy. College of Moors in Malaga in which studied the great jurisconsult Ebu Haphud Alamin in 1353. Another in Murcia in 1163. At Sevilla with academia biblioteca y monasterioacademy, library and monastery produced several great writers. Mozarabes Xtian architectsMozarabs [Iberian Christians under Muslim rule] Christian architects succeeded. these left off [drawing: arch] but made [drawing: arch] more columns.Pictoral representation of Llaguno y Amírola's text.

tei:div.ab: Ao DomAD 1809 bad repair. Hence nine hours in good weather to Tetuan – Aman of Xeriff who talked Spanish had an astonishing number of children –
El sobriñoThe nephew Abu Abdallah or Abu Abdihelsi was of same name as his Uncle. Therefore the Uncle was called El Zagal or Valiant & the Nephew El Zogoybi or unfortunate

END OF TOUR IN SPAIN 1809

tei:div.ab: A Spanish romance begins thus “En tiempo que el Rey Theseo “Residia en Badajoz Y quando Maricastaña Allà en Castilla reynò. Quando hablavan las bestiasiii. &c &c. In the time when King Theseus resided in Badajoz and when Maricastaña reigned there in Castile. When beasts spoke [hablaban]. &c &c. ['In the times of Maricastaña' being a Spanish phrase for long ago.] Spanish version appears exactly the same, other than punctuation, in Georges-Bernard Depping, Sammlung der besten alten Spanischen Historischen, Ritter- und Maurischen Romanzen (Altenburg and Leipzig, 1817), p. 437: 'Jupiters und Danae's Liebschaft'. This may be a coincidence, but WG certainly read German.
Against the inner arch of this gate the Moor broke his lance on going out with the King. A fatal omen.. At the last siege Muza walled up this & other Gates. The ballad says the Gates were of Brass

ALHAMBRA GRANADA The House of the AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) spoiled by repairs. in it the royal chapel was the royal mosque There is a miradorbalcony/oriel overlooking the carrera de Darrocourse of the Darro. Mahomet 3d called also Abu Abdalla built the mosque the chapel 21 & ½ varas 9 & ½ wide in the mosque a few plaisters or stucco of Solo Dios es vencedorOnly God is the victor remain, The columns are all arabic. The niche for the Coran remains A building alaparte oriental del Real Alcazar called Palacio del principeon the eastern part of the Royal Fortress called prince's Palace destined by Mahomed ben Juseph to Ismael his brother or because the prince of Asturias lodged in it when the Rroyal family came last to Granada. There is a hall 21 varas broad & 20 long. & in it inscrip Solo dios es vencedorOnly God is the victor. cupolas & hanging niches very rich in roof. In the next room an inscrip “Al mismo Dios.”To God himself / To the same God This hall 5 varas square 10 & ½ Varas high. 15 windows in it on Eeast Wwest & North. & “And the beauty thou hast emanates from God.” There is a miradorbalcony/oriel in this edifice which is very highly ornamented & supposed a Mirabmihrab, a niche indicating the direction of Mecca.. At the Eeast of this Palacio del principeprince's Palace a mosque 5 varas long 5 & ½ wide. 7 & ¼ high. “Solo dios”Only God in it now a Cinta (belt) makers houses “God is our help in all affliction.” – “Give Glory to God & consequently give thanks to God himself (or the same). On the Right of the calle RealRoyal street (at the Alhambra) says Padre EcheverriaEcheverría, Paseos por Granada is the Cadisthe house of the qadi, the judge of Islamic law house.

Variously copied or closely paraphrased from review of Francisco de Porras Huidobro, Disertacion historica sobre los Archivos de Espana y su antiguedad, con algunas reglas para su coordinacion (Madrid, 1830), including translations from Ibn Hayan, in Westminster Review, XLII (Oct 1834), pp. 196-7. It is always possible WG was using a copy of the review from a different journal.
'170 years after Hegira': AH 170, by the Islamic calendar 'Ommiades': Umayyads 'Abbassides': Abbasids 'Berebers': Berbers
170 years after Hegira was Abd ar Rahman ben Moaire, ben Hashim Al Adaghel or the intruder, last of the Ommiades – He escaped from the Abbassides & with some Berebers seized Spain. Hashim 1 was his Son – Next Al Hakem 1 Abd ar Rahman 2, Mohammed 1, Al Mondher, Abd Ali, Abd ar Rahman 3. These reigned 279 years Ommiades. Hashim & his Hajib or Minister Al Mansour, rivals of Haroum ar Rashid & his Vizir Khaled ben Barmek.
il’ Allah لا إلهNo God Pertaining to 'Solo dios' in left-hand text [not from Westminster Review]. Part of ا إله إلا الله No God but Allah
Fatima – Lubna – Ayesha. Mariam learned Moorish Ladies Ayesha was beautiful like the rising moon – fine & slender like a young aloe bending its head to the southern breeze. if she ran she looked like an antelope disappointing the sportsman by her rapid flight, & if occupied by study or meditation her eyes resembled the soft & melting eyes of the Gazelle looking from the top of a rock on the burning sands of the desert. Ibn Hayan.

tei:div.ab: Ecija on XenilGenil above confluence with Guadalquivir. Hottest place in Spain. Moorish blood. Azulejos, Cortijos = farm houses. Jose Maria famous Robber who always hand picked horses – captures.

Cosario the Carrier of Antequera. Galeras covered waggons. The majo or fancy national costume. Western side of Granada is Xenil. The Monachil Monachil joins it. Above Monachil nearest road to Sierra Nevada. After quitting gorge Monachil sweeps through a flat in front of Village AzubïaLa Zubia the sort of Frascati of Granadinespeople from Granada. The place beseiged from Azubia, West of which all is a dreary waste – On East near gate of Elvira is the circus & the paradise of CartuxaCartuja, a Carthusian monastery. It gives 2000£ per annum. Above Cartuxa reach Viznar country seat of Archbishop. Viznar several hamlets well seated. The VegaFertile Plain a poor soil except from irrigation. sandy loam running into clay. Macael for white marble. Fine people, upright but not stiff. arms set back & very graceful. Eyes sunk in large sockets. Aquiline nose regularly curved. fine teeth. Greatest part of City Carrera del Darro Zacatin & Puerta de ElviraCarrera del Darro [walk along the Darro], Zacatín and Elvira Gate. Xenil always large. Darro much covered. Theatre near Carrero del torrocarrera del toro (the bull run)

Zacatin [drawing: lines] with Darro a bazaar from the BivarramblaPlaza de Bib-Rambla or Bibarrambla to the Plaza Nueva. Whence to Rright is the Calle de los Gomeles towd Alhambra & to left the Calle de Elvira. The Cathedral on site of mosque & in it many pictures. Tomb of an Archbishop of marble of Macael same as las dos Hermanasla Sala de las Dos Hermanas (the Hall of the Two Sisters) in the Alhambra marble In the quarry are now blocks 12 ft Square At + of Geronymiteschurch of Hieronymites: the Real Monasterio de San Jerónimo (Royal Monastery of St Jerome). is buried the great Gonzaloo de Cordova.

Most of the Flecks in walls are by lightening French spoilt pavement of Macael marble in first court, & blew up Re ChicosMuhammad XII of Granada, nicknamed Boabdil or 'El Rey Chico' (the Boy King) by the Christians. tower.
Above Alhama Sierra de Tejada, ĪLLŎRĂ, ALŌRAÍllora, Álora. Alhendin.
Cadiar Along.

tei:div.ab: Larch? none now in Spain

What is the wood called Alercelarch by old writers? A Moor of Sevilla in 12 century says enough to shew that the Moors knew all sorts of tricks with trees. He does not mention the Alerce. The Mosque at Cordova roofed with it & some yet remains, Gutters of cast lead for Moors knew not rolling. Thuya articulataTetraclinis or Thuja articulata, of the cypress family is the alerce & it grows in Barbary.

tei:div.ab: 1810 VOYAGE TO LISBON
4 Days all but 3 or 4 hours Thermometer below 60
October Tuesday 23. 1810 Plymouth Cremilli.e. Cremyll Ferry, across the Tamar between Plymouth and Mount Edgcumbe passage.

Go on board the Poictiers 74 Cap BeresfordProbably John Beresford (1766-1844), later 1st Baronet, brother of Sir William, the future 1st Viscount Beresford. John was certainly in the navy at the time, and this Captain Beresford is Sir William's brother. about 4. Sail about 6 from CausandCawsand bay Wednesday24 at 12 off Ushant. cold. high sea Wind fair. Thursday 25 Oct latitude 4o6:5’0. Friday 26 of Cape Finisterre having a run of 240 miles in 24 hours Saturday 27th Mondego off Berlengas at 12. See the palace of Mafra. About 2 a pilot came on board in an old boat with 2 other men. The oars made of 2 poles on which a deal board was tied. the sail [drawing: boat]. A decayed walnut shell mended with a wafer box, a most dangerous tattered vehicle. The man began by sayin d-damn my eyes. and assured us the French had sent flags of truce requesting a cessation of hostilities which Ld Wellington would not grant.
Anchor in the bay of CascayesCascais

tei:div.ab: The garden is regularly laid out in walks at Belem. A Pillar is shewn where the palace stood which was burnt. Behind the Palace is a church where the King was fired at, at the time of the great earthquake. The Monastery at Belem very curious the stone remarkably beautiful & the carved work at the great door of the church, the pillars in the inside, the roof

tei:div.ab: the cloisters &c &c are most beautiful. Several of the Kings and Queens of Portugal buried here.

tei:div.ab: On Sunday Nov 4 1810 go to the army about 24 miles from Lisbon, dine with Marshal BeresfordWilliam Beresford (1768-1854), then Sir William, later 1st Viscount Beresford, general in British army and marshal in Portuguese army. meet Ld Wellington & Marques RomanaDon Pedro Caro y Sureda, 3rd Marquis of la Romana (1761-1811), Spanish general.. The English Portuguese & Spanish scattered about in the villages & woods on the western side of a high ridge. The french under MassenaAndré Masséna (1758-1817) about 6 miles east of it. JunctJunction on a high flat by a wood. SobralSobral de Monte Agraço a village below our lines, in the hands of the french. Ld Wn Lord Wellington . at Perro NegroPero Negro. Marshal Beresford at Zapateria. El Marques Romana at Enxheira dos CavalheirosEnxara dos Cavaleiros. WG has originally written 'Enxhara', corrected to 'Enxheira' without crossing out 'a'. Sir Brent Spencer at a pretty Villa called as Fontinhas the fountains, with orange trees & a pretty garden. House at Zapateria by no means bad. Astonishing quiet

figure.note: Pen and ink plan: interior and garden
Pen and ink drawing: landscape

tei:div.ab: prevailed everywhere considering how near the enemy was. The English fort on a high and very cold spot the highest point between the sea & the Tagus in this line. In a carriage it takes about 6 hours to go 24 miles in the direction of SobralSobral de Monte Agraço, & not less on horse back. Town of Loures in the way 2 leagues from Lisbon. On the road many pretty QuintasVillas or estates. See the source of the Tagus toward Santarem. The country as far as the British line extends very uneven and the roads well commanded by forts erected on the occasion

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: landscape with buildings
figure.label: ON THE SOUTH BANK OF THE TAGUS

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Lisbon

tei:div.ab: At Lisbon the Nnorth wind is cold. but the town is entirely sheltered by the hill on that side. With a Westerly wind the air is warm but in the autumn like all places on the Atlantic foggy & damp, and often rainy. Grapes begin to be rather scarce in the middle of November. The houses very high some 6 or 7 stories & the generality 3 or 4. The Opera house of Sant CarlosSão Carlos (St Charles) very magnificent, & the court always procured good actors. The lanes ranged round 3/4ths of an oval. The proscennium has 4 columns but they make part of the oval. The stage is remarkably deep. There is a Spanish Theatre called Salitre with a set of Spanish comedians and dancers.

tei:div.ab: At the Theatre called from the street Rua d’os CondesRua dos Condes are Portuguese plays, and very excellent grotesque dancing. The men appear to leap as high as rope dancers, and twist round in the air very quickly. The streets at Lisbon would be impassable in a climate like that of London, for every species of filth is thrown into them, but they are generally to be crossed without getting wet and in the new part of the town built by Pombal there are side pavements. Here are 2 very handsome squares with excellent houses. The palaces of the Nobility are not half so handsome as those of Madrid. The town being on a slope & sometimes on a very steep hill might easily be cleared of all filth but at present this collects in certain places which do not appear ever to be dry or clean. A few
