Battered by Lieut Frederic BerkeleyProbably Maurice Frederick FitzHardinge Berkeley (1788-1867), future 1st Baron FitzHardinge, then a lieutenant commanding gunboats on the Tagus.
Belongs to Señor Lopez

tei:div.ab: boats ply on the river to take passengers from Belem Buenos ayres &: to the other end of the city. The opposite coast by Almada is very pretty. Buenos ayres a continuation of Lisbon to the west. Here the houses have gardens. The Palacio Quintellai.e. Palácio Quintela, built in the late 18th century. Had been the headquarters of the French governor of Portugal in 1807. is one of the best in the city. It is a large house with a pretty little garden but excepting fine Tapestry in one room, there seems very little difference between the decorations of the interior and those of the common houses of the town. The Arsenal very spacious, 2,000 men employed in it. The look very magnificent & the academy on a most extensive scale as far as the room goes. The booksellers shops not good. There are very few books in the Language except on religious subjects. Several of the most

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: carriage
figure.label: fixed stairs
King of Spains journey from Madrid to Lisbon. Several yet remain –
Bod

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Sintra

tei:div.ab: common Spanish books are translated. Two streets the Rua d’ouro & Rua de Prata(literally, Gold Street and Silver Street) in which gold silver & precious stones are sold. a severe law against selling imitations for real jewels. Over shops Bom Vim for good wine. Gabinete com decencia para bebidas friasRespectable parlour for cold drinks. A play called the death of Captain Cook in the isles of the Hottentots. Other inscriptions in shops. Cha Caffe e SaguTea, Coffee and Tapioca Pudding. Bixas Boas good leeches. Bebidas doces. Bobedas doces & agoas ardentes. Armacem de MusicaSweet drinks. Sweet drinks & spirits. Music store. [Bobedas = 'nonsense', but presumably an error for Bebidas]. Oath “cem pipos de diabos”. “100 pipes of devils”. At a Cake Shop Aqui se vende Pão de luxoLuxury bread sold here. Removed from – Antonio Jose de Coelho filho de Elvas or de CoimbraLiterally, son of Elvas or Coimbra removed from Elvas or Coimbra.
tei:div.note: Inscriptions on a church wall. Viva Maria Viva Jesus. Jesus amoroso. Jesus, meu, espozo.Long live Mary[.] Long live Jesus. Loving Jesus. Jesus, my husband.
Caffe y Xicolate
Street called Rua dos Santos velhos(literally, Old Saints Street)

In a Spanish poem
“Ni que el Doctor don Apolo”
“Alla en Delfos respondiesse.”
Nor that the doctor, Don Apolo,
Answered there in Delphi. These lines appear in Romancero general, en que se contienen todos los Romances que andan impressos, ed. Pedro Flores (Madrid: Juan de la Cuesta, 1614), p. 54. WG seems to draw on this collection elsewhere, but an alternative source is possible. There are many editions of Flores's collection.
Boms vinhos de todas as calidades.Good wines of all qualities.

In enquiring at 20 houses to find a person the man knocked at the doors crying o Sir Josè The answer was regularly quim e? – answer Seu criado – que procura?The answer was regularly 'Who is it?' [quem é?] - answer, 'Your servant' - 'What are you looking for?'
One of the women – a grotesque dancer was called Evangelista & was often cheered when she performed well – brava Evangelista.well done, Evangelista
Rapaz a boy & Rapasida a girl
Bom FimGood End the name of a Ship.
The English sailors called the stick with which the mules are beaten “Arriba” Mule” Arrivo Sticks.
Gallician carts “commissarys fiddles”
Coimbra the English soldiers called Queenborough.

tei:div.ab:
Povoa Póvoa de Santa Iria AlvercaAlverca do Ribatejo & Alhandra where the heights & the English lines come down to the water. from Alhandra to Villa Franca Vila Franca de Xira the bank beautiful the southern shore flat, and sandy islands. At Castanheira Castanheira do Ribatejo another range of heights comes to the water. Passing this see Alemquer Alenquer at a distance. Further on at Villa Nova Vila Nova da Rainha hills on N north bank recede. Very flat on each bank. on the S south see Zamōra. After Villa Nova Vila Nova da Rainha see Azambuja
L left at foot of hills. An island ends on R or S right or south . See Benaventa Benavente on S bank at a great distance next convent of Jerico & then Salvaterra Salvaterra de Magos a great hunting palace with a town & opera house & woods & plain for coursing. very ugly.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: buildings
figure.label: Inn on the road to CintraSintra
Inn in the way to Cintra

tei:div.ab: soon after reach Valada an ugly flat meadow like Lincolnshire. The houses protected from the Tagus by a high bank. Ld Wellingtons headquarters then at Cartaxo about 5 miles distant. At Valada the meadows were very like England & equally green. Mallows, Sow thistle & other herbs. Plenty of Pumpkins. A sailor carried 6 on a stick. The French were at Santarem separated from us by a bridge only, on which both had sentries. The sailors at Valada who were transporting troops across got 5000 across through the river is very broad in an hour. A

Decr 4 a lovely hot day go toBemficaBenfica in a carriage in one hour Gardens to the country seats at BemficaBenfica very fine oranges &c Thence by Queluz a royal palace in a low situation to CintraSintra passing over a very ugly country without trees.

label.note: ابو القاسم Abu [father of] al-Qasim (عبد حمن) Servant (عبد) of Haman (حمن).

It seems the last word is missing a letter, as the meaning is currently unclear. It should be (عبد الرحمن), which means the servant (عبد) the most merciful (الرحمن). The extra space between (عبد) and (حمن) also indicates that some letters are missing. Perhaps referring to Abu al-Qasim Muhammad ibn Abbad (ruled 1023-1042), qadi of Seville.

tei:div.ab: Decr 4th 1810 a very fine warm day visit CintraSintra. In one hour reach BemficaBenfica, a village in a dip with some houses gardens & a church. See that of the Marquez de Abrantes. It is now much neglected all the gardens of Portugal are in the same style & very pretty with oranges of all sorts &c&c&c & fountains. An artificial rock & cascade. The small orange or myrtle here. In another hour reach QuáluzQueluz on 'R' smudged outLeft. a large German looking palace in a hole with a village round it & ploughed open fields. In 3 hours more through a very ugly country like the worst parts of Derbyshire with stone walls, & very bad ruined paved road reach Cintra. The first sight of it is beautiful. Descend into the village. The houses, trees, waterfalls from the hill &c&c the most picturesque possible. The palace on a very pretty hill insulated. The number of roofs make its appearance very singular. Two spires are kitchen chimneys. The whole is

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Sintra
figure.label: CINTRASintra

tei:div.ab: an imitation of Moorish work & at a distance looks like parts of the Alhambra but nearer wants the ornaments. A very good inn or two in the village it being the resort of travellers in the summer, & 11 degrees cooler than Lisbon with water perpetually running. The height above the sea is great & it is exposed to the N north wind. At the Marques de Marialvas house here the convention of Cintra was signed. The tops of the hill are often bare but some are covered with pines. The royal family have another palace about ½ mile nearer Lisbon. In the Moorish palace the apartments have azulejos like the Alhambra but ill done. The great hall of the swans has a very richly gilt & painted roof with swans in compartments but the walls are half way down whitewash. Another room has drawing: magpie por bim i.e. 'por bem': for the best (literally, for good). The ceilings with magpies at the Palacio Nacional de Sintra do actually read 'por bem'.. Some of the tiles are

figure.note: Pencil, pen and ink drawing: view of Sintra
figure.label: Mrs Daseys
FROM THE PALACE AT Sintra

tei:div.ab: in raised work of Leaves &c.. The place abounds in all sorts of fountains & tricks cisterns &c &c. The cieling of the great square tower has the arms of many of the Portuguese families, that of the conspirator Tavira i.e. Távora family, publicly executed in 1759 for involvement in assassination attempt on King José I the previous year. painted out. The room inside is 14 yards square. The ceilings roofs are all fine or pretty the walls all whitewashed or meanly painted like scenes. view over the sea CollaresColares Mafra &c&c but the distant country is ugly.

tei:div.ab: Wednesday Novr 4 symbols The french before the lines of the allied army at Sobral not more than 35 000 fighting men, desertions daily reducing them besides sickness, in total want of provisions. on the point of despair. The Genl General supposed to be ready to lay down his arms, & very compleatly conquered. Communications entirely cut off
The desertions from the french innumerable, the army ruined by it iii

Nov 5 imposible for the french to retreat, 20,000 + Militia in their rear. Abrantes occupied by the allies the bridget under the walls of the town which is very well fortified, symbols Able to withstand the enemy if he does not come with more than 100000 men. No possibility of that. Lisbon safe for the winter
The French have no artillery nor amūnition
The Portuguese regulars 50,000 men with cavalry symbols The french pursued us before Busaco so as to leave behind all their guns xx

13 Novr The Frenchh retire to Santarem will lose all their rear in the retreat, will be surrounded by our forces 38 000 English & 20,000 Portuguese. Santarem an unfortified town. The french in great trepidation dying of disease & famine. Nok feark whatever of the enemy on the south side of the Tagus. No bread.q
Novr 17. Impossible for the french to retreat the rains having swelled the river Zizare. No materials either for bridges or boats.

Want of every thing, wish to retreat if possible. Try to get off their cannon by degrees that they may retreat quicker No possibility of receiving succoursx. The Zizare swelled by rains totally prevents communication or z retreat. The french in distress for want of Salt o Portuguese said Wine.
The returns of french passing through Bayonne this war 500000 men of which compared with the returns Decr 1810 280000 are dead or prisoner.
tei:div.note: The french (_______) have 65,000 men without reinforcements.
The french have provisions in such plenty that they left stacks & fields untouched on their retreat. WG i.e. something Gell himself observed?
+ French retreat to Santarem Novr 13 without loss or attack
iii In the year 1810 the french lost by desertion 1500 men the English alone 480 –
No bridge at all at Abrantes. There was once one of Boats at some distance from the town, which may be taken any time by a coup de main.
tei:div.ab: Jan 1811 They have many more guns than the due proportion and a sufficient supply of ammunition

The Portuguese m have no more than 20,000 men symbols The h General not being at home the french retreat without losing more than 500 men at most. They have time to fortify the causey at Santarem and bid us defiance.
xx The french have more and larger guns than we. xx
Santarem the most impregnable position in Portugal. xx The french have more guns than requisite for their numbers.
The french ask the English officers to an opera at Santarem. kThe enemy under Soult arrive at Badajos jan 8. Rations of bread regularly served. symbols

In the course of a fortnight 3 bridges over the zizare a dock yard at Punhete on the Zizare. No difficulty whatever in passing the river and communications so well established that a corps of 7,000 men join the french about Jan 4. 1811. after very hard rain.x 21000 men coming in three divisions. z The affair of the Zizare compleatly given up and communications acknowledged, at the end of December. oSolt within 3 leagues.
Jan 1811 It is supposed the french will drive us back to Sobral

tei:div.label: Song Modinha Modinha: a kind of sentimental love song popuar in 18th- and 19th-century Portugal. 'Modinha', the diminutive of 'fashion', apparently refers to fashionable aristocratic salons.

lg.l: Que mais quer o meu coracão.
Sei que amo e sou amado
Que mais quer o meu coracão
Se a minha alma d’outra alma
Se a vida toda he praze
Que mais quer o meu coracão.
Loving in order to be loved
What more does my heart want?
What does it want? Oh, what does it want?
I know I love and am loved
What more does my heart want?
If my soul enjoys fine adoration
What more does my heart want?

tei:div.ab: The french RomanaDon Pedro Caro y Sureda, 3rd Marquis of la Romana (1761-1811), Spanish general. dies & we go to bury him at Belem.
Jany 21. 1811 Junot Jean-Andoche Junot (1771-1813), French general. wounded in the face in a skirmish in which the whole of our advanced poste were driven in.
Junot Killed by the English + – Account of Jan 25 1811
tei:div.note: + Junot very little hurt Jan 26
tei:div.ab:
I went with Capt Beresford Probably John Beresford (1766-1844), later 1st Baronet. with whom I came to Lisbon in the Poictiers to Zapateiro to see his Brother Sir Wm. Beresford William Beresford (1768-1854), then Sir William, later 1st Viscount Beresford, general in British army and marshal in Portuguese army. in the lines. We went in a Calesh. Bad road. Zapateiro a country house by a road side. The Troops very seldom seen. Next morning the General lent us horses. Mine was a strong black called John Bull. We rode to a wickerwork fort & found Ld. Wellington. He seeing me without uniform took me entirely under his protection & walked me away from the company. Shewed me Junots Camp in the distance. Asked me what They said in England of the army. I said we were told we should meet it coming back half way over the bay of Biscay. He quickly said “Then why did you come. I said because it was said you meant to fight & I was sure if you did you would conquer. He was quite pleased at this. It was at the time Cobbet was trying to write him down The radical William Cobbett (1763-1835) was regularly scathing about Wellington in his Weekly Political Register. The retrospective tone suggests that this passage was written some time afterwards, as do the altered hand and the space left to remember the horses's name.. He said that he could stand the french if they came with no more than 100000 men & that they could not provision more possibly. That it was said Buonaparte was coming. He would rather have 10000 men more against him as Bonaparte could sacrifice the 10000 without a word being said against him. He wished the french would attack him but he could not attack them without being certain of Victory & little loss, because not only he but the whole government at home would be destroyed by the least false step whereas Buonaparte feared no opposition & was unacountable to any one. Fearful odds for Ld Wellington to contend against. He desired me to go to a certain bridge in the valley below – When there said he look about you & see how many guns are pointed at you. Tis only over that the enemy can come & I wish he would try it. I went & found it as he said. He came & dined at Genl General
Beresfords & so did Romana & they were both very agreeable. We lived like people in the country & rode out to each others houses to dinner. I rode Count Lemos horse back to Lisbon & Mr Lemos took our Calesh.

figure.label: garden of Austrian minister.

tei:div.ab: The ladies played at a game called the Saints. The company took different names as St Antoão St Ursula &c. Each had a veil one of the ladies went round and lifting up the veil asked who would buy such a saint describing him or her & her qualities in a ludicrous way. whoever laughed paid forfeit and stood up to sell the saints.

The impudent attempt frequently printed to make Latin & Portuguese the same Noted by many travellers, including Robert Southey, Letters Written during a Journey in Spain, and a Short Residence in Portugal, 3rd edn, 2 vols (London, 1808), vol. 2, p. 62. WG's hand and the passage's positioning suggests that this was a later addition rather than an observation during his own travels. WG has two more lines than Southey (lines that appear in other versions), though, and WG uses different punctuation, so Southey was not his source.

lg.l: Canto tuas palmas famosos canto triumphos
Subjectas sacra nympha feros animosa tirannos
Tu phoenix vivendo ardes ardendo triumphos
Das rosa bella rosas fortes das sancta columnas
Æternas vivas annos o regia planta
Devoto cantando hymnos, vos invoco sanctas
Tam puras nymphas amo adoro canto celebro
Per vos felices annos o candida turba.
Per vos innumeros de Christo spero favores.

tei:div.ab: In Cathedral of Granada are carvings.
Abdallah delivering Keys of City to Ferdinand.
Moors with hands tied going into exile
Moors male & female baptized. Costumes perfect.
In Cathedral Tomb of Ferdinand & Isabella of marble
Valeroso Hijodalgo
tei:div.p: Muy bien se muestra en tu virtud la nobleza de tu sangre. Leida la carta hize tocar trompetas y añafiles en regozijo de tu convite y se convino entre todas las donzellas de mi linage, que gozosas iremos con tigo al sarao dispuesto por el noble Caballero que da las Fiestas y Zambras
Ala te embio bonanza y queda con el.
tei:div.ab: No mas De la Alhambra Daraxa Pariente del Rey Chico de Granada
tei:div.note: Brave Gentleman hidalgo The nobility of your blood shows very well in your virtue. Having read the letter, I made the trumpets and añafiles long, straight Moorish trumpets sound in rejoicing at your invitation and it was agreed among all the maidens donzelas of my lineage linaje, that we will joyfully go with you to the sarao musical soirée arranged by the noble Knight who gives the Feasts and Zambras dances associated with Spanish gypsies and supposedly of Moorish origin. Allah send you te envíe prosperity and be with him. No more From the Alhambra Daraxa Kinswoman of the Rey Chico the Boy King, Muhammad XII of Granada

This letter may be of WG's composition: the first line ('Muy bien ... tu sangre') opens a different letter in Ginés Pérez de Hita, Historia de los Vandos de los Cegries y Abencerrages... (Barcelona, 1757), p. 44 (and presumably in many other editions), while Daraxa herself and many of the things mentioned here (trumpets, añafiles, zambra, sarao etc) appear elsewhere in the book. The Mirador de Daraxa is a part of the Alhambra complex.

tei:div.note: p166, 3 Vol
tei:div.ab: En el tiempo de estas paces a 20 de Muharram del año setecientos 777 mandó el Rey Muhamad edificar la casa de Azake para recogimiento de pobres y alivio de sus enfermidades: acabó a 20 de Xewal año 798, edificio magnifico con todas las comodidades que sabe proporcionar la sabia arquitectura y la riqueza de un generoso principe con fuentes y espacios estanques de pulidos marmoles para recreo de los melancolicos. Tambien hermoseó con edificios la ciudad de Guadix a donde pasaba una buena temporada cado año. Durante la larga paz que tenia con todos los principes vecinos, fomentò las artes y manufacturas el comercio y la agricultura, y venian a Granada traficantes de todas la partes de Syria Egipto Africa Italia y Almeria: era la escala celebre de España pretty stopping in Spain Andaban en Granada gentes de diversas naciones asi Muslimes como Xtianos y Judios, y parecia la patria comun de todas las naciones. Poco despues vino a traer la esposa el Principe de Fez, y se casó en Granada con la hermosa Zahira hija de Abu Abdala Juzef que fue muy celebrada Passage copied from José Antonio Conde, Historia de la dominacion de los arabes en España, sacada de varios manuscritos y memorias arabigas, 3 vols (Madrid, 1820-1), vol. 3, pp. 165-6, with some additions and abridgements and error in final line. King Muhamad of Granada 1375 At the time of this peace on 20 Muharram in the year 777, King Muhamad ordered the building of the house of Azake to gather the poor and alleviate their illnesses: he finished on 20 Shawwal in the year 798, a magnificent building with all the comforts that the wise architect knew how to provide and the riches of a generous prince, with fountains and spacious pools of polished marble for the relaxation of the melancholic. He also beautified the city of Guadix with buildings, where he spent a good season every year. During the long peace that he had with all the neighbouring princes, he promoted the arts and manufacturing, trade and agriculture, and trades from all parts of Syria, Egypt, Africa, Italy and Almeria came to Granada: it was the famous stop-over in Spain Pretty stopping in Spain i.e. WG's translation of above People from diverse nations, Muslims as well as Christians and Jews, walked in Granada, and it seemed the common homeland of all nations. Shortly afterwards, the Prince of Fez came to bring his wife, and in Granada he married the beautiful Zahira, daughter of Abu Abdala Juzef, who was very famous. WG's copying error: confusing Abu Abdala Juzef, mentioned in earlier omitted passage, with Abu Ayan

At Seville the AlcazarFortress yet a Royal palace. Some is Moorish some of Carlos V. the Lonja or exchange part of it – Palace of Dukes of Alcala fine moorish. Medina Celi all the same. Triana the Suburb S South , of river. Walls almost entire. Many hermandades & confradiasfraternities and guilds – Tricles with the river. Cortijos Farmhouses scattered, Cazalla de la Sierra , Constantina Aracena places for Summer retreat in Sierra Morena.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: shield
figure.label: Aben – Alhamar
Sometimes red blue & green shields

tei:div.ab: Copied, translated or paraphrased from Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 3, pp. 38-9. Aben Alhamar King of Granada. Tomò por armas escudo campo de plata banda diagonal azul, y en ella escrito in letras de oro "le galib ile Ala" "no es vencedor sino Dios." porque sus pueblos le solian saludar con el titulo de Galib y el replicaba "Wa le galib ile Ala." y no hay mas vencedor que Ala." las estremos de la banda del escudo en bocas de dragones. His descendant bore same arms only varying the colors, to red blue & green shields & changed color of band also. He began the Alhambra, directed the work y andaba entre los alarifes y arquitectos muchas veces. The Court: Abu Meruan Abdelmelic Juzef ben Senanid ilustre natural de Jaen primer Wazir. 2d. Wazir. Aly ben Ibrahim Asaibani Azadi. de Granada, muy noble y rico. Capitan della Guardia Muhamad hijo del Wazir Aly – he was also Alcayde. Wali o principal Caudillo de sus tropas Abu Abdala Muhamad Arramim. Almirante o caudillo del mar el padre de este. Aben Muza Alcayde de su caballeria Secretario de su Mezuar o consejo Yahye ben Alcatib de Granada. Alcatibes o secretarios para ordenes y cartas. Abul Hasan Aly Arrayni 1 2 Abu Becar ben Chatab. 3 Abu Omar Juzef ben Said Alyahsi di Loxa. 7 Alcadies o jueces de corte. Abu Amer Yahye Alaschari. 2 Abu Abdala Muhamad Alansari celebre jurisconsulto who wrote many works. 3 Cadi de lo criminal, Abu Abdala el Tamini de los Asalamies de Loxa. 4 Aben Ayadh ben Muza el Yahsabi. 5 Aben Adha. 6 Abul Casem Abdala ben Abi Amer. 7 Aben Fat baron de Sevilla – Aben Alhamar King of Granada. He took for his arms a shield with a silver field and blue diagonal band, on which was written in gold letters "le galib ile Ala" "there is no victor but God." because his peoples or towns used to greet him with the title of Galib and he would reply "Wa le galib ile Ala" and there is no other victor but Allah. The ends of the band on the shield in dragons' mouths. His descendant bore same arms only varying the colors, to red , blue & green shields & changed color of band also. He began the Alhambra, directed the work and walked among the builders and architects many times. The Court: Abu Meruan Abdelmelic Juzef ben Senanid illustrious native of Jaen, first Wazir minister. 2nd Wazir. Aly ben Ibrahim Asaibani Azadi of Granada, very noble and rich. Captain of the Conde has 'de su': of his Guard Muhamad son of Aly the Wazir - he was also Governor. Wali or main Commander of his troops Abu Abdala Muhamad Arramim. Admiral or sea commander, the father of the latter. Aben Muza, Leader or Governor of his cavalry. Secretary of his Mezuar or council, Yahye ben Alcatib of Granada. Alcatibes or secretaries for decrees and letters. Abul Hasan Aly Arrayni 1, 2 Abu Becar ben Chatab, 3 Abu Omar Juzef ben Said Alyahsi of Conde has 'de' Loja. 7 qadis or court judges. Abu Amer Yahye Alaschari. 2 Abu Abdala Muhamad Alansari, famous jurisconsult who wrote many works. 3 judge qadi of criminal law, Abu Abdala el Tamini of the Asalamies of Loja. 4 Aben Ayadh ben Muza el Yahsabi. 5 Aben Adha. 6 Abul Casem Abdala ben Abi Amer. 7 Aben Fat baron of Sevilla erroneous translation of Conde's text: 'Aben Fat el conocido por Alasbaron de Sevilla': Aben Fat, known as Alasbaron of Seville
