figure.label: El Mirabi.e. mihrab, a niche indicating the direction of Mecca.

tei:div.ab: Abulcacim Tarif says

In year 91 of Hegira Don Rodrigo .A.D712. Jacob Almançor or Miramamolin Abilgualit Jacob Almancor at same time Anagilda = Kg Acosta Retired to Cordova To Tanjer & thence to Africa & died with her son D. Don Sancho

K Rodrigo sent to Ataulpho to imprison Sancho in the Torre de la piedraStone Tower in the Sierra Morena near Cordova. Anagilda delivers him & puts off Ataulphos nose & ears. Rodrigo destroyd all the Castles of the nobility in Andalusia &Castille.

= Zahra Abnalyaca d daughter of a Moorish African King who was during a trip to sea driven by the wind to Cabo di Gata & made prisoner. Became a XtianChristian & Her father died of it. She was taken by Tarif & well treated. Mahomet Gilhair had the care of her & made love to her he turned Xtian for her & was by the Moors beheaded.
Don Julian Ld of Algeciras was sent to the Viceroy Muça el Zahani
Almancors title Rey de las ArabiasKing of the Arabias.

Don Julians daughter ravished by Dn Rodrigo at Toledo. Florinda her name in Arabic La Caba a bad name. Don Julian the ambassador at Mucas court returns to Toledo takes away his Daughter & with all his moveable & tenants flies to Musas court who recd him well & sends him to Arabia to the Miramamolin Almancor who agrees to attack Spain & Julian goes with Tarif Abenziet of Damascus with 6000 infantry & a few cavalry. Lands at Jabalfeth Sierra della conquista Luna, Historia Verdadera, p. 21 has 'Jabalfath', saying that it has been corrupted into Gibraltar, meaning 'Sierra de la conquista' (Mountains of the conquest)
Summary of [Miguel de Luna], Historia Verdadera del Rey Don Rodrigo ... Compuesta por el Sabio Alcayde Abulcacim Tarif, de Nacion Arabe, 7th edn (Madrid, 1676), pp. 3-21 (or another of several editions since 1592).[True History of King Don Rodrigo... Composed by the Wise Governor Abulcacim Tarif, of the Arab Nation]. As WG notes on pag 168 (his page 37), the work had long been proved a forgery by the morisco author Miguel de Luna.
In 1390 the Cortes fixed for Henry II fixed 4000 men in garrison & 1,500 horsemen

In 1406 Henry 2d of Castille wishing to attack the King of Granada wanted 4 000 horse 10 000 lances & 50 000 infantry, with a fleet of 30 galleys &50 ships. 6 great cannons. 12 iron rams. 6000 waggons.

Don Rodrigo enters the enchanted Tower one mile east of Toledo in a rocky place a fine old edifice, but degraded by time. under this was a cave, de bobeda Luna has 'una cueba con una boca de bobeda': a cave with a vaulted mouth [bóveda].. very narrow with a door cut in rock & a strong iron gate over this in Greek letters The king who opens this cave & discovers its marvels shall see good & bad things”. King Rodrigo entered with some friends who fled but the Kg got many lights. In a quadra muy hermosa very beautiful hall [quadra = cuadra] like a sumptuous edifice he saw a statue of bronze of great size on a pillar 3 cubits high. This figure with a great club beat the ground & caused a horrid sound. The King told this vision he did not come to destroy anything but only to see its marvels on which the statue ceased the blows. The King & his companions then examined the quadra hall & found at the left of the statue written. Oh unhappy King to your own loss have you entered here”. on the Right “By foreign nations shalt thou be dispossessed & thy country chastised.” On the shoulder of the statue “I envoke the Arabs” on the breast. “I do my office” – At the entry of the hall was a bola redonda round ball whence a noise like a water fall. On the Kgs departure the statue recommenced the noise & the King orderd a heap of earth to be thrown up against the door. Closer abridged translation/paraphrasing of [Luna], Historia Verdadera, pp. 23-5.
Ataulpho went against Tarif with 30 000 men & 500 horse
Ataulpho conquered. Then Rodrigo sent an Archbishop Don Orpas with 30 000 men & 3000 horses.
Tarif by degrees got 60 000 men & 10000 cavalry.
Orpas was beat. Rodrigo then came with 23 000 cavalry & 13000 infantry. Ramiro the ensign fell dead.
Rodrigo in 8 battles lost all & fled & Tarif took Cordova.
Some moors found a Shepherd in D Rodrigos clothes & took him he had changed with the King.
Tarif passed thence to Granada without opposition

They found a small city on a height very pleasant & delightful vale below it thro which ran a very pretty river. The surrounding mountains full of trees & frescuras Luna has 'arboledas y frescuras': groves and freshness.. a Paradise on earth. The city soon given up to him. on conditions of peaceable nature. Betiz Abenhabuz of Arabia felix made governor. Tarif then went against the Mts de Sol y Ayre Luna has 'las montañas de Sol, y Ayre': the mountains of Sun and Air, which he places near Granada. where he had great dificulties. Captain Abrahem Abuxarra at length subdued them & their Bishop Otogerio. Then Carmona & Merida.
tei:div.note: Summary (and partial translation on Granada) of [Luna], Historia Verdadera, pp. 31-55.

tei:div.ab: At MALAGA an arabian palace the Alcacaba Alcazaba (Citadel) now the new custom house. In castle a sort of chimney over every window & door running up to battlements to throw stones down. Gibralfaro.
Santa Fé 2 leagues from Granada
Earthquake in 1809. Church cut in 2.
Muley Hasen Mulhacén peak 12 762 feet from sea. Picacho de Veleta Peak of Veleta 12 459.
general run 1824 & 1781 fathoms
Mt Perdu Mont Perdu / Monte Perdido top of Spanish Pyrenees 1763 fathoms. Muleyhasen Mulhacén 1824. 76 fathoms lower than Teneriffe.
Sierra de Gador near Almeria 7.800 feet.

Rock of Filabres 2 000 feet high. 4 miles round. Almeria taken 1147 by Alfonso & a fleet of Genoese. Garnets i.e. gemstones near Capo di Gata Cabo de Gata. Near T de las Guardas is jasper near T. de White carnelian Neste Torre de las Guardas Tower of the Guards and Torre de Neste Tower of Neste.
Precious stones in cavern of Bujo.
In puerto de la plata Puerto de la Plata Moorish corsairs. near it in rock el monte de las guardas Guards' Mount amethysts. Alpuxarras Alpujarras lie between Sierras Nevada & de Gador.

At Concud human bones &c. Soto di RomaSoto de Roma, a royal estate outside Granada granted to the retired minister Ricardo Wall (1694-1777). Mr Wall. 4000 acres of forest. Pheasants. died in 1778. wento i.e. went to Godoy Manuel Godoy, Spanish minister, inherited Soto de Roma after Ricardo Wall's death. road from Sa Fe to a venta on rio Saladillo Santa Fe to a country inn on the river Saltillo from salt springs of Almaha. Loxa Loja & its moorish castle in pass 9000 souls. Chiuma Possibly Churriana, at the mouth of the Guadalhorce. has 8000 souls. river Guadalhorce.
A french Knight & Moorish princess fled from Granada to pena de los enamorados Lovers' Rock [pena = peña], by tradition.
Antiquera Antequera Anticaria 8000 families 40000 souls, taken 80 years before Granada by Juan II. In Moorish castle which is very perfect is armour. short javelins. Xbows crossbows oval shields
tei:div.label: Antequera
tei:div.ab: made of two hides musket proof. The entry called the giants arch. Mosque perfect. fountains. Fuente de la PiedraStone Fountain.
FONTI DIVINO ARAM L. POSTUMIUS STATULIUS EX VOTO .D.D.D. Lucius Postumius Statulius gifted and dedicated (dono dedit et dedicavit) the altar of this divine fountain as a votive offering.
Alora 4 leagues from Antequera 4 000 souls.

figure.note: Drawing: arch

tei:div.ab: arabs of Syria of the Ommiades Umayyads.
house of Abbas used drawing: arch ???
Ronda 20000 souls. encircled by Guadiaro connected with country by an drawing: arch bridge 120 feet high 2d drawing:arch bridge 280 feet arch 110 feet diamdiameter?
Alameda The Alameda del Tajo, Ronda has a precipice of 500 feet

all the rivers of Ronda fall into the cueva del GatoCat's cave. a mile through which is a lake with ruins of antiquity. beyond this deep lake passage of water too small to penetrate 4 miles from cave the river again comes out & runs by AlgaucinProbably Gaucín. The comment on civility is not in Conder and may be WG's own recollection.. Civil people.
Algaucin 10 000 souls.
tei:div.note: This whole section summarises and paraphrases Josiah Conder, The Modern Traveller. A Description, Geographical, Historical, and Topographical, of the Various Countries of the Globe, 30 vols (London, 1830), vol. 18: Spain and Portugal, pp. 11, 273-87, 293-5, 300. WG's observations and facts are always in the same order as Conder's. Conder's book, a compendium of existing accounts, draws on Jacob (above all), Swinburne, Dillon, Cavanah Murphy, Peyron, Laborde and Bourgoing in these passages.
tei:div.ab: Drum of Almansor.
tei:div.note: Arabic Al-Mansur [Almanzor] lost a drum at Calatañazor [the supposed battle of 1002, since proven a fiction]
tei:div.ab: Almansar Khasara Tabluhu fi Calcanassar
Drums invented by Arabs

This is called so by Spaniards In reference to 'Calcanassar' (Calatañazor) but it was Kalat Anesor vide Conde Chap CII p 543 Vol I.See Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, p. 543: chapter 102, 'De la batalla de Calat Anosor y muerte de Almanzor' (On the battle of Calat Anosor and the death of Almanzor)

100 000 Moors condemned by inquisition 4 000 burnt. Philip III in 1609 banished 140 000 from Valencia & after 3 years 600 000 from Murcia Seville & Granada. 400 000 families says count CampomanesPedro Rodríguez, Count of Campomanes (1723-1802). or at least one million. Before this 800 000 Jews in time of Ferdinand & Isabella. Fonseca writes “justa expulcion de los Moriscos. 257 page Spain Vid see.Damián Fonseca, Del gusto scacciamento de Moreschi da Spanga, Italian edition (Rome, 1611); Justa expulsion Misspelling of 'expulcion' is Conder's. Page reference is to him: Conder, Spain and Portugal, vol. 18, p. 257. de los Moriscos de España The just expulsion of the Moriscos from Spain, Spanish edition (Rome, 1612). The tricks of sacrificing one child to Baptism & lending it to other families for the same purpose. Vide p258 Apen HumeyasAben Humeya, or Muhammad ibn Umayyah (1520-69), led the Morisco Revolt of 1568-71 in the Alpujarras. letter apostolic. See Conder, Spain and Portugal, vol. 18, p. 258, footnote. In 1726 the inquisition seized 360 families of Mahometans, their goods 12 000 000 crowns. in 1787 the Quemadero or burning place of Granada neglected. but 8 years before 2 Jews & a Turk burned. Silk in 1726. 2. 600 000 lbs. in 1776 only 100 000 Sugar motrilMotril, a town on the south coast known for its sugar. to Marbella. canes 9 ft high A village up the darro or Douro Moorish round plump faces bright eyes small nose & underjaws good people. In Granada out of 652990 souls 1979 nobles or hidalgosgentlemen.

Alhama – Alhama or La Mala La Malahá the royal salt springs in way. 2000 souls. runs to el saladillo Probably El Saltillo, between Vélez-Málaga and Alhama de Granada. Conder also calls it ‘El Saladillo’, ascribing the name of the spring to the saline taste of its water.. Thence 4 hours to Alhama, city only accessible from west where a castle. 1 500 families. Moors had a revenue of 500 000 ducats from letting XtiansChristians bathe. Alhama to Lamala La Malahá 20 miles. only one small village on road. 8 Leagues to La Venuela. an hour beyond La Venuela La Viñuela Velez Malaga 7000 souls. Drawing: drum
Malaga 75 000 souls. Velez beautiful
tei:div.note: Summarises and paraphrases Conder, Modern Traveller, vol. 18, pp. 256-67, which itself draws on Townsend, Swinburne, Jacob, Peyron and Bourgoing.
tei:div.ab: Foreign review Nov. 1828 says Moors had no knowledge of classics therefore all their poetry new. all in vulgar tongue. even science in verse & algebra. The rest of Europe wrote then in latin. Many XtiansChristians in Spain wrote in Arabic, many of their books yet at Toledo & Escurial. The clergy menaced XtiansChristians for this. Also Moors wrote a code of Arab laws in Spanish & a book of agriculture. A Spanish MSManuscript. in Arab letters mentiond by M. de Sacy. When Calcanasor i.e. the legendary Battle of Calatañazor, usually dated to 1002 and usually as a Muslim defeat. was taken by Moors in 998. a ghost as a fisherman on the banks of the Guadalquivir sung in a loud & mournful voice “Almanser has lost his drum at Calcanasor”. he sung alternately in Arabic & Spanish & then vanishd. First real Spanish poetry Galician where no Moor. Gonzalo Hermiguez to Ourouana his wife

Many Spanish histories of 12th century. Ferdinand & his Son Alonzo the wise translated code of Goths into Spanish & used Spanish in every thing. But Alphonso read arabic deeply, but ordered that all useful works should be translated into Spanish. The Limousin tongue, says Raymond Vidal an old Troubador was the 3d & principal tongue of Spain used in Guienne & Provence Catalonia Valencia & Islands. Antonio Ruffi historian of Marseilles says tounge of that city changed in 12 century by Catalonian words. [O with X through (Indicating continuation onto next page) Actually summary of Foreign Quarterly Review, vol. 3, no. 5 (Sep 1828), 1-28: review of Silvestre de Sacy, Chrestomathie Arabe..., 2nd edn, 3 vols (Paris, 1826-7). Specifically, pp. 13-18 of the review.
Calat Anosor Arabic in Calcanasor in his drum has lost El manser Al or Elmanser Khasara Tablahu fi Calcanasor.

metamark.note: O with X through (Indicating continuation from previous page)

note.bibl: Summary of FQR review of Silvestre de Sacy, pp. 18-19, 22-5.

tei:div.ab: Ergo the Troubadours came first from Catalonia, Pittoni in history of Aix says “Ce fut sous eux que nous Provençaux trouverent l’art de rimer”It was under them that we Provençals found the art of rhyme.. Hence Toulouse under the Berengers metropolis of Troubadours.
Abderramen King of Cordova invaded Toulouse in 8th century. Then Charlemagne invaded Spain.

Alphonso 6th of Castile conqueror of Toledo being dethroned by his brother Sancho fled to the Saracen King of Toledo. & remained 3 years, recovering his throne he took Toledo from the son of his benefactor, a siege of 5 years, The Moors by stipulation remained at Toledo under the XtiansChristians with laws property & grand mosque. & Arabic for more than 100 years the tongue. Some years later Alfonso defeated at Medina by Kings of Cordova & Seville, he made peace marrying Zaïde daughter of the Moorish Here, WG has used 'Moorish' rather than the FQR's 'Saracen'. King of Seville.
Toledo taken in 1085, here Moors French & Spanish lived together. Wm of Poictiers William of Poitiers (c. 1020-90) first of Troubadours known went with Alphonso against Toledo.
Homer unknown from 4th to 14th century. Among Chas. VthsCharles V's library at the Louvre 900 Vols only Ovid Lucan & Boëthius.
Sonnet in form & alternate rhymes all Moorish
Times of Chivalry says Sismondy never existed but in Romance.

Berengere wife of Alfonso VIII of Castile came on walls of Toledo against the besieging moors in 1139 called them cowards & dared them to leave a woman quiet & go & meet the King at Oreja. The Moors did so, lauding her beauty & virtue
In 10 century the monk Gerbert alias pope Sylvester II studied at Moorish college at Seville. so after did Adelard, Gerard of Cremona &c.
Frederic Barbarossa had Arabic books turned into Latin.
Petrarch says Arabs invented rhyme.
15th century only Pico of Mirandola studied Arabic.
Clenard a few years after went to Spain to learn arabic & only found one person Ferdinand Nuntius who knew it a little.
Pope Gregory destroyed Livy. Cardinal Ximenes burned 5,000 fine volumes. One Zegri a converted Moor burn’t 150,000 volumes though converted by force.
When Philip 2d founded Library of Escurial he could only get 300 Arabic M.S.S.Manuscripts

The great stock afterwards added were taken by de Lara off Salee in 1611 in 2 moorish ships bearing the library of the EmpEmperor: of Morocco. There were 3,000 arab M.S.S. some said 7,800 as a Moor said. Half this burnt at a fire of Escurial in 1671. The moorish literature not quite forgotten in Spain but the first work printed in Arab letters there 1760-70 Bibliotheca Arabico-Hispana, by Casiri Miguel Casiri, Bibliotheca arabico-hispana escurialensis..., 2 vols (Madrid: Antonio Perez de Soto, 1760-1770)..
Koran printed at Venice 1530 probably burnt by Clement VII because no confutation
About 50 years later Arab press in Maronite convent at Rome.
English monk Adelard turned Euclid from Arabic to Latin.
Robt. of Rutland Robert of Ketton (fl. 1141-57), an Englishman based in Spain. translated Koran in 12th century.
De Sacy Crestomathie Arabe good new work. 3 Vols 8oo. c Silvestre de Sacy, Chrestomathie Arabe..., 2nd edn, 3 vols (Paris, 1826-7).
SIERRA NEVADA
Pa de Veleta surely 'Picacho de Veleta': Peak of Veleta. 3794 Muleyhassan Mulhacén
Sierra Tejada 2 557

SPAIN
Temp In the time of . Philip 2d. he was very poor yet 58 Archbishops. 684 Bishops. 11 400 abbots. 936 chapters. 127 000 parishes. 7,000 hospitals. 23,000 fraternities. 46,000 monasteries. 135 000 convents. 312 000 secular priests. 200 000 inferior ecclesiastics. 400 000 monks & nuns. & whole population 10.500000. at least 400 000 Moors banished by Philip III.

Philip IIs revenue 30 000 000 of ducats – not half had his Successor, whose public debt exceeded 100. Charles II had only 7 or 8 000 000 of francs. Philip V only 7,500000 souls Charles III had 11 000 000 souls. From beginning of Ferdinands reign to end of next reign revenue had increased from 26,000000 to 60 … … i.e. 60,000,000 of crowns

Conde Vol 2 p108 says el Rey Alfonso de Galicia ufano y evanecido de sus victorias y de la conquista de Toledo cabeza de España y casa principal de los Reyes Godos King Alfonso of Galicia, made proud and conceited [envanecido] by his victories and the conquest of Toledo, capital of Spain and main home of the Gothic Kings having a secret understanding with Abed of Sevilla. Aben Abed Almutamad was king of Seville Alfonso had already made tributary Yahye Alcadir de of Valencia. Alfonso wrote to Aben Abed that he would have certain places & Castles by force.

Alfonso wrote this, "Del Emperador y señor de las dos leyes y naciones, el excelente y poderoso Rey D. Alfonso ben Sancho al Rey Almutemed bila Aben Abed, que Dios fortifique y alumbre su entendimiento para que se determine a seguir el verdadero camino que os conviene. salud y Buena voluntad de parte de un Rey engrandecedor de reynos y amparador de pueblos, al cual han encanecido los cabellos en el conocimiento y prudencia de las cosas y en el ejercicio y destreza de las armas, y en perpetua consecucion de victorias en cuya casa nació la consecution de sus deseos y el cumplimiento de su voluntad en cuyas banderas esta de asiento la Victoria From the Emperor and lord of the two laws and nations, the excellent and powerful King Don Alfonso ben Sancho to King Almutemed bila Aben Abed, may God fortify and illuminate his understanding that he may be determined to follow the true path that suits you [plural]. Health and goodwill on the part of a King who is an aggrandiser of kingdoms and a protector of peoples, whose hair has greyed in the knowledge and prudence of things and in the exercise and skill of arms, and in perpetual achievement of victories, in whose house was born the achievement [Conde has 'consecucion'] of his desires and the fulfilment of his will, in whose banners Victory sits...This is the beginning of a longer letter printed by Conde, vol. 2, pp. 109-10.Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 2, pp. 108-9.

Goths entered Spain 409. beat Romans & natives Goths King married daur of Emp. daughter of Emperor Theodosius. Natives retired to Galicia. 418 Vandals. 456 Theodoric the Goth beat king of Suevi. Euric son of Theodc Theodoric went from Pyrenees to Rhone but Clovis retook this from Alaric son of Euric. 624
Kg King Suintilla
Kg King of whole Peninsula. Ceuta resisted moors. Count Julian its Governor. Musa could not take it. Kg King Witizas Sister Julians wife. 712 Taric defeats Roderic at Xeres. Palagius retires to Asturias. Goths Arians first.

Under Tarik. Royal Legion of Damascus at Cordova. Legion of Emesa at Seville
of Kinnisrin or Calchis at Jaen
of Palestine at Algeziras & Medina Sidonia
of Yemen & Persia at Toledo
Egypt in Murcia & Lisbon
of cavalry of Irak & Syria at Granada. These were 10 000 of the most noble Arabs & Syrians.
Spain under Viceroy of Caliphs till Ommiades Umayyads fell. When one of them came to Spain x was Caliph Abdalrahman. He beat the AbbassidesAbbasids & reigned at Cordova. This race lasted abt 250 years. Then split into Kingdoms.

Pelagius founded Km. Kingdom of Leon. beat Moors 718. 881 Alphonso took Coimbra. Ramirus 2d Madrid & almost Toledo. From David Brewster (ed.), The Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, 18 vols (Edinburgh, 1830), vol. 18, pp. 277-9. The Encyclopaedia paraphrases Edward Gibbon's History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire here (vol. 5, including chapters LI and LII), but the order and precise wording of observations shows WG was reading Brewster.Vide p17 WG's page 17 of this notebook (pag 186).

note.bibl: Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. iv-xx. These are extracts, which Gell sometimes adapts with his own Spanish.

tei:div.ab: Conde Dominación de Los Arabes en España

El Rey Don Alfonso el Sabio ordeno en el año 1254 en Sevilla estudios de Latin y. Arabigo. En tiempo de Felipe III fu presa una nave en que iba la libereria de Muley Zidan Principe de Marruecos. ma. en 1671 un incendio consumia en El Escorial mas de ocho mil volumenes, la mayor parte arabigos.

Arabs at conquest of Spain gave el libre egercicio de su religion la conservacion de sus templos y la seguridad de sus personas, bienes y posesiones. Y la fidelidad de estos en guardar sus pactos y mantener justicia igual con todos las clases sin distincion alguna ganaba la confianza de los pueblos &.. Y en estas prendas generoso animo y hospitalidad eran estremados los Arabes de aquellos tiempos.
Isidoro de Beja (el Cronicon de) es el unico contemporaneo a la venida de los Arabigos. Hasta el año 7mo de Jucef el Fehri 745 J.C.
Sebastiano Salmanticense Cronica 886 J.C.
Cronicon Abeldense que añadiò el monge Vigila 973.
Cronicon de Sampiro Asturiense 982
Pelagio Ovetense 1109.
Anales Complutenses 1119 – In Era MCXXIV die 6. X Kal Novembris die SS. Servandi et Germani, fuit illa arrancada in Baduzo. id est Sacralias et fuit ruptus Rex domnus Adefonsus.
los Compostelanos 1248 – says. Era MCXXIV fuit illa die Badajoz
Toledanos 1290 – Era 1124 arrancaron Moros al Rey don Alonzo en Zagalla.
De estos Cronicones y algunos escritos Arabigos formò Don Rui Ximenez Arzobispo de Toledo su historia de los Arabes: He spoke the Muzarabes tongue well. Ao 539 de los Arabes 1140 de J.C.
La historia que se dice del Moro Rasis, de los Cronicones antiguos con algunas noticias de malos libros arabigos: toda llena de errores y fabulas absurdas. But its geography good.
tei:div.note: Conde Domination of the Arabs in Spain King Don Alfonso the Wise ordered the study of Latin and Arabic in the year 1254 in Seville. In the time of Philip III, a ship was seized with the library of Muley Zidan, Prince of Morocco. 'ma': not in Conde; WG may be using Italian for 'but'. in 1671 a fire in the Escorial consumed more than eight thousand volumes, most of them Arabic. Arabs at conquest of Spain gave [Christians] the free exercise of their religion, the preservation of their temples and the security of their people, property and possessions. And their [the Arabs'] fidelity in keeping their pacts and maintaining equal justice among all classes without any distinction won the confidence of the peoples &c. And in these garments, generosity of spirit and hospitality, the Arabs of those times were distinguished. Isidoro of Beja (the Chronicle of) is the only contemporary to the arrival of the Arabs Conde has 'Arabes'. Until the 7th year of Jucef el Fehri 754AD. Chronicle by Sebastian of Salamanca 886AD. Albeldensian Chronicle, compiled by the monk Vigila 973. Chronicle of Sampiro of Asturias 982. Chronicle by Pelagius of Oviedo 1109. Annals of Alcalá de Henares 1119 - In the year 1124, on Friday, the 10th day before the calends of November, the day of Saints Servando and Germán was torn down in Badajoz, that is Sagrajas: and the lord King Alfonso was broken. The Battle of Sagrajaz, near Badajoz, was an Almoravid victory against Alfonso VI, though actually on Friday 23 October 1086. ‘arrancada’ (torn down) is Spanish rather than Latin. Annals of Santiago de Compostela 1248 - says. In the year 1124 it was on that day in Badajoz Conde is compiling slightly differing sources here Annals of Toledo 1290 - in 1124 the Moors threw King don Alonzo out of Zagalla. Don Rui Ximenez, Archbishop of Toledo, formed his history of the Arabs from these Chronicles and some Arabic writings: He spoke the Mozarabic tongue well. Year 539 of the Arabs, 1140AD. The story that is told of the Moor Rasis, is a compilation (Conde) of the old Chronicles with some information from bad Arabic books: all full of errors and absurd fables. But its geography good.
tei:div.ab: Iza ben Ahmed Razif a real Author.
really wrote a history on which many fables engrafted.
Cronica general de El Rey Don Alfonso el Sabio.General Chronicle of King Don Alfonso the Wise.
very good for that time. yet many fables
Cronicas particulares de Don Alonso el onceno.

History de Tarif Aben Taric por el Morisco Miguel de Luna impudente osadia literaria. WG is citing [Miguel de Luna], Historia Verdadera del Rey Don Rodrigo ... Compuesta por el Sabio Alcayde Abulcacim Tarif, de Nacion Arabe (first published in 1592).[True History of King Don Rodrigo... Composed by the Wise Governor Abulcacim Tarif, of the Arab Nation]
Varios autores de Hadices = tradicionales.
Hadgi Chalfa 1200 historiadores.
tei:div.note: Particular Chronicles of Don Alonso the eleventh. History of Tarif Aben Taric by the Morisco Miguel de Luna, impudent, daring, literary. Various authors of Hadiths = traditional. Hadgi Chalfa 1200 historians.
tei:div.ab: Aben Regig o Rechic hista de Africa.
Aben Hayan de Espana el mejór, a los reynados de los Omeyas en Cordoba. Aben Regig or Rechic history of Africa. Aben Hayan the best on Spain, to the reigns of the Umayyads in Cordoba.
Arabs generally shortened history & geography & left only the skeleton.
Fez not founded till ao 192 Heg.
Arabic governors

Amires. Walies. Wacires. Cadies. Alcaydes. Xeques. Hagibes. Almucademes. Arrayaces. Emirs (princes), Walis (leaders or prefects), Wazirs (ministers), Qadis (judges of islamic law), Governors, Sheikhs, Hajibs (court officials), Muqaddams (officials; WG translates later as captains or chiefs), Captains

Hours = hora de Azohbi = Alba – de Adoha = dia claro – de Adohar = mediodia. de alazar = media tarde. almagrib sunset, puesta del Sol Hours = hour of Azohbi = Alba - de Adoha = a clear day - de Adohar = midday. de alazar = mid-afternoon. almagrib sunset, sunset
alatema o alaxa = al anochecer.i.e. el anochecer = sunset horas de sus oraciones o azalaes. hours of their prayers or azalaes.
months Muharram Safer Rabie 1ma Rabie 2o
Giumada 1a. do 2a. Regeb. Xaban

Ramazan. Xawal. Dylcada. Dilhagia Months of the Islamic calendar Muharram, Safar, Rabi al-Awwal, Rabi al-Thani, Jumada al-Awwal, Jumada al-Thani, Rajab, Shaban, Ramadan, Shawwal, Dhul Qadah, Dhul Hijjah do = ditto (the same), i.e. 'Giumada'
never exceed 30 or less than 29 alternately.
epochs from foundation de la Caaba o casa cuadrada. of the Kaaba or square house [at Mecca]
El Hegira principio 16 junio 622 de J.Xtus. The Hegira [Islamic calendar] began on 16 June 622AD.

note.bibl: Conde,Historia de la dominacion, vol. 2, passim: i.e. the Emperor of the Christians, Alfonso.

tei:div.ab: The Rey Alfonso called El Embalatur de los Xtianos Aladfuns & Adfuns.

note.bibl: Extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. xxi-xxiv.

tei:div.label: Conde Followed
tei:div.ab: Works of Abu Abdala Muhamad ben Abi Nasr el Homaidi de Cordova. Cronica de la conquista de España. Amires &c la serie de los Beni Omeyas, Reyes de Cordoba, y vidas de varones ilustres de España. 450 de Hegira continued by Ahmed ben Yahye ben Ahmed ben Omeira Edobi de Mallorca 560.

El Homaidi cita Abdelmelic ben Habib Zalemi, Abdala ben Junes, Abdala ben Wahib, Alaitz ben Saad y Abul Casem Abderahman ben Abdala ben Abdelhakem all writers of the oldest times. Es un tomo en folio escrito en papel moreno y grueso
Asimismo

Aben Alabar, el Codai Valenciano escritor muy docto y extractò mucho de Abu Meruan ben Hayan ben Chalif. Tambien de los anales de Abul Hassan ben Besam de Mocri abu Abdala ben Abdelaziz ben Saad Axati, y de Iza ben Ahmed ben Muhamad ben Muza el Razif, y de Muhamad Abu Becar ben Jucef ben Casem Xelbi en su historia de Aben Abed Rey de Sevilla.

Obra de Meraudi intitulada “Prados Aureos”. 327 de los Arabes y la expedicion de Abderraman III, talas y conquistas reciprocas de Zamora por las tropas del Rey de Cordoba y los Xtianos acaudillados por el Rey Radmir de Galicia. 327 hasta 336.
Abul Casem Chalaf ben Abdelmelic ben Bascual de Cordoba hasta el quinto siglo de la Hegira un tomo in folio.

note.ab: Works of Abu Abadala Muhamad ben Abi Nasr el Homaidi [i.e. Al-Humaydi] of Cordoba. Chronicle of the conquest of Spain. Emirs etc. the succession of the Beni Omeyas [Umayyads], Kings of Cordoba, and lives of illustrious men of Spain. AH 450 [Anno Hegirae: Islamic calendar] continued by Ahmed ben Yahye ben Ahmed ben Omeira, Edobi of Mallorca, 560.

Al-Humaydi cites [Conde has 'cita a...'] Abdelmelic ben Habib Zalemi, Abdala ben Junes, Abdala ben Wahib, Alaitz ben Saad and Abul Casem Abderahman ben Abdala ben Abdelhaken all writers of the oldest times. It is a volume in folio written on brown and coarse paper.

Aben Alabar, el Codai, of Valencia, very learned writer and he extracts much from Abu Meruan ben Hayan ben Chalf [according to Conde]. Also from the annals of Abul Hasan [Conde], ben Besam, Mocri abu Abdala ben Abdelaziz ben Saad Axati, and Iza ben Ahmed ben Muhamad ben Muza el Razif, and Muhamad Abu Becar ben Jucef ben Casem Xelbi in his history of Aben Abed, King of Seville.

Work of Meraudi entitled 'Golden Meadows'. 327 of the Arabs [i.e. AH 327] and the expedition of Abderraman III, cutting down and reciprocal conquests of Zamora by the troops of the King of Cordoba and the Christians led by King Radmir of Galicia. [AH] 327 to [AH] 336.
Abul Casem Chalaf ben Abdelmelic ben Bascual of Cordoba [covers the period] until the fifth century of Hegira, a volume in folio.

tei:div.ab: Epoch of the Almoravides y de los Almohades en la historia de Fez de Abdel Halim de Granada 726 – tomo en quarto en papel.
Lizan-Edin ben Alchatib Asalemani Secretario de los Reyes de Granada. called El Plenilunio de la dymnastia Nasrina en Granada: y 3 tomos en folio biograficas 2 Memorias 1.
Abdala Algiazami de Malaga wrote Granada y la historia de sus Reyes.
Ahmed Almaxarsi del Rey Jucef Abul Hagiag el augusto de Granada. Y de la de los Beni Merinas in prose & verse by Ismail ben Jucef Amir de Malaga, intitulada “Olor de la rosa”.
Anales de Abulfeda, los de Xakiki y de Fesani
Anales de Aben Sohna.
Obra de Abu Teib de Ronda anecdotes of Princes & Arabs &c

Obra rara de Abdala Aly ben Abderahman ben Huzeil de Granada. expediciones sacras o guerras contra Christianos, de arte militar de hacer frontera, de ardides y estrategemas de guerra, armas, maquinas, y caballeria. es muy curioso en los usos y costumbres de los Arabes Españoles. Tomo in folio escrito en papel moreno y grueso, de harta antigüedad.
La mayor parte de estos M.S.S estan en la Bibliotheca Real publica en Madrid y en la Escorial
At Paris in Royal library “Historia de Espana y su description por Ahmed el Mocri Almagrebi in Arabic.

Condes book. La primera trata de la entrada de los Arabes en Espana, y la sucesion de los Amires, o caudillos de la conquista dependientes de los Calyfas de Oriente. La 2a contiene el establecimiento de la monarquia de los Beni Omeyas y la sucesion de estos Reyes. La tercera comprende la guerra civil y division de los reynos en España: venida de los Almoravides y Almohades y la sucesion de estas dymnastias. Y la quarta es toda del reyno de Granada ultimo period de la dominacion Arabiga en España.

note.ab: Epoch of the Almoravids and Almohads in the history of Fez by Abdel Halim of Granada 726 - volume in quarto on paper.
Lizan-Edin ben Alchatib Asalemani, Secretary to the Kings of Granada. Called the Full Moon of the Nasrid dynasty in Granada: and 3 volumes in folio, 2 biographical and 1 memoirs.
Abdala Algiazami of Málaga wrote Granada and the history of its Kings.

Ahmed Almaxarsi [wrote] about King Jucef Abul Hagiag the august of Granada. And of the [history] of the Beni Merinas in prose and verse by Ismail ben Jucef, Emir of Málaga, entitled 'Scent of the rose'.
Annals of Abulfeda, those of Xakiki and of Fesani
Work of Abu Teib of Ronda anecdotes of Princes and Arabs etc

Rare work of Abdala Aly ben Abderahman ben Huzeil of Granada. [Treats of] holy expeditions or wars against Christians [Conde: 'Cristianos'], of the art of war, of making frontiers, of schemes and strategies of war, weapons, siege engines, and cavalry. It is very curious on the usages and customs of the Spanish Arabs. Volume in folio written on brown, coarse paper, of great antiquity.
Most of these manuscripts are in the royal public library [Conde: 'biblioteca'] of Madrid and the Escorial.
At Paris in Royal library 'History of Spain and its description['] by Ahmed el Mocri Almagrebi in Arabic.

Conde's book. The first [volume] deals with the arrival of the Arabs in Spain, and the succession of the Emirs, or leaders of conquest, dependent on the Caliphs of the East. The second contains the establishment of the monarchy of the Beni Omeyas [Umayyads] and the succession of these Kings. The third comprises the civil war and division of the kingdoms of Spain: the coming of the Almoravids and the Almohads and the succession of these dynasties. And the whole of the fourth is about the kingdom of Granada, the last period of Arab domination in Spain.

tei:div.note: The following are extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. 1-7.
tei:div.ab: Conde. La dominación de los Arabés
de los campos de Yemen. Islam = seguridad y resignation. unde Muslimes. Idolatrous antes Mahomad.

Saad ben Ahmed Cadi de la ciudad de Toledo decia que fueran 2 generaciones de Arabes in Arabia. One is extinct tribes of Ad, of Themud, Tesm y Jadis. Los que permanecen son dos castas de Cahtan y Adnan. el imperio estaba en la cabila o tribu de Cahtan. y la familia de los Reyes Homiares. Kings Lords y Tobeos. Campiñas di Irak o Caldea.

Homiar tribu adoraba el sol, Canenah a la Luna. Misam la estrella Aldebaran. Laham y Jedam, Jupiter Estrella. Tay la constellacion de Sohail. Kais la Ashera al Obur. Asad la de Mercurio. Tzaquif un tempillo Alat en las alturas de Nahla. Some believed in ye resurrection & some sacrificed a camel or horse on the tombs.

Mahomad naciò en Mecca ciudad del Hegiaz. Conde, The domination of the Arabs from the lands of Yemen. Islam = security and resignation [i.e. resignación]. whence Muslims. Idolatrous before Muhammad. Saad ben Ahmed, qadi [judge of Islamic law] of the city of Toledo, said that there were 2 generations of Arabs in Arabia. One is extinct tribes of Ad, of Themud, Tesm and Jadis. Those who remain are two castes [i.e. lines] of Cahtan and Adnan. The empire was in the tribe [cabila] or tribe [tribu] of Cahtan. and the family of the Himyarite Kings. Kings, Lords and Successors [Conde: 'Tobeos ó sucesores']. Countryside of [Conde: 'de'] Iraq or Chaldea. Himyarite tribe worshipped the sun, Canenah the moon, Misam the star Aldebaran, Laham and Jedam the star Jupiter, Tay the constellation Suhail [Vela], Kais [the star] Ashera al Obur, Asad that of Mercury, Tzaquif a small temple [Conde: 'templillo'] Alat in the heights of Nahla. Some believed in the resurrection [of the dead, not specifically of Christ: Conde] and some sacrificed a camel or horse on the tombs. Muhammad was born in Mecca, a city in the Hejaz. there the Anct Temple AlbaramConde has 'Alharam' to true God. founded by Ismael. Mahomad of tribe or Cabila de Coraix tribe of Quraysh of great family. Conqueror at Honain at Bedrè & Ohod.
Adnan descendant of Ismael
Maad
Nazar
Modhar
Alyas
Modreca
Hozaimah
Kenanah
Alnadhr
Malec
Fehr
Galeb
Lova
Caab
Morra
Kelab
Abdmenaf
Hasem
Abdelmotaleb Xi.e. indicating below
Abdalah = Amina
Mahomad = CadijahKhadija, the Prophet's first wife. Not in Conde.

Arabs counted from the epoch of the Ethiopic war or “la entrada del Señor del Alfil o del Elefantethe entry of the Lord of the Elephant ('alfil' is Arabic for elephant). Invasion of Mecca by the Ethiopian Christian governor of Yemen, Abrahah al-Ashram, in c.570-1AD.. In this Abdelmotaleb Xi.e. indicating above, Muhammad's grandfather defended his country & destroyed the army of the Ethiopian King. This war mentioned in the Koran. Jusuf ben Said of Illora writes about it also.
Medina Yatrib afterwards called Medinatalnabi = city of Prophet.

Mahomed born at dawn 8 of month Rebie primeraRabi al-Awwal (month in Islamic calendar) on tuesday 622 after Xt Christ .WG has misread here: Conde says Muhammad was born in 572AD, but that Hegira (Islamic calendar) begins in 622AD.
tei:div.note: The following are extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. 22-30, 33.
tei:div.ab: In year of Hegira 86. Ao Xt 705AH 86, 705AD died the Calif Abdelmelec. His son Walid ben Abdelmelic succeeded. He confirmed Muza ben Noseir i.e. Musa ibn Nusayr (c.640-c.716) in command of the troops in Africa, He & his son Abdelaziz conquered in Almagreb. beat the Moor tribes Masmuda. Zanhaga. Ketama & Hoara. Meruan son of Musa came to Tanja i.e. Tangier.

Certain Xtians of Gezira de Alandalus ofendida de su Rey Ruderic vinieron a Muza ben Noseir, y le incitaron a pasar con tropas a España. The channel or gut called Alzacac. El Rey Don Alfonso el Sabio made the chronicle of these times but la Caba the Donzella Alifa &c all Moorish fictions. The Calif applauded Muzas enterprise. Muza sent Taric ben Zeyad. He passed with quinientos caballeros Arabes en 4 barcos grandes ao 710 Certain Christians of Gezira of al-Andalus [Conde's translation: the peninsula of Spain], offended by their King Ruderic, came to Musa ibn Nusayr and incited him to cross with troops into Spain. The channel or gut called Alzacac. King Don Alfonso the Wise made the chronicle of these times but la Caba, the maiden [Conde has 'doncella'] Alifa etc all Moorish fictions [Conde, vol. 1, p. 25: part of story of why the Arabs crossed to Spain; la Caba, daughter of Count Don Julian]. The Calif applauded Musa's enterprise. Musa sent Taric ben Zeyad. He passed with four hundred Arab knights in 4 large ships in 710AD.. They took some places on the coast of Andalucia. & returned.

After this Taric landed with an army at Gezira Alhadra or Isla VerdeGreen Island. Taric beat the natives & fortified Gebal Taric Alfeth anciently. & burnt his Ships. Tadmir, Roderics captain there. He wrote to Roderic. Señor aqui han llegado gentes enemigas de la parte de Africa. yo no se si del cielo u de la tierra: yo me halle acometido de ellos de improviso: resisti con todas mis fuerzas para defender la entrada: pero me fue forzoso cedar a la muchedumbre y al impetu suyo, ahora a mi pesar acampan en nuestra tierra: ruegoos Señor, pues tanto os cumple que vengais a socorrernos con la mayor diligencia. y con cuanta gente se pueda allegar: venid vos Senor en persona que sera lo mejor.”My lord, enemy peoples from Africa have arrived here. I do not know if from heaven or earth: I found myself suddenly attacked by them: I resisted with all my strength to defend against their arrival: but I was forced to give in to the crowd and their momentum, now in spite of me they camp on our land: I beg, my lord, that it satisfies you to come to help us with the greatest diligence. and with however many people can be gathered: come yourself in person, my lord, which would be best.
He sent a fine body of cavalry Gothic who skirmished always with loss. The Muslimes commanded by Mugueiz el Rumi.
Roderic raised the whole country & came to
tei:div.note: Extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. 30-50.
tei:div.ab: Sidonia with 90 000 men. The hosts met on a Sunday on banks of the Guadaledei.e. Guadalete 2 days before RamazanRamadan. Temblaba debajo de sus pies la tierra y se estremecia, y resonaba el ayre con el estruendo de los atambores y añafires y con el sonido di guerreras trompas, y con el espantoso alarido de ambas huestes The earth trembled under their feet and shuddered, and the air rang with the noise of the drummers and trumpets [añafiles] and with the sound of [Conde has 'de'] war trumpets, and with the dreadful howl of both hosts.. 4 Xtians to 1 Turk Conde has 'cuatro Cristianos para cada Muslim' (four Christians for each Muslim) The night separated the armies. Next day the same. Taric on 3d day saw the Moors ready to yield so cried G’ualai.e. a war cry. Conde gives Taric a much longer speech & attacked & killed King Ruderic. & the rest fled. The place covered with bones long after. Taric sent Roderics head to Muza. Muza left Africa or Cairvan to Abdelaziz his son & brought over 8,000 foot & 10 000 horse. His sons Abdelola & Meruan came also, the last gave his name to a palace on the river West of Cordova. Came also Arabs of tribe Coraix i.e. Quraysh. also Almonazir, Aly ben Rebie Lahmi, Hayut ben Reja Tamani, Hanas ben Abdala Asenani, que despues fue la grande Aljama de Saracustawho afterwards founded [Conde: fundó] the great Aljama [mosque] of Zaragoza. Taria proceeded in spite of Muza & made good regulations for sparing the natives when they submitted. Mugueiz el Rumi went to Cordova. Zayde ben Kesadi el Sekseki to Malaga. The third body Taric took by JayenJaén to Tolaitola or Toledo the capital. Kesadi joined on the road having conquered the people of EstijaÉcija. Malaga & Elvira yielded.

Spali Esbilia = Sevilla. Mugueiz took Cordoba. Taric at Tolaitola which Capitulated. Those who fled lost their goods, those who staid kept all only paying tribute. Churches & religion spared only no more to be built without licence. Taric lived in the alcazar del Reythe King's fortress. in a room 25 crowns of gold garnished with hyacinths i.e. jacinths &other stones. ie one crown for each of 25 Gothic Kings who had reigned.

Muza went by Esbilia & took it by convention. left Abdila el Towail de Medina of Medina governor. Thence to Carmuna Carmona which yielded. he had 18 000 horse few foot. went into Algarbe or Lusitania i.e. the south of Portugal & took Libla, Ossonoba,
Myrtilis Beja &c & came to Merida a magnift city with high towered walls.

Besieged it sent for his Son Abdelaziz with fresh troops. Citizens skirmished with loss. Ambuscade by Musa in a deep glen. He takes a tower is driven from it called from the deaths Borg Axuhuda = Torre de los Martires Tower of the Martyrs.

Abdelaziz came with 7,000 horse & ballesteria grande de los Berberies Conde has 'gran ballestería': the great crossbowmen of the Berbers. The city yielded. Those who came to the camp saw his long white beard one day, it was red black the next. it alarmed them. Found at Merida Roderics Queen.

Taric from Tolaitola took a city tras los montes beyond the mountains & gave it his name. Then Guadilhigiara its river & mount. & a Valley Feg Taric. Medina Almeida la mesa de Suleiman Suleiman's table because a mesa table garnished with emeralds & jacinths found there. Next Medina Maya where much booty & returned to Toledo. Seville rebelled & killed 30 Moors. Abdelaziz sent & took it & chastised it. The Roman bridges of Tagus & Guadiana they admired much & called Ionian. At Talbera Medina Conde has 'Medina Talbera' Taric came to meet Musa the Wali & appeased him by jewels & spoil & so they went to Toledo. There in the Alcacar Fortress (Alcázar) Musa asked for the “mesa de Suleyman Suleyman's table. It wanted one foot Taric said he had found it so. Musa discharged him for disobedience, to his Wali, in the name of the Calif.

Abdelaziz conquers Tadmir & its Gothic King in Murcia. Tadmir ben Gobdos. At Lorca Xns Christians defeated in a great battle. Xtians fled to Auriola. The Xn women mounted guard as men & tied their hair under chins to sham beards. Moors taken in. Capitulation. “En nombre de Dios clemente y misericordioso Abdelaziz y Tadmir hacen este convenio de paz que Dios confirme y proteja: que Tadmir haya el mando de sus gentes, y no otro de los Xtianos de su reyno que no habra entre ellos guerra ni se les tomaran cautivos sus hijos ni mugeres: que no serán molestados sobre su religion, ni se les incendiarán sus iglesias, sin otros servicios ni obligaciones que las aqui convenidas: que esta avenencia se entienda tambien sobre siete ciudades, Auriola Valentila, Lecant. Mula. Boscara. Ota y Lorca. que In the name of God, gracious and merciful, Abdelaziz and Tadmir make this covenant of peace, which God confirms and protects: that Tadmir is in command of his people, and not another of the Christians of his kingdom[:] that there will be no war between them, nor will they take their children or women captive: that they will not be disturbed in their religion, nor will their churches be burned, without other services or obligations than those agreed upon here: that this agreement also be understood for seven cities, Auriola, Valentila, Lecant, Mula, Bocsara, Ota and Lorca. That [onto next page]
tei:div.note: Extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. 50-7, 61-6.
tei:div.ab: el no recibira nuestros enemigos ni nos faltarà a la fidelidad, ni ocultarà trato hostil que entienda: que el y sus nobles pagarán el servicio di un dinar o aureo cade año, y cuatro medidas de trigo, y cuatro de cebada, y cuatro de mosto, y cuatro de vinagre, y cuatro de miel, y cuatro de aceite; y los siervos o pecheros la mitad de esto, Fue escrita en cuatro de Regeb, año noventa y cuatro de la Hegira. Testificaron sobre esto Otzman ben Abi Abda, Habib ben Abi Obeida, Edris ben Maicera, y Abulcasim el Mezeli [From previous page: that] he will not receive our enemies, nor will he lack loyalty to us, nor will he conceal hostile treatment that he knows about: that he and his nobles will pay tribute of one dinar or gold piece each year, and four measures of wheat, and four of barley, and four of grape juice, and four of vinegar, and four of honey, and four of oil; and the serfs or commoners half of this, This was written on the fourth of Regeb, year ninety-four of Hegira [AH 94, by Islamic calendar]. Otzman ben Abi Abda, Habib ben Abi Obeida, Edris ben Maicera and Abulcasim el Mezeli testified to this.. The messenger who went to make this accord was Tadmir himself. The Moors entering the city next day asked where was the garrison Tadmir told them Women.

Abdelaziz next took Sierras de Segura, Bazta, Acxi, Jayen, Elvira y en Garnata, que tenian los Judios y en Anticaria y Malaga y otras ciudades de la costa del mar.Abdelaziz next took the mountains of Segura, Bazta, Acxi, Jaén, Elvira and Granada, which the Jews held, and Antequera and Málaga and other cities of the sea coast.
Tadmir ben Gobdas King of Eastn Andalucia.
The Calif sent Muza to restore Taric. Taric & Muza both went against East Spain ordering again prohibition de robos y pillage con pena de la vida.Prohibition of robbery and pillage on pain of death.

Taric went to founts of Tagus. Arcabica sierras. Molina y Segoncia, y las vegas y campos que riega el Ebro.Arcabica mountains. Molina and Segoncia, and the fertile plains and fields irrigated by the Ebro. Muza to Sentica & Salamanca Astorica & then along the Duero to the east, to Medina SaracustaZaragoza then besieged by Taric. Muza ben Noseir took a great fine & left governor Hanax ben Abdala Asenani who built a Mezquita y una principal Aljama a mosque and a principal great mosque.

They took Wesca, Turiazona, Calagurra, Ilerda, Tarragona up to mts Anfranc i.e. the Pyrenees (Conde has Afranc: France). Taric took Tortuxa, Murbiter, Valencia, Xativa y Denia. Islam at Barciluna, Gerunda y Empuria & also into land of AfrancFrance & took Medina NarbonaNarbonne

where fine 7 idol equestrian of silver in a temple. Then to Guf & to Galicia por Asturica y en Lugidania through Astorga and into Lusitania. The Calif had a fifth of spoil. They plundred & quarrelled so the Calif ordred both Muza & Taric to Damascus. Muza left his son Abdelaziz Governor of Spain. Amir.

Muza went to Damascus with great riches & 400 Varones de las familias regias godas who wore on their heads diademas de oro. & golden belts. entrò en Syria 95 of Hegira. 400 men of the Gothic royal families who wore on their heads diadems of gold and golden belts. He entered Syria AH 95 [713AD].
The Calif Walid received him well I mean Taric
Fostat near Cairo = a Tent. Alguf = north. Alquibla = S.south Axarkia = E.east Algarbe West.
Mechtisebes; treasures of provinces

The Calif ordered the death of Muzas sons in Spain. Poor Abdelaziz was at an Alqueria cerca Sevilla que se llamaba Kenisa Rebina a farmhouse near Seville, called Kenisa Rebina where he built a Mosque. El Wali his Title His muger goda Ayela favorecia mucho a los Xtianoshis Gothic wife, Ayela, greatly favoured the Christians. Zeyad ben Nabigat el Temimi got him slain head cut off & body buried en el patio. 97 of Hegira in the yard [courtyard or backyard]. AH 97Tadmir sent & got protection from the Calif.
Ayub was elected Wali brother of Abdelaziz he moved from Sevilla to Cordoba.

The Governor of Zaragoza Hanax ben Abdala ben Amru ben Hantala ben Fehid ben Kenan ben Thalbe ben Abdala ben Thamir Asafei el Senani conquistador de Egipto Africa Almagreb e de España companero de Muza ben Noseir conqueror of Egypt, Africa, the Maghreb and Spain, companion of Musa ibn Nusayr.. He built the great Mosque & Calat-Ayub. The embalmed head of Abdelaziz carried to Suleiman the Calif, when Muza visited him his sons head shewn. o Muza conoces esta cabeza. si bien la conozco, la maledicion de Dios sea sobre quien asesinó a quien era mejor que el. y se salió del palacio lleno de dolor y fallecio de gran melancolia Oh Musa, do you know this head? Yes, I know it well, the curse [Conde: 'maldicion'] of God be on whoever murdered he who was better than him. And he left the palace full of grief and died of great melancholy.. This Calif built the great Mosque of Damascus, with 600 lamps hanging from gold chains. cost 40 chests of 14000 doblas gold coins each. Calif Omar charged them. much smoke.
tei:div.note: Extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, pp. 66-80, 84-92, 98-105, 123-9.
tei:div.ab: Calif Omar ben Abdelaziz succeeded Suleiman he ordered Aly not to be cursed in pulpits.

He deposed Ayub as a son of Muza & made Amir of Spain Alhaur ben Abderahman el Caisi. Ayub only governed but well 7 months. Alhaur el Amir went with an army into Galia Narbonense que es Tierra de Afranc Gallia Narbonensis, which is a Land of France a cruel man. Gibal Albortat = the Pyrenees. from latin portasgates. Jezid was next Calif Ahaur deposed for cruelty 103. Hegira AH 103. next Wali was Alsama ben Melic el Chulani, he got to Carcaxona y Tolosa (Thoulouse) Carcassonne and Toulouse. The Señor de AlfrancLord of France (i.e. Charles Martel) here opposed him & beat & killed him. Moors retired Ambisa ben Sohim who had been left lieutenant sent reinforcements. Abderahman ben Abdala el Gafeki made Amir

The Calif Jezid died for love of Hebaba who was dead. he kept her to look at & at last buried her then had her dug up again & died in a few days. aged 33 years or 29. Hixem ben Abdelmelic next Calif 105 Hegira AH 105 (723AD). Abderahman was deposed & Ambisa became Amir but the deposed Amir remained his friend. Ambisa rebuilt the bridge of Cordova visited the provinces & gave Xts & Muslimes Christians and Muslims. Conde includes Jews. equal justice.

In this time Jews of France & Spain many & rich heard Zonaria their messiah was come & went to Syria leaving their goods. He got into France to the Rodans. Killed by wounds 106 Heg. 724 XtAH 106, 724AD.

He left Hodeira ben Abdala el Fehri who was changed for Yahye ben Zalema. the Basques in Alguf montes Albaskenses Basque mountains. changed for Otman ben Abi Neza Amir. Next Amir was Hodaifa ben Alhaus. nex Otman ben Abi Neza el Chemi. 109. These Emirs rapidly changed.
Albab in Mes Albortat = Puycerda i.e. Albab in the Pyrenees (Montes Albortat) = Puigcerdà
The Moors arrived at the Garuna. The King of AfrancFrance was Caldus. (Carlos Martel Charles Martel). Mesaudi calls all French Kings Colorio & Lodorio the Spanish Lodron or Odron. Bordhal = Bordeaux.
Medina Towrs = Tours. Moors took it. Hosts met on banks of Owar (Loire). The Moors lost the battle & fly to Narbona MedinaNarbonne Abderahman being killed.

The moors get into France again under the Amir Abdelmelic ben Cotan 736 Xt736AD. next Emir Ocba ben Alhegag. he established Cadis Conde has 'Cadies', i.e. Cádiz. Abdelmelic became Amir again but was delivered by his own people to Baleg & Thaalaba two new adventurers from Africa at

Cordova tied to a stake at end of bridge. They cut off his head. Abderahman ben Ocba came to revenge his father. already Thaalaba & Baleg had separated. The son of Ocba killed Baleg with his lance & his troops fled. Abderahman had the title of Almanzor i.e. al-Mansur, the Victorious from this Victory. 742ao. Hegira 125 742AD, AH 125.
The Calif Walid ben Jezid impious drank wine abused power, entered lands of Mecca with hunting dogs made good verses & liked music. he was killed 126 AH 126, 743AD.

Iusuf el Fehri Amir de España Jusuf el Fehri, Emir of Spain746. Amer made governor of Sevilla, he descended from Mosab alferez del Profeta en la batalla de Bedre. era muy poderoso y habia cōstruido un magnifico palacio en Cordoba fuera de sus muros a la parte del ponente de la ciudad y un espacioso cementerio. Mosab, ensign of the Prophet in the battle of Bedre [i.e. Badr, 624AD]. He [Amer] was very powerful and had built [construido] a magnificent palace in Cordoba outside its walls in the Poniente part of the city and a spacious cemetery. Lisbon = Alisbona. Portocale a city or port.

Loado seas Senor Dios, dueño de los imperios que das el señorio a quien quieres, y quitas el señorio a quien quieres, y honras a quien quieres y humillas a quien quieres en tu mano esta el bien y el mal y tu eres sobre todas las cosas poderoso. Praise be to you, Lord God, owner of the empires, you who give lordship to whomever you want, and take lordship away from whomever you want, and honour whomever you want, and humble whomever you want, in your hand is good and evil, and you have power over all things. &. So begins the reign of the Calif Meruan. Forat the Euphrates.
Spain in time of Calif Meruan. under jusuf el Fehri.

Mando restituir los caminos militares de Andalucia a Tolaitola. a Merida, a Alisbona, a Asturica, y a Saracusta y Tarracona. Reparò los puentes deribabos las Aljamas & con la tercia parte de los productos di cada provincia. La primera provincia Andalucia antes Beitica del Beti rio de Cordoba desde su nascimiento. & Guadiana contiene Cordoba Esbilia, Carmona, Estija, Talica cerca de Esbilia antigua casa real de los Eparcos de España, Sidonia Arcos, Libla, Malaga, Elbira, jayen Arjona Castolona, Alturja, Cabra Bulcona (*Porcuna) Astaba Ossona, y otras. 2d Provincia de Tolaitola antes de Cartagena de las sierras de Guadaramla hasta las montañas del otro lado del Duero, contiene Tolaitola, Ubeda, Bayeza, Mentiza, Wadiacix. Basta, Murcia, Bocastra, Mula, Lorca, Auriola, Elixe, Xatiba, Denia, Lucante, Cartagena, Valencia, Valeria, Segovia, Segobrica Ercabica, Wadilhijara, Secunda, Oxima, Colounia, Cauca, Balancia y otras. 3 Provincia de Merida antes Lugidania y Galicia Algarbe hasta las costas que baña el mar Britanico – contiene Merida Beja, Baracara, Dumio, Alisbona, Portocale, Tude Auria, Luco, Astorica, Samora, Iria, He ordered the military roads to be restored from Andalucia to Tolaitola [Toledo], Merida, Alisbona [Lisbon], Asturica [Astorga], Saracusta [Zaragoza] and Tarracona [Tarragona]. He repaired the demolished [Conde: 'derribados'] bridges, great mosques [etc] with a third of the produce of each province. The first province, Andalucia, formerly Beitica from the Beti, a river in Cordoba, from its source [until it enters the ocean (Conde)]. and [the river] Guadiana [i.e. the region between these two rivers (Conde)] contains Cordoba, Esbilia [Seville], Carmona, Estija [Écija], Talica [Italica] near Esbilia [Seville], the former royal home of the Eparchs of Spain, Sidonia, Arcos, Libla [Niebla], Málaga, Elbira, Jayen [Jaén], Arjona, Castolona, Alturja, Cabra, Bulcona (*Porcuna), Astaba, Ossona, and others. 2nd Province of Tolaitola [Toledo], formerly Cartagena, from the Guadaramla [i.e. Guadarrama] mountains to the mountains on the other side of the Douro, contains Tolaitola [Toledo], Ubeda, Bayeza, Mentiza, Wadiacix, Basta, Murcia, Bocastra, Mula, Lorca, Auriola, Elixe, Xatiba, Denia, Lucante, Cartagena, Valencia, Valeria, Segovia, Segobrica, Ercabica, Wadilhijara, Secunda, Ocxima, Colounia, Cauca, Balancia and others. 3rd Province of Merida, formerly Lugidania [Lusitania] and Galicia, [from] the Algarve to the coasts that bathe in the British Sea - containing Merida, Beja, Baracara, Dumio, Alisbona [Lisbon], Portocale [Porto], Tude, Auria, Luco [Lugo], Astorica [Astorga], Samora, Iria [... onto next page ...]
*Porcuna now
Vetica, ossonoba, Egitania, Colimbiria, Beseo, Lamico, Caliabria, Salamantica, Abela, Elbora, Iabora, Cauria y otros.

4ta Provincia de Saracosta antes Celtiberia, montes de Ercabica y donde nace el rio Tajo, ambos lados del Ebro hasta dentro los montes de Albortat y Albaskenzes. sus ciudades Saracusta, Tarracona, Gerunda, Barciliona, Egara, Empuria. Ausona, Urgelo. Lerida. Tortusa. Wesca. Tutila. Auca. Calahorra. Bambolona. Tarazona. Barbastar. Acoscante, Amaya. Jacca, Segia y otras.

5ta Narbona que esta en tierras de Afranc. desde la falda oriental de los montes de Albortat, como descienden las vertencias hacia el mar de Damasco, entre los montes y la costa del mar hasta el rio de la ciudad Nemauso que entra en el rio Rodano. sus ciudades Narbona, Nemauso. Macalona. Lotuba. Elena y otras.
tei:div.note: [... from previous page ...] Vetica, Ossonoba, Egitania, Colimbiria [Coimbra], Beseo, Lamico, Caliabria, Salamantica [Salamanca], Abela, Elbora, Iabora, Cauria, and others [Conde: 'otras']. 4th Province of Saracosta [Zaragoza], formerly Celtiberia, [from the] mountains of Ercabica and [i.e. to] the source of the river Tagus, on both sides of the [river] Ebro up to the Albortat [Pyrenees] and Albaskenzes [Basque] mountains. Its cities Saracusta [Zaragoza], Tarracona [Tarragona], Gerunda, Barciliona [Barcelona], Egara, Empuria, Ausona, Urgelo, Lérida, Tortusa, Wesca, Tutila, Auca, Calahorra, Bambolona, Tarazona, Barbastar, Acoscante, Amaya, Jacca, Segia and others. 5th [province] Narbona [Narbonne], which is in the lands of France. From the eastern side of the Albortat mountains [the Pyrenees], as they descend the slopes [Conde: 'vertientes'] towards the sea of Damascus [the Mediterranean], between the mountains and the sea coast to the river of the city of Nemauso [Nîmes], which enters the river Rhone. Its cities Narbona [Narbonne], Nemauso [Nîmes], Macalona, Lotuba, Elena and others. [Conde gives more cities here]
tei:div.ab: Jusuf sent his son Abderrahman called Abulaswad. with an army of horse & foot to the Afranc frontiers under Ocaili cousin of Samail general of Syria & Suleiman ben Xibeb with Egyptian Troops to keep down the rebels who presumed on the internal feuds of the Moors in Spain.
O [symbol: triangle] Soliman son of Hixem & Abderahman remaind in the Court of the new Calif Asefa who was very kind to them till Sodaif came to Court & said this

lg.l: y tal vez bajo del brazo
Que por eso al lado esta
Y da de mano al azote
Hasta que de todo el orbe
It can be fixed with the sword
Which is why it is by your side
And it gives a hand to the scourge
Because it usually does not suffice
Of the people of Beni Omeya [the Umayyads]
There will remain no trace or sign.

tei:div.ab: When the Calif heard this he ordered them both to be slain. 90 Knights of the Omeya Umayyad family had fled to the court of Abdala ben Aly – Asefah’s uncle, They were going to dinner with him when a liberto freedmanof the Beni Haxiam came into the hall with other verses Conde reproduces these verses as well, so that Abdala had them all killed on the spot. Tables were placed over them & the company eat over them still groaning: very pleasantly WG's comment - not in Conde. then dug up the dead Califs at Damascus & found Hixem intire whom he first impaled & then burned. Soliman ben Aly the other uncle of the caliph, Asefah did the same to the OmeyasUmayyads & gave them to the dogs till none remained. The verses mentioned Abdelxiamsi the original stock of Omeyas also Alhusein ancestor of Asefah, killed by Jezid & his body dragged & trampled by horses in streets. also Zaydi whose body Hixem impaled. also Ibrahim brother of Asefah who died in prison Vide verses some of them - [symbol: asterisk]See verses some of them - Linking to asterisk on pag 176, below (WG's page 27).
The Calif Meruan the last of the OmeyasUmayyads
The CaudilloLeader, Commander Nasir ben Seyar sent him advice of a rebellion thus ao 748. Excelentes the year (anno) 748. Excellent [verses - Conde's verdict]

lg.l: Yo temo que han de llegar
duerme a sueño suelto ū vela.
I fear that they have to come
Does not extinguish them in time
Will be neither mountain nor forest
But people, who lose their lives
I said, watching such a vision
Oh - who at a lesser distance

tei:div.ab: 1o Verses

Merwan lost 30,000 men in battle & the rest were drowned in the Forat (Euphrates), Meruan fled & again fled thro Egipt Saleh took him & sent his head to the new Calif Asefah who occupied the palace of the Califs in Cufa.
arrancado su lengua para embalsamarla una fuina la arrebató castigo divino por las impiedades que Meruan solia decir.
Asi Saleh referia en su carta y versos que escribio a su primo el nuevo Califa

lg.l: Dios te dio triunfo y victoria
Pues la arrastra y la devora

note.ab: Thus Saleh recounted in his letter and verses that he wrote to his cousin, the new Caliph

lg.l: God gave you triumph and victory
For the many blasphemies he has said
Drags it off and devours it -

tei:div.ab: 2d verses.
Ao 749 Xt
Omeyan Umayyad Califs 14
Moavia ben Abi Sofian 19 years 3m 26days

Jezid 3 years 6m. 3d Moavia ben Jezid 3 months, 4 Meruan ben Hakem. 9m 10 days. 5 Abdelmelic ben Meruan. 13y 4m. 6 el Walid son of Abdelmelic ben Meruan ben Alhakem conquered Spain built fine things in Damascus. reigned 9y.7m. 7th Suleiman ben Abdelmelic 4y 8m. 8th Omar ben Abdelaziz 2y 5m. 9th Jezid ben Abdelmelic 4y 1m. 10 Hixem ben Abdelmelic 19y 9m. his sons went to Spain persecuted by the Califas de Beni Alabas & reigned there. 11th El Walid ben Jezid ben Abdelmelic ben Meruan reigned 1 year 3m. 12 Jezid son of Walid, called el Nakis – 5m 12d. 13th Ibrahim ben Walid 4m & was deposed & died in rio Azabo when Calif Meruan lost the battle. 14 Meruan son of Muhamad ben Meruan ben Alhakem called el Giadi (Sciite)? 5y 10m 15d, killed in Egypt, Vide [symbol: triangle]See symbol above on same page

note.ab: Succession of the Moorish Kings - Years of Christ [i.e. AD]
Aben Huz. Lost the conquered crown of Seville, 1248.
Giomail ben Zeyan, who lost it 1238
Abul Walid and Abul Said Ismail died [latter] 1325
Abu Said, who died at the hands of
Abdalah el Zagal and Abdala el Zaquir brought the rule [of the kings of Granada] to an end.

tei:div.ab: nombres Arabes de esta historia
alah – Dios
alislam o islam la religion mahometana
alcoran – Leyenda – la ley de M
aljama = concejo, ayuntamiento
alcadi. Cadi – Jue de Aljama
alime – Sabio. Alfaki – Doctor
alhageb Ministro principal de Palacio Primer ministro en Cordoba.
alcayde – Caudillo Gobernador
almocri – Lector de mezquita
ain Fuente
alimam Prefecto de la oracion en la mequita
Azala oracion. Azobi del alba – Adohar del medio dia: Alasar de la tarde
almagrib al ponerse el sol. Alatema al anochecer
almimbar – Pulpito
alminar. Faro. torre de mezquita
almueden – Sacristan = muezin
alchatib Predicador
alhafit Doctrinero
almucadem Capitan – adelantero
alnahibe Capitan de Caballería
alferez – el que lleva la bandera
alfaraz. Caballero de lanza y espada
almogaraves – Campeadores – Caballeria de lanzas y ballestas
alhige – peregrinacion santa
algazazes. Batidores y espias
algara – Correria – cabalgada
aliget – Guerra Santa
algacia Conquista expedicion de guerra
alwacir. Minist. princip. de ciudad o palacio
amir, Gefe, Capitan, General, Principe
amir amumenin, Prince of the faithful
amelia Provincia gobierno de ella
alcudia alcaldia – jurisdiccion de alcalde
alcatib secretario
algarbia – parte occidental
afranc – Francia.
tei:div.note:
Arab[ic] nouns in this history [i.e. Conde's]
Alah - God Alislam or islam: the Muhammadan religion Alcoran - Legend [par excellence (Conde)] - the law of M[uhammad] Aljama = council, city council [elsewhere in this notebook, great mosque seems a more appropriate translation] Alcadi, Cadi - Judge [Conde: 'Juez'] of the Aljama Alime - Sage. Alfaki - Doctor Alhageb: principal Palace Minister, First minister in Cordoba. Alcayde - Leader, Governor Almocri - Reader at the mosque Ain: font Alimam: Prefect of prayer in the mosque [Conde: 'mezquita'] Azala: prayer. Azohbi [Conde]: at dawn - Adohar, at midday: Alasar, in the afternoon Almagrib: at sunset. Alatema: at dusk Almimbar - Pulpit Alminar. Beacon. mosque tower Almueden - Sacristan = muezzin [official who proclaims call to prayer; 'muezin' is WG's addition, not in Conde] Alchatib: Preacher Alhafit: one dealing with doctrine Almucadem: Captain - leader Alnahibe: Captain of Cavalry Alferez - he who carries the banner Alfaraz. Knight with lance and sword Almogaraves - Champions - Knights with lances and crossbows Alhige - holy pilgrimage Algazazes. Scouts and spies Algara - foray - cavalcade Aliget - Holy War Algacia: Conquest, war expedition Alwacir. principal Minister of city or palace Amir, Chief, Captain, General, Prince Amir Amumenin, Prince of the faithful Amelia: Province, its government Alcudia: mayoralty - mayor's jurisdiction Alcatib: secretary Algarbia - western part Afranc - France.

list.item: Said-Almedina = Prefecto de las ejecuciones de justicia
list.note: Copied from Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 3, p. viii.

list.item: Aldea: small place [lit. short place, i.e. village or hamlet]
Chothba, Prayer for the King [Conde has 'Oracion pública por el Rey': public prayer for the King]
Said-Almedina = Prefect of the execution of justice
Wacir - principal Minister, Governor [of a city: Conde has 'Gebernador [sic] de ciudad']
Wali - Prefect, leader, Governor [of a province: Conde has 'Gobernador de provincia']

tei:div.note: Copied from Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 2, unpaginated frontmatter.
tei:div.ab: Modern Moors by Sr. Arthur Brooke

Present Sultan of Morocco is Muley Abderahman Ben Hisham suppose Hixem of SpaniardsWG's addition. 1822 sultan, many rebellions. Succession nevr undisputed. Atlas tribes always rebel. Bigoted indolent luxurious, but not very cruel is good. Only Plunders & extorts. When he goes to Fez or MequinezMeknes the South rebels when he goes to Morocco the north rebels. Amaar basha of El Garb was cruel &c the MnMountain tribes complained. Sultan asked 100 000 dollars to remove him. The Basha offered 300i.e. 300,000 dollars to remain. But tribes rebelled & defeated the Bashas troops [symbol: therefore] Sultan deposed & plundered Basha & gives him Bastinadocaning his feet night & morning.

Muley Ishmael sported in murder carried gun or lance on purpose. Sawing in 2 eyesBrooke has 'putting out the eyes' [i.e. separate from sawing in two].. crucifying. burying alive & burning. Muley Ismael not passing a river orderd his prisoners to be all killed & with rushesBrooke has 'interwoven with rushes' to make the bridge. ???

When one killed by mistake for another he begged pardon. when one was beat & chained it was in way to fortuneBrooke has 'he was considered in the high road to preferment'. Sultan called on him in prison send him clothes & make an officer. but despoiled him after for plunder. his Son Muley Mahomet rebelled but he killed him by cutting of a hand & foot. Muley Zidan other son strangled by wives for cruelty. Muley Ishmael died at 90Brooke has 'past ninety'. had 2 000 women. who quarrelld when he orderd a black Eunuch to weed them 20 or 30 in one day. by a cord round their necks. he had 700 sons on horseback. he married his people to Guinea blacks which makes them now so dark population. his Son Sultan Muley Hamet.Summary of Sir Arthur de Capell Brooke, Sketches in Spain and Morocco, 2 vols (London, 1831), vol. 1, pp. 223-4, 227-33. Jews in Atlas. Moors tall straight commanding dark eyes white teeth black beard. In hayk like Romans.

No faith to Xtians, cruel, tyrannical. suspicious. not vicious? never speaks of his wife. in 1831 if you could believe such stories.Summary of, and reflection on, points made throughout Brooke, Sketches in Spain and Morocco.

Difficulties of dates. each arabic year comprises a part of two of our years generally. Arab year lunar 354 days & the intercalary 355. [symbol: therefore] beginning varies. Each year retroceding acia Enero 10 dias in 11Conde has 'retrocediendo cada año ácia Enero diez dias ú once.' Each year retroceding 10 or 11 days towards January.[ácia = hacia]. When the Arab year agrees with ours intercalary it recedes 12 days. [symbol: therefore] in 34 years the beginning of Arab Year runs thro’ all our months. Their lunas. Muharram, Safer, Rabié primera, Rabie 2a, Giumada 1a Giumada 2a. Regeb, Xaban, Ramazan, Xawal, DylcadaMonths of the Islamic calendar: Muharram, Safar, Rabi al-Awwal, Rabi al-Thani, Jumada al-Awwal, Jumada al-Thani, Rajab, Shaban, Ramadan, Shawwal, Dhul Qadah, Dhul Hijjah. Conde says the Arabic name for months is 'lunas'.. Dilhagia. each month from first sight of new moon ‘till 1st sight of next. never exceeds 30 days nor less than 29. so they count them alternately. But DylhagiaDhul Hijjah has always 30 in intercalary years.Notes on/near-translation of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 1, p. xix.

Chap 37 2d Vol of Conde, abt year 1145 talks of the Bab Morur [symbol: triangle]Links to symbol on pag 178 (WG's page 25) of Granada. Then a great rebellion agst. the AlmoravidesAlmoravids. Merwan ben Abdelaziz cercò Xatiba, Abu Abdala defendia bienMeruan ben Abdelaziz besieged Xatiba [Xàtiva], Abu Abdala defended well.The past tense, cercó, is WG's adaption of Conde. The spelling 'Meruan' is Conde's.. Abu Giafar Wali of Murcia came to help Meruan in siege 2d time. The Almoravide garrison forced into the AlcasabaCitadel (Alcazaba). Aben Ayadh the AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) came to help the Valencians. Then Abdala aben Gania gave up city & retired to Almeria. Then Meruan took & fortified Xatiba & went to Valencia paying well. Entered Valencia on a dromedary hermoso con preciosos vestidos y lucientes armas. rodeade de Xeques y nobles Cavy. in triumph. luna Safer 540 or 1145[Meruan ben Abdelaziz] entered Valencia on a beautiful dromedary with precious clothing and shining weapons, and surrounded [Conde: 'rodeado'] by Sheikhs and noble knights [Conde: 'caballeros'] in triumph, in the month of Safar AH 540 or 1145AD.. Lecant united. and comand by Merwan ben Abdelaziz. Abu Giafar returned to Murcia pursuing & robbing the Almoravides in their way to Almeria. In Granada rebellion continued. the Almoravides defended themselves in AlcazabaCitadel. The rebels sent to Cordova for help. The Cadii.e. qadi, a judge of Islamic law. Abul Hacen ben Adha wrote & Hamdain sent su sobrino Aly ben Omar Muhamad Adha conocido por Omilimadhis nephew, Aly ben Omar Muhamad Adha, known as Omilimad. & from Gien came Aben Gozei the AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) with troops & mil caballos de la Ajarquiaa thousand horse from the East & united to Abu Giafar of Murcia made 12 000 horse & more foot. The Almoravids frightened fled from AlcasabaCitadel (Alcazaba) at Alba & joind their friends en cercanias de Granadaon the outskirts of Granada. fell on the Rebels killed Giafar of Murcia routed all & returned to AlcazabaCitadel. The fugitive Murcians returning to their city proclaimed Amir the noble XequeSheikh Abderrahman ben Tahir, 1145 5401145AD or AH 540. Wali Almanzor & his Almoravides in Alcasaba di MalagaConde has 'Alcazaba de Málaga', the citadel of Málaga yielded the fort & Amir Abu Alhakem Ben entered. 540. The Wali Almanzor went into Murcia to his father Abu MuhMuhamad ben Alhag.
Tahir from love to family of Aben Hud named Seif-Dola Aben Hud his NaibCaptain in Murcia. Thence Abu Muhamad ben Alhag & Aben Suar & others went to Cordova
tei:div.note: Extracts from/summary of Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 2, pp. 294-7, 300.
tei:div.ab: [Symbol: triangle] Emir Handain of Cordova recdi.e. received them (Conde) well & sent su primo Alfolfoli y su sobrino Omilimadhis cousin Alfolfoli and his nephew Omilimad with horse to turn Aben Tahir out of Murcia. Tahir sent for help to to Alcayde Abu Muh’ ben AyadahGovernor (alcaide) Abu Muhamad ben Ayadh (as Conde has it) of Valencia.

He came & met Zaonun AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) of Auriola who made him Amir at Auriola of Murcia, Poor Tahir knew not of this & went with a troop & joy to meet him 1145, 540i.e. 1145AD or AH 540, at Alcazarquibir. Abu Tahir went to Dar Saguir & finding out how it was retired to his own house quietly. Many wishd Ayadh to kill him but he would not, knowing his worth, & thus was deposed Abderrahman Aben Tahir. after being Wali 50 days for his Ally.. Then people of Valencia wanted to depose Amir Meruan ben Abdelaziz. People of Lecant, Liria Gezira Xucar yand Murbiter wrote to Aben Ayadh of Murcia to come. Meruan fled to AlcazarFortress from the mob, whence he got to a friends house & thence by night over the walls, broken bones, one guide, lost way in MtsMountains. of Almeria fell into hands of Alcayde Muh’ ben MaymunGovernor (alcaide) Muhamad, who knew & sent him in chains to Abdala ben Gania, el sobrinothe nephew, who carried him about in chains.

Meruan ben Abdelaziz fled from Valencia to Colbira & then tired returned by night to Valencia where in a house where recognised again escaped fell into hands of Maymun & so to Gania el sobrinothe nephew,

At Valencia, the NaibCaptain of Aben Ayadh proclaimed Emir Abdala ben MuhdMuhamad ben Sad ben Mardanis, & placed him in AlcazarFortress. Soon after came Aben Ayadh & remained some time & then went to Murcia leaving for Naib Abu MuhMuhamad ben Sad. This mans people took Abu Giafar Ahmed ben Gubeir father of Abu Husein el Sabiothe Wise who defended the Alcazar del pueblo, y le envio en cadenas al castillo Maternisthe Fortress of the town, and sent him in chains to Maternis castle & put him in a tower. ransomed him with 3000 doblasgold coins & stole his books to his greatest grief. He went to Xatiba wher again caught by Aben Gania who kept him in a dark prison till sent to Majorca.

When Hamdain saw Seif Dola chased from Cordova he went to Gien & gaind over the AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) Aben Gozei who burned with revenge against Granada together with Hamdain. They entered Granada por Bab Morurthrough Bab Morur (the gate) the Cadii.e. qadi, a judge of Islamic law. Aben Adha came to meet there on foot. he saluted them & hospedòhosted [them]. as also his son Amad-Dola. He called for water Aben Ada brought the cup an Alima said Senor drink not que esta confeccionada. He drank not & Aben Adha ashamed to be suspected drank it all himself. He however died in the night. for en verdad estaba confeccionada con ponzoña agridulce, que parecia agua de azucar y naranja. fuese acaso u maliciosamente preparada para acabar con quien la bebiera de los Aben Hudesan Alima [possibly an alime, a sage] said My Lord [Conde has 'Sultan'], drink not for it is prepared [i.e. poisoned]. He drank not and Aben Adha ashamed to be suspected drank it all himself. He however died in the night. for in truth it was made with bittersweet poison, which resembled sugar water and orange. It was perhaps maliciously prepared to kill whoever drank it of the Aben Hudes Aben Hud would not stay in City but made a fine pavilion in gardens above for 10 days. Then pasó a la Alcazaba Alamra o de los Principes y alli hubo sangrientas battallas con los Almoravides que se defendian valerosamte contra Aben Hud y los de la ciudad, y asi cada dia morian muchos de cada partehe went to the Alamra Citadel or Citadel of the Princes [i.e. the Alhambra] and there he had bloody battles [Conde: 'batallas'] with the Almoravids who defended themselves valiantly against Aben Hud and the citizens, and so every day many died on each side.. Till on 8th day the AlmoravidesAlmoravids beat in hōrible battle the citizens & Aben Hud with immense slaughter and took wounded Amad-Dola son of Seif Dola Aben hud who died in AlcazabaCitadel that night of his wounds. The Almoravids sent him cafanadoConde has the same, 'cafanado'. The 1854 English translation gives this as 'wrapped ... in camphor': José Antonio Conde, History of the Domination of the Arabs in Spain, trans. Mrs Jonathan Foster (London: Henry G. Bohn, 1854), vol. 2, p. 436. to his father to bury in a caja de grana con franjas de oro llena de preciosas aromasa scarlet box with gold stripes, full of precious fragrances..

Aben Hud only staid one month at Granada for people were tired of the evils of war & of him, so at night he went to Gien, having in City of Granada as governor Abu Hasan ben Adha el de la copahe of the cup.WG clarifies Conde here: Abu Hasan ben Adha is of course the son of 'he of the cup', i.e. Aben Adha who had drunk the poison, because that Aben Adha had promptly died. (son of course of him.

The citizens made peace with the Almoravides of the AlcazabaCitadel of whom some went to Almunecab puerto de Elbira para estar mas dispuesto para pasar a Africa.Almunecab, the port of Elbira [i.e. Almuñécar, the port of Elvira], to be readier [Conde: 'dispuestos'] to cross to Africa.

A Certain Senanus was made licenser of Physicians by Almoctader the Emperor ao Heg 319AH 319 To him came a dignified Doctor, in a paper in his sleeve he presented gold money said he could neither read nor write but had a numerous family. Senanus said then never practise either bleeding nor cathartics nor in any malady you dont well know. That is exactly my way said the Doctor I have never used any thing but jallap & oxymel & went his way.

See, for instance, Echeverría, Paseos por Granada (1814 edn), vol. 1, pp. 210-11. (WG may be drawing on Echeverría's earlier edition here) pursued by seven hell hounds. The Tower on W.West side of Alhambra not far from water tower at South point. There are not more than 3 or 4 stories above ground. The King is said to have retired by this gate but perhaps he came out of it to meet King Ferdinand at St. Salvador near the present Passeo de Xenilwalk along the river Genil –
