A work of Avicenna written at Vadi Alhagera (copied).Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. 295:‘Arabes itaque, præter numeros Indicos, quos Europæi Arabicos vocitant, literas pro numeris adhibent ut ceteri Orientales’. The Arabs therefore, besides Indian numerals, which the Europeans call Arabic, use letters for numerals like the rest of the Orientals. Casiri is referring to Abjad numerals or hisab al-jummal (sentence arithmetic).

tei:div.ab: MUHAMED ABU ALAHMAR.

Abu Abdallah = father of Abdallah?? called also Muhamed Ibn Alahmar or Muhamed son?? Of Alahamar [symbol: therefore] Abu father & son. oh oh. Ben Alahim would be son of – – WG is learning about Arabic nomenclature, but 'abu' only means 'father of', not 'son of'. WG's joke worked when he originally (and erroneously) had 'Muhamed Abu Alahmar', which he has corrected to 'Ibn'. The joke is WG's rather than Irving's.. Abu Alahmar his name in short – founder of Alhambra born in year 1195 or year of HegiraIslamic calendar 591. of family Bena Nasar. made governor of Arjoua? ArjonaThis error, 'Arjoua' for Arjona, presumably a printing error, appears consistently in Irving's original but is corrected in The Monthly Review. Gell's correction suggests that he may have seen both texts, but most strongly that he had read Irving's original. His correction may draw on his wider knowledge of al-Andalus by 1832, rather than The Monthly Review. & Jaen – At death of Aben Hud many factions & divisions in Spain & in 1238 he became Kg. of Granada. made hospitals colleges fountains baths &c – but James the Conqueror had subdued Valencia & Ferdinand the Saint came to Andalusia & beseiged Jaen Muhamed Abu Alahmar went to him kneeled & became his Vassal – paid tribute – attended Cortes as Vassal noble & served in war with horsemen. Served Ferdinand with 500 Knights at seige of Seville. Ao The year (anno) 1248 Seville taken, Muhamed foresaw the ruin of Moslems, said “Que angoste y miserabile seria nuestra vida, sino fuera tan dilatada y capaciosa nuestra esperanza”WG declines to record the English translation given by [Irving], Alhambra, vol. 2, p. 281: 'How straightened and wretched would be our life, if our hope were not so spacious and extensive.' Irving and Monthly Review both have 'espaciosa', rather than WG's 'capaciosa'. –

He returned unhappy to Granada. People hailed him as El Ghalib – he shook his head saying Wa la ghalib ila AlaAgain, WG declines to include the translation offered by [Irving], Alhambra, vol. 2, p. 281: 'There is no conqueror but God'. Then he took this motto. He used to say “Arm thy self in peace clothe thyself in summer” aware that his peace with XtiansChristians could not last long. Encouraged arts, planted. Silk. gardens gold mines – other metals. made gold money with his own name. Begun Alhambra after 1248Irving has 'towards the middle of the thirteenth century'.. His dress plain. Went seldom to his harem. Made his wifes live in friendship. Made Alhambra gardens with flowers & delighted in them. Read histories. taught his 3 sons. –

Ferdinand died at Sevilla in 1254. Abu Alahmar sent 100 Knights to funeral to Kg Alonzo Xth. who each carried a taper – He sent these every year on anniversary. Went himself to battle in his 79th year to resist an invasion. The AlcaydeGovernor (alcaide) going out broke his lance against gate – bad omen – King taken ill & nearly fell. Don Philip, brother

to King Alonzo X was with himi.e. when he died.. put in silver coffin embalmed and buried in a marble sepulchre in Alhambra. His treasury always full though he spent much whence people said he dealt in magic.Paraphrasing/summary of [Irving], Alhambra, vol. 2, pp. 269-83. There is almost nothing that is not also in The Monthly Review, 2:2 (1832), pp. 221-47, at pp. 243-6, but the error 'Arjoua' and the note on Yusef Abul Hagig, who does not appear in the review, both suggest WG had actually read Irving's book. His name often repeated in the inscripts of Alhambra –i.e. inscriptions. This observation is WG's, not appearing in Irving or the Monthly Review.

Yusef Abul Hagig finished the building & ornaments of Alhambra. King in 1333.[Irving], Alhambra, vol. 2, pp. 287-95. This is not mentioned in the Monthly Review article, so is more evidence that WG had actually read Irving's book.

Cathedral & AlcazarFortress of Granada 1529 Diego de Siloe architect with Covarrubias?Probably drawing on Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias, vol. 1, p. 198, though he draws comparisons with Covarrubias rather than suggesting that he and Siloe worked together.

tei:div.ab: Huat idris – I think is Apes hill. Vateres. Guadres marmol Afric. The best soldiers of Kg of Granada came thence. They had a guard of 500 who lived in the Calle de los Gomeles. Bula lul the Orlando of the Moorish songs came hence, Killed in plain of Tolosa in hegira 609 or 1231.From Antoine Augustin Bruzen de La Martinière, Le grand dictionnaire géographique et critique, 9 vols (The Hague, Amsterdam and Rotterdam, 1726-39), vol. 4, p. 196.Various works make similar points, but the spellings, citation of Mármol and order of the observations point only to La Martinière. 'I think is Apes hill' is WG's addition, and he has changed La Martinière's 'Gomeres' to 'Gomeles'. The present-day street is Cuesta de Gomérez. The date is AH 609 or 1231AD.

Codex literis Cuphicis exoratus Marochi Heg 944 but the author abu Baker Asemo Alcaisi. Granatae Cancellarius. born in ao Heg 760. died 829. Munus Judicibus oblatum.Codex written [Casiri has ‘exaratus’] in kufic letters [litteris] in Morocco, AH 944 but the author Abu Baker Asemo Alcaisi. Chancellor of Granada. Born in AH 760. Died 829. A gift offered to judges.
Theatrum JudicumTheatre of Judges by Mohamad Ben Abraham Ben Farhun a Lawyer of Granada ao Hegirae 811.AH 811
Several books on Matrimony.
Amantium CertaminaLovers’ Struggles by Ahmad Ben Abrahim Ben Mohamad a Syrian who lived at Granada ao Hegirae 812.AH 812
Codex lit Cuph exaratus Granatae
Averrois tractatus de SacrificiisCodex written in kufic letters at Granada Averroes’s treatise on Sacrifices or Animals for Sacrifice or Victuals according to MahomnMahometan (i.e. Islamic) law.
tei:div.note: From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. 457-66.
tei:div.ab: In a Toletan MS of Galen is a note Dno Moyse Susani filio with his friend Joanne Moysis filio Ben Feris. read this work 25 Novr aerae Sapharensis id est Hispanae 1422. Xti 1384 idque in urbe Toleto quam deus servet incolumem. A Jew & Xtian Physician of Toledo. Also there notes Xtiani duce Rege Ferrando urbem Jaen recuperarunt die 4 Martis ao Xt 1245. Hispalim 26 Aprilis 1248. Tharifam 21 Sept ao 1340. 1257 Nieblam.
Alphonsus Rex astronomus ob Heg 683 1284 of Xt.
Sanchus obiit Toleti 26 April. 1295 Xt.
obiit Rex Ferrandus in Jaen 7 Sept 1310.
Obt ejus filius Rex Alphonsus in monte expugnationis id est Gibelthar 26 Martii. Xt 1350
Ejus filius Rex Petrus 1368
Rex Henricus 1379
Rex Johannes equo prolapsus ao 1390
Rex Henricus obt Toleti 20 decr. 1432

Regina Catharina obt in Valladolid in Arabic Baladualid بلد الوليدValladolid Arabic not present on p. 248 of Casiri. WG has taken it from elsewhere. id est urbs principis Mauritani Valid ao 1418From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 248. In a Toletan Manuscript of Galen is a note: Lord Moses, son of Susanus, with his friend Joannes Moses, son of Ben Ferus, read this work 25 November 1422 in the period of Safar [second month of the Islamic calendar], that is of Spain. 1384AD. And that in the city of Toledo, which may God keep safe. A Jew and Christian Physician of Toledo. Also there notes the Christians, led by King Fernando, retook the city of Jaen on 4 March 1245AD [Casiri has 1243]. Seville, 26 April 1248. Tarifa 21 September 1340. Niebla, 1257. King Alfonso the astronomer died AH 683, 1284AD. Sancho died at Toledo, 26 April 1295AD. King Fernando died at Jaen, 7 September 1310. His son, King Alfonso, died at the mountain of storms, that is, Gibraltar, 26 March 1350AD His son, King Pedro, 1368 King Enrique, 1379 King Juan fell off his horse in the year 1390 King Enrique died at Toledo, 20 December 1432 Queen Catalina [Catherine of Lancaster] died at Valladolid, in Arabic Baladualid, that is the city of the Moorish leader Valid, in the year 1418 – all notes in this book – p248i.e. Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 248.
Corans without number p486Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 486, though the books there are actually commentaries on the Quran.

Explanation of MahomMahometan faith by Abu Abdallah Mohamad ben Joseph Abderita for Abi Abdalla Mohammad King of Granada who was of the Nasserites & died Hegirae 733AH 733From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 526.
tei:div.note: بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم In the name of God (Allah) the most gracious and merciful
tei:div.ab: Codex – Comment on Khalil ben Isaac great Lawyer by Scharapheddin Althakhikhi Lawyer of Granada.
Same epitomized by Abdelrahman Alagehuri of Granada.
Same in 8 Vols by Nassereddin Alzarcani of Granada.
Abdallah Ben Mohamad Ben Zakri Heg 838AH 838 Lawyer of Granada.
Admonitions to Judges &c Heg 896AH 896 by Abu Abdallah Mohamad Ben Abdalla vulgo Almoknasicommonly called Almoknasi chief judge of Granada.
Of Cordova Abu Othman Sada Ben Abi Giaphar Ahmad Ben Leon Altagibi Law,
tei:div.note: أبو عثمان سعد بن احمد بن ليون التجيبيAbu Othman Saad bin Ahmed bin Leon Al-Tajibi [writer, b. AH681, 1282AD, from Almería]
tei:div.ab: Copy of Codex Cuph in urbe Guadix Heg 820 de Jurisprudentie carmen – Auctor Abu Giaphar Mohamad of Granada 790 Heg.Copy of Kufic Codex in the City of Guadix, AH 820, Poem on Jurisprudence – Author Abu Giaphar Mohamad of Granada, AH 790.

Book of Kings Tributes & Rents of Cordova Heg 677 Xti 1278AH 677 or 1278AD, by Abu Giaphar Ben Nasser Alravadi of Cordova. Orders that XtiansChristians when conquered by Mahometans may have lauds & Churches
Even books from Bokharai.e. Bukhara, in present-day Uzbekistan in Spain.
Abdelrahman Alagehuri of Granada Civil law,
Poem on Logic & Algebra by a Cordovan Author with Comment by Ben Ali ben David Almosarati of Granada 7th century Heg7th century AH.
Book of Both Laws or Pandects.

Book to confute the Mahometan methodistsWG's interpretation. Casiri (vol. 1, p. 483) has 'severiores Alcorani sectatores' (strict followers of the Quran). who would not allow of music &c well confuted.
tei:div.note: From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. 466-77, 483.
tei:div.ab: Codex Arabico Latinus Alcorani confutatio. Auctor P. Dominicus Germanus de Silesia.Arabic-Latin Codex Refutation of the Quran. Author Father Dominicus Germanus of Silesia.
Epistles of S Paul St John S Jude &c &c &c
Codex Arab. Codex. Sacrorum Canonum collectio ad Usum Hispana-Ecclesiae.Arabic Codex. Codex. Collection of Sacred Canons for the Use of the Spanish Church.
Codex Heg 692AH 692 of Dr Ali Ben Hassan Alhossain of Granada Lexicon TheologicumLexicon of Theology.
Heg 752AH 752 Epitome of Theological Dogmas by Abdelrahman Ben Mohamad ebn Khaldun Alhadrami of Granada
Synopsis TheologicaTheological Synopsis of Abulabbas Ahmad Ben Mohamad vulgo Ebn Albannacommonly called Ebn Albanna of Granada.
Scholastic Theology de Actibus humanisOn Human Actions by Ebn AltalmansaniCasiri has 'Altalmasani' of Granada
Mahomet Alkobari of Granada wrote Unitatis & fideiKnowledge of Unity and Faith scientia comments on Heg 954AH 954.
Poem explaining Alcoran by Ebn Haian of Granada Heg 792AH 792
on the Coran – The shining Star by Abu Mohan’i.e. Mohamad Abdalla Ben Alvaschi of Toledo but at Granada ob Heg 487died (obiit) AH 487
many others –
Heg 652AH 652 Ebn Alkathib of Granada Oceani Rivus on the AlcoranRiver of the Ocean (on the Quran)
Abdalla Ben Moh’ ben Zakri Granada Heg 838 wrote Curiosi Viri desiderium.Abdalla Ben Mohamad ben Zakri [of] Granada AH 838 wrote The Curious Man’s Desire.

The library had 600 000 volumes. 44 of catalogue 300 writers & more. 70 public libraries in Andalusia. 3d Caliph had 12 045 000 dinars or 6 millions of £ per anmper annum (yearly). Cordova had 640 mosques. 900 baths 200 000 houses. Banks of Guadalquivir had 12000 Villages.
Saraglio had 6,300 persons. had a guard of 12 000 horse.
tei:div.note:
From Brewster (ed.), Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, vol. 18, p. 281.
The Encyclopaedia quotes Gibbon, Decline and Fall, vol. 5, chapter LI: Conquests by the Arabs, Part VII, and chapter LII: More Conquests by the Arabs, parts I and III.
'640 mosques' confirms that WG was reading the Encyclopaedia, as Gibbon gives 600.
tei:div.ab: دار الخلافةThe House of the Caliphate Dar el Kalifat the Kalifs Palace – dar is door portedoor (French), dar demeureresidence (French).
Almogares = soldados viejosold soldiers in Castle garrisons. Elite.
[Arabic] Talayha = piquet or adorned post.
طلاعة المسلمين Usually refers to the vanguard or most powerful troop - soldiers or Muslims pickets of Muslemin
القائد CommanderThough Gell has written القايد Alcayde = commander of 10 men.
[Arabic] = Calatrava – rabia rabat رباط رباه رباط Battle cries, the second asking God for the power to keep fighting.
rab rabat towers of sentinels, round towers,
القنطرهthe arch Alcantara from bridge. 2 Spanish orders with arab names. Fontarabia from [Arabic]
Almogavares from غارraid gar = pillage.

Almogavares of Granada = peons labradores y hombres del Campo. 3 Knights with 2 of these in Las antiguidades de la ciuidas de España 1775 mentions these as distinguished'labradores y hombres del Campo': peasant farmers and country men.
[Ambrosio de Morales], Las antiguedades de las ciudades de España (Alcalá de Henares, 1575), fo. 127v (foliated, not paginated). [The antiquities of the cities of Spain; not 1775]
Morales does not reproduce Arabic script, though, so cannot be source for what comes before. In fact, WG likely to be reading about Morales through another source, perhaps with same error on publication date.
Adalides Or champions, military leadersالدليلguides = guides. Almocadems المقدمchief chief. in armies. King only named these.
An Adalid had a dress, a sword, a horse & 2 armours. a rich man girded on his sword & he was hoisted on his shield. He drew his sword & turning defied the enemies of his King.
Thus an Adalid was a Knight or like one.

A KtKnight or Rico ombreNobleman (the common Spanish term; literally, 'rich man') had coat of arms & a Banner. If an Adalid was taken by Enemy the state ransomed them & had them cruelly killed. yet the honour sought by Knights.
vid p38 history earlyWG's page 38 of this notebook (pag 167): brief history of the Goths in Spain.

From Brewster (ed.), Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, vol. 18, pp. 280-1.
WG has replaced 'ph' with 'f' in the Spanish names.
tei:div.ab: Verses by Valadata Daughter of Mohamad Almostakfi Billah of Cordova to her lover AbansiCasiri has 'Abdusius' – a noble Moor.
from Arabic in Escurial.

lg.l: “My presence wounds your heart, yet not less true
“My cheeks in blushes speak my love for you
“Yet mutual wounds not equal shame impart
“By all my cheek is seen but not your heart.
lg.note: WG's translation is quite far from the Latin given by Casiri (vol. 1, p. 106), so is indeed likely based on the Arabic original in Casiri's footnote b.

tei:div.note: From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 106.
tei:div.ab: King Don Hernando took Ronda in 485 هجريHijri, the Islamic calendarThough Gell has (by missing a letter) actually written the verb:هجر flee before 1486.

In Marmol – prophecy in inquisition of Granada .p182. that Turks will take Rome with armies & the Moors will take the Isla de España, y Malaga se tornara a labrar y edificarthe Moors will take the Island of Spain, and Málaga will return to working and building. At Velez & Almuñecar will be quell’d the pride of the heresy of Cordova which keeps it in its vices & sins. A Comet the sign of this.

Recibo de ti mi dios lo que me has ordenadoMármol has ‘Recibo de tí, mi Dios, lo que me has ordenado’: I receive from you, my God, what you have ordered for me.. Çidi el Guerguali a MorabiteMármol has 'Cidi' (no cedilla). A marabout, a Muslim holy man or hermit..

Prophecy of Tauca alMármol has 'el' Hamema or Doves breast. Succour to Islam when year begins with Saturday & a cloud of birds come among which 2 are Gabriel & MiguelThe archangels Gabriel and Michael – then all world moslemMármol has 'volverá todo el mundo á la ley de los Moros': all the world will come under the law of the Moors. –

In inquisition of Granada & in cave of Castares in Alpuxárra. Translated by Alonzo del Castillo Interpreter of Office. but he says the Arabic is so equivocal that a long or short vowell makes all the difference. “The generation of those who adore one only God shall possess Gibraltar for it was their origin & entry & to them shall return in 10th succession. y que dios revelo no falto ni faltarà.Mármol has 'Y lo que Dios reveló, no faltó, ni faltará': And what God revealed was not lacking, nor will it be lacking.

Convertios a dios y no os durmais que amanecerais sepultados entre las peñas.Mármol has 'convertios á Dios, y no os durmais, que amanecereis sepultados entre las penas': turn to God, and do not sleep, lest you wake buried among miseries.

The [drawing: crescent moon] shall descend into the garden of Tuhema after the [drawing: full moon] shall have risen split & prophets shall appear. Then shall a King son of a faultless King with Troops take Alhambra & thence many provinces & climes. Then shall be glory to the Moors. He takes Seville & at the first sally Antequera climbing its walls & by force of arms rompiendolosbreaking them. 7 years this victory endures & riches taken from Heretics. Dolarfe King of the Xtians Christians . A Brutal old Antichrist will sow at midday & reap at vespers
He Plants trees with right & plucks fruits with left hand – Sins were before as heavy as mountains.
tei:div.note: From Luis del Mármol Carvajal, Historia del rebelion y castigo de los moriscos del reyno de Granada, 2 vols (Madrid, 1797), vol. 1, pp. 178, 181-4, 190-5. WG's page reference is to the 1797 second edition, rather than to Mármol's original work of 1600.
tei:div.ab: Visir y Hagel del Palacio mayordomo mayor.Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias, vol. 1, p. 243: 'la inspeccion de la obra estuvo al cuidado de su Visir y Hagel del palacio, ó mayordomo mayor': the inspection of the work was in the care of his Vizier and Hagel of the palace, or head steward.
MOORISH TERMS IN SPAIN. Por D. Eugenio Llaguno y Amirola y D. Juan Cean Bermudez.

list.item: Alhambra = dar alamra = casa real. Rey AlhamarLlaguno y Amírola (Noticias, vol. 1, pp. 246-7) is more tentative than it would appear here on etymology, with some saying the name comes from Rey [King] Alhamar, who ordered it built, and others that it is from 'dar-alamra', meaning 'casa real' [royal house].
Almaceria = maceriaLlaguno y Amírola has 'huerta cercada para siembra': fenced garden for planting. This is not far from the Italian 'maceria', a dry stone wall, which must be what WG is using.

Anaquel = shelves?WG is correct. Llaguno y Amírola has 'division en los armarios ó estantes para poner libros, platos ú otras cosas. Tambien significa el armario ó estante.' Division in cabinets or bookcases on which to put books, plates or other things. It also means the cabinet or bookcase.
Axaraca eastern ornamts. lazos.eastern ornaments. bows or loops.

Aximez [drawing: window] windowWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'ventana de dos ó tres arcos con tres ó cinco columnitas, como las que hay en los edificios árabes y góticos.' Window with two or tree arches, with three or five little columns, like those found in Arab and Gothic buildings.
Azogue place of market at Segovia
AzulejosWG clearly does not need Llaguno y Amírola's lengthy definition of these tiles.
Borje torre metido en un CastilloLlaguno y Amírola has 'metida': tower placed within a Castle
Cenefa a border. Rambla = arenalsandy terrain
Maxaraque: solanaterrace or gallery facing the sun to East
Xarahiz = [drawing: circle] wallWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'pared de piedra en obra circular.' Stone wall in circular form.
Zocodover zoco-dober plaza detrasLlaguno y Amírola has 'Zocodober': square behind as at Toledo behind AlcazarFortress
Aduana = casa de colecioncollections [i.e. customs] house

Aduar a [drawing: circle] r populationWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'poblacion movible de los árabes. Casas, plural de dar, que significa casa, é indica que eran de forma orbicular, redondas dentro y fuera.' Movable town of the Arabs. Houses, plural of dar, which means house, and indicates that they were ring-shaped, round inside and outside.
Alamud cerrojo o pasador en ventanas palo principal del pabellon.bolt or latch on windows, main pole of a pavilion
Alarife. Sage mechanist. Gene el Arif = garden del maestro Jucef Nazar.of the master [architect] Jucef Nazar [i.e. the origin of the name of the Generalife, Granada]
AlbanarLlaguno y Amírola: 'Albañal' or 'Albañar' = conduits Almohadas. piedras de silleria resaltadas en los edificios.ashlar stones, sticking out of buildings
Alberga = estanque. DovetowerLlaguno y Amírola has 'Alberca': pond (estanque). 'Dovetower' is WG's translation of Llaguno y Amírola's definition of the next word in his list, 'Albergue'.

Albuhaire laguna also arches with azulejosLlaguno y Amírola: or 'Alboaire': lagoon. 'arches with azulejos' is WG's translation of Llaguno y Amírola's definition of the next word in his list, 'Albohaire'.
AlcolbaLlaguno y Amírola has 'Alcolea' little castle

Alfarge artesonado de los Techos. El pie de Piedra o ladrillo sobre que se coloca una cama &c y la misma cama coffered ceiling. The stone or brick base on which a bed etc is placed and the bed itself.Vide Queens bath AlhambraSee Queen's bath, Alhambra. This is WG's addition.

tei:div.note: Selected from longer list in Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, pp. 243-51. Some of WG's definitions are in Llaguno y Amírola's Spanish, others are translated into English or Italian and many are WG's own summaries of Llaguno y Amírola's longer definitions.

9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 measured ruler
A Vara is 3 feet each foot is 10 inches & 7/8ths English qu??WG is unsure but roughly correct, as the Spanish vara was set at 32.91 inches in 1801.

Blank
Blank
tei:div.ab: Spanish Romances. most ancient are of 13 century – the last of the 15thWG's error. The original French says 'la fin du seizième siècle', the end of the 16th century..
some really translated from Arabic. written in reigns of Aben Hassan. Muley Abdallah & Boabdil. Romances of Rodriguez later.
But those of Rodrigo the oldest.
Bernardo del Carpio son of Sancho Diaz Ct Count of Saldaña & a Dauri.e. a Daughter, WG's error. The original French says 'une soeur', a sister. of Alphonso the chaste.
Fernan Gonzales Ct of Castille.
Adarga a round shield. Azagaya a javelin
El Marabeth. Morabeth a Tribe of Zahara.
Alcala Castle or Citadel.
Mudexares = tributaries?i.e. mudéjares. From the Arabic for subjugated, tamed or domesticated; and, by extension in Spanish, those Muslims who remained in Iberia after the Reconquista.
Alcayceria the bazar.

“Cries resound in the Towers of the Alhambra & through the City of Granada in all parts. For without reason the King has beheaded in one day 36 abencerrages nobles of great valour. Accused by the Zegries & Gomeles of treason. All the Dames weep all that are in Granada. From the windows & open galleries are shewn mourning draperies..”WG's translation from the Bibliothèque universelle's French, p. 258: ‘Dans les tours de l’Alhambra de grands cris retentissent; dans la cité de Grenade des gémissemens résonnent de toutes parts; ‘Car sans aucun motif, le roi a fait décapiter en un seul jour trente six Abencerrages, nobles de grand bravoure ... que les Zégris et les Goméles accusoient de trahison … ‘Toutes les dames les pleuroient, toutes celles que renferme Grenade; des fenêtres et des façades des maisons tombent des draperies de deuil.’
Alhama taken by Don Rodrigo Ponce de Leon in 1483.
Rioverde under Rondai.e. the Río Verde river
Sierra bermeja between Malaga & Gibraltar.
Fernando Perez de PulgarHernán Pérez del Pulgar (1451-1531) wrote avemaria on mosque door.
tei:div.note: From ‘Sur les romances espagnols’, Bibliothèque universelle des sciences, belles-lettres, et arts, vol. 46 (1831), pp. 225-62, at pp. 227-8, 231, 233, 248, 251, 258, 260-1.
tei:div.ab: De Rasis. Hist History from Arabic translated into Spanish ergo true historyWG's addition. tum notabilia quaedam inde excerpta & diligenter examinata.From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. xxiii. By Rasis. History from Arabic translated into Spanish therefore true history. Then some noteworthy things extracted from it and carefully examined.

Pedro de Lara aothe year (anno) 1611 near Salè took 2 ships of Zidan Kg of Morocco. took 3000 MSSManuscripts. King offered 70 000 Ducats for ransom. Kg of Spain answered he would have the release of all the XtianChristian Slaves. The Kg Zeidan would have given them but having war with un Morabito y con su sobrino Muley Xequea Marabout Muslim holy man or hermit and his brother, Sheikh Muley could not, so the books went to the Escurial. Vida y hechos del Rey D. Phelipe III. by Gonzales DavilaCasiri cites a 17th-century manuscript history of the life and deeds of King Don Philip III by [Gil] González Dávila, kept in the Royal Library at Madrid.. Many burnt June 7 1671.WG's translation of Spanish and Latin from Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. iv-v. Casiri gives most of this text in Spanish in a footnote, but additional comments from the main text are in Latin. Joseph [Giuseppe] Baretti, A Journey from London to Genoa, through England, Portugal, Spain, and France, 3rd edn, 4 vols (London, 1770), vol. 3, pp. 82-4 gives the Spanish with an English translation, citing Casiri. WG was drawing directly on Casiri, though: not only does he leave untranslated Spanish, but he also dates the Escorial fire precisely, as only Casiri does, and avoids Baretti's error of 1761.
Ualadata daughter of Kg Mohamad Almostakphi Billa Kg of Spain Poesies in quantity.

De Urbe Ramla or RamaOn the City of Ramla by Ebn AlkalifeThis is not in Casiri. It is possible WG has misunderstood Casiri's attributions and written 'Ebn Alkalife' in error because Casiri attributes an earlier work to Ebn Alkhathib., who gives history also of Samarcand &c. also of the Bibliotheca of Porphyrius.Library of Porphyry [of Tyre]
Dioscorides. Hippocrates. Galen. Plato. Euclid. Ptolemy. Zoroaster. of the city Tadmir.
On Cannon & Nitrati pulveris potassium nitrate powder [i.e. gunpowder]& the ancient use of paper by the Arabs. Nubian Geographer.
De Nominis Andalusia etymo Etymology of the name Andalusia–
Many of these were in library – Royal at Granada but taken at the fall to Morocco.

note.bibl: From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. xix-xxiii.

tei:div.ab: Persians Shiites Ottomans Sunites. At Bagdad & Ispahan the two sects fought. Sultan Selim killed 40000 Shiites Contemporary of Henry VIII of England. Francis I of france Leo the X. Charles Vth. Andrea Gritti of Venice Doge Wassili Ivanovitch conqueror of Astrachan founder of Russian greatness
2d Century Omar Ben Abdolaziz the most just sovereign of family of Ommiai.e. the Umayyad dynasty

Prince Dschem Brother of Sultan Bajazet. who said “there is no blood between Kings” – the custom being to kill all the younger Sons. Dschem fled to Rhodes where the Knights entertained him. They were bought by the Sultan who paid 40 000Quarterly Review has 45,000 Ducats a year to them to keep him. He got to Nice. then to Chamberry then to Rousillon. Then by Rhone to Puy. Here the Kts Knights took away & sent back to Rhodes 29 of his attendants. Bajazet offered the right hand of St John to deliver him up. The prince transferred from Castle to Castle. All European Kings tried to deliver him. & the Pope tried. The grand master put him in a tower with seven floors. Cellar Kitchen Servants 3, 4 & 5 rooms & bed of Prince 6 & 7th for Knights on guard. Charles VIII of france got him sent to the Pope in 7th year of captivity. he embarked at Toulon for Civita Vecchia & lived at the Vatican. Charles VIII took him & Pope in Cast St Angelo the Castel Sant'Angelo, Rome but poisend by the pope & got in dying state to Naples. his body sent to Egypt but went to Brusa & buried in Tomb of Amurath 2d.

In reigns of Soliman & Salim best time of Turks the greatest commanders by land & Sea were apostates from Xtianity Christianity . HammerJoseph von Hammer, Geschichte des Osmanischen Reiches. gives 8 out of 10 grand Visiers of this epoch.
Wlad & Drakul princes of Wallachia & Bosnia such murderers as surprized even the Turks.

But Selim 2d contemporary with Charles IX & Ivan the Cruel, St Bartholomews massacre at same time. Fort of Wittenstein in Finland taken garrison cut in pieces Commander spitted on a lance & roasted alive. This at time that Bragadino governor of Famagusta in Cyprus flayed alive by Selim the drunkard who being drunk slipped getting into a bath & got a fever & died.

Chaireddin BeglerbegQuarterly Review has 'Begler Beg' [i.e. Beylerbey, Lord of Lords] of Algiers carried off 70 000 of the persecuted moorsQuarterly Review has 'Morescoes' from Spain to Africa. This Chaireddin tried to carry off from Fondi the great beauty Julia Gonzaga wife of Vespasiano Colonna Sister of the “divine” Joanna of Arragon painted by Raffaelle. She was to have been carried to harem of Turkish Sultan. The sailors of Barbarossa disembarked & She scarce escaped nearly naked behind a horseman whom She afterwards stilettoed. because “he had dared or seen too much”. In Solymans time, The turks played the devil in Fondi for 4 hours & particularly insulted the Virgin mary.

Hayreddin or Barbarossas own commentaries give all thisGell drafted a novel about the sixteenth-century Ottoman pirate, Hayreddin Barbarossa, about the same time as he was working on these notes: American School of Classical Studies at Athens, Gennadius Library, MSS 70.3: Sir William Gell, An authentic narrative of the History of Jacub of Jenigawarder and his son, Ariadeno Barbarossa, of the island of Mitylene, in the Aegean Sea, [19th century]. He was of Greek descent a Roumelian Sipahi who settled in Mitylene at its conquest by Mahomet 2d. His father had 4 sons the first a Lesbian merchant the 3 others Pirates. Elias the youngest killed against Rhodians Urudsch or Horuc & Chisr or Chaireddin Pirates. They took a rich french Ship sent it to Sultan & had in return 2 caftans of honour & 2 gallies. They seized two African towns Budscha & Dscherdshill but fought for Algiers against Spain, Then the elder brother Isaac joined Them but he was killed by Spaniards storming Kalaatol Kalaat or the Castle of Castles. Kalaatol. Usdruch Quarterly Review has 'Urudsch'killed at capture of Telmessan but Chaireddin was Beglerbeg of Algiers. Sultan Selim sent him a scimitar a horse & a sandschak or investiture. Subdued for Sultan the native princes of Tennes & Telmessan.
tei:div.note: Extracted/summarised (with same spellings, order etc) from review of Joseph von Hammer, Geschichte des Osmanischen Reiches, vols 1-8 (Pest, 1827-32), in The Quarterly Review, vol. 49, no. 98 (Jul 1833), pp. 283-322, at pp. 288, 299-303, 306-7, 309-15.
tei:div.ab: Kenz al mactoum = hidden Treasure.
Esm al aadem = the great name = اللهAllah (God)Herbelot does not include Arabic, which must be WG's addition.

Motassem 8th Abasside Kalif first used Allahi.e. Motassem, the eighth Abbasid caliph, was the first to add the name of God to his own. Billah = of God. Alallah by God, Lellah, Bemrillah &c by order of God, as EuropansWG's meaning here is unclear and is not apparent from Herbelot..
99 true names with Allah 100.
401 Paradise open to those who call often one of the 100 true names. whence 100 beads in Chaplets.
399 fatal year 613 HegAH 613 to Moslems. Franks Took Damietta, Moguls & Genghizkhani.e. Mongols and Genghis Khan Persia ao in the year[s] (anno) 1216 & 17.
Moslems think Issai.e. Jesus on 2d advent will make whole world Moslem ie unite Xtians Christians
All held Moslem who antebefore Mahomet held the unity of God.
tei:div.note: Extracted from Barthélemy d'Herbelot, Bibliothèque orientale... (Maastricht, 1776), pp. 303-4. WG may be using another of many editions since 1697. 399 and 401 are probably page references, so would identify the precise edition used by WG.
tei:div.ab: Tetekellem bel lisan el araby
tei:div.note: تتكلم بالسان العربي

From Claude Etienne Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe vulgaire et littérale (Paris, 1813), pp. 210-11, which has French, Latin and Arabic. Savary renders the phrase, alongside the same Arabic text, as 'tetekellem bêl-liçân êl-a’raby': 'Parlez-vous arabe?' [Do you speak Arabic?]
tei:div.ab: بي the dot for Bs often under بي
[Arabic] deus liberalis [Arabic] alla akram
than is [Arabic] men as [Arabic] The elephant greater than lion?
elfil acbar men alsabah the lion.
[Arabic] magnus [Arabic] major [Arabic] excellens
[Arabic] -tior. [Arabic]
tei:div.note: From Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 253-4 n. Savary gives the passage in both French and Latin, with WG choosing to use the latter. Savary renders the phrases, alongside the same Arabic text, as:الله كريم 'Allah kerim, Deus est liberalis' [God is generous]الله اكرم 'Allah acram, Deus est liberalior' [God is more generous]الفيل اكبر من السبع 'elfil acbar men elsabah, elephas est major leone' [the elephant is greater than the lion - WG is correct]كبير 'kebir, magnus' [great]اكبر 'akbar, major' [greater]فاضل 'fadel, excellens' [excellent]افضل 'afdal, excellentior' [more excellent]كثير 'ketir, multum' [many]اكثر 'actar, plus' [more]

list.note: Arabic numbers 1-11 From Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 255-6. For 'wahat', Savary has 'ahed' or 'ouahed'. For 'wahed achar', he has 'ahed achar'.

Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 257, gives these phrases as:
'ahed achar beit, onze maisons' [eleven houses]
'tessa-t-achar rageol, dix-neuf hommes' [nineteen men]

Quicumque me amabit hunc amabo = men iehobbeni ahobbo. [Arabic]
what you wish I wish = ma terid arid.
haïtma terouh arouh –
sabah el kheir
sabakoum bil keir. tu.
masa el kheir
entoum thaiiebin quom’ vales
thaiieb el hamd-lil-lah.
selam aleik
aleik es. Selam
marhabak. welcome.
rouh ma es selame. vade in pace.

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 308, 315-18, 323.

list.item: ‘Transivit per hortum imperatoris, marrat belboustan essoultan’ [she went through the sultan’s garden]
‘Quicumque me amabit, hunc amabo, men iéhobbéni ahobbo’ [whoever will love me, I will love him]
‘Quidquid volueris, illud placitum habebo, ma térid arid’ [what you wish, I wish]
‘Quocumque ibis, ibo, haïtma térouh arouh’ [wherever you will go, I will go]
‘Vobisne prosperè cedit? entoum thaïiébin’ [are you well? WG has confused this and the previous line]
‘Rectè, Deo volente, thaïiéb el-hamd lil-lah’ [well, thank God]
‘Felix tibi sit adventus, marhabak, marhaba bak’ [welcome]
‘Vade in pace, rouh mâ es-sélamé’ [go in peace]
‘Aleïkoum es-sélam ou rahmet allah ou barakato’ [from dialogue: Greetings. May God give you his mercy and his blessings.]
‘Eich halkoum maoulana’ [from dialogue: How are you, master?]

figure.note: Inside back cover with full-length portrait and Arabic

Probably of Abu Abdallah Muhammad XII (c. 1460-1533) of Granada. The caption below: الله عبد Abdullah. And below that, on the pink border: Praise be to God (Allah), lord of worlds. [The identification of Muhammad XII is helped by the Nasrid shields in the background and the fact that the figure is shown with a bird perched on his right hand, as in the identifiable image on pag 202.] The shields carry the Nasrid motto: ولا غالب الا اللهAnd there is no greater conqueror than God
Back cover with shield and Arabic

Shield of the Nasrid rulers of Granada, with 'Granada' written underneath. ولا غالب الا الله And there is no greater conqueror than God غرناطه Granada Though the text actually readsغرلناطه A spelling error

figure.note: Pencil, pen and ink drawing: gateWith a few small changes, WG has here copied David Roberts's illustration in Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835), pp. 72-3: 'The Gate of Justice; Entrance to the Alhambra'.
figure.label: Bab el Adeli.e. Puerta de la Justicia (Gate of Justice), Alhambra, Granada. 'Bab el Adel' does not appear in any of the sources WG is drawing on in these pages, so it may be his own translation of 'Gate of Justice' into Arabic.
figure.ab: Five fingers allude to 5 precepts. Faith. Prayer. Alms. Fasting Pilgrimage.Probably summarising Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835), p. 73. WG draws on Roscoe several more times in the following pages.

figure.note: Pencil drawing: gateWG has here copied part of David Roberts's illustration in Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835), pp. 172-3: 'Tower of the Seven Vaults'.
figure.label: Puerta de siete SuelosGate of the Seven Floors (or Vaults, in Roberts's caption), Alhambra, Granada. Blown up by the French in 1812, soon after WG's visit, and rebuilt in the twentieth century from illlustrations.

tei:div.ab: By this gate King went to deliver keys to Kg of Spain. went over hill of Los Martires and garden of present Convent. Then into ravine by Xenil to mosk now Hermitage of St Sebastian. Here is the record in the wall. Then went to his family across the Vega by hill of Tears so to that called the Moors last sigh.Very similar to [Irving], Alhambra, vol. 1, pp. 170-2. Although WG may have taken the same route as Irving, who traces that of Boabdil [Muhammad XII of Granada], WG's observations here match Irving's exactly, with a couple of variations in spelling: WG changes 'Los Martyros' to 'Los Martires' and 'mosque' to 'mosk'. WG is probably drawing on a close paraphrasing of Irving's passage, with the same spelling of 'Los Martires', in Roscoe, Tourist in Spain. Granada, pp. 173-5.
The Horse Guards at Granada.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: gateDespite some differences, WG's drawing bears similarities to David Roberts's illustration in Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835), pp. 116-17: 'The Casa del Carbon'. The similarities include this title, which WG also uses.
figure.label: CASA DEL CARBONi.e. Corral del Carbón (Coal Yard; 'Casa del Carbón' would be Coal House), Granada. WG's drawing represents the building before twentieth-century restoration.

tei:div.ab: The Casa del Carbon is nearly in centre of City, between the Zacatin & the Moorish bridge. close to the Darro, the Post house for Couriers & Cavaleriera. Built by Abu Alhamar. Some of The Horses of the breed of Nejdi some of Dongola – The Casa del Carbon not unlike a jewish house.Summary of Roscoe, Tourist in Spain. Granada, pp. 117-20. Same observations in same order, though WG has replaced Roscoe's 'high-bred corredores' (runners, i.e. horses) with 'Couriers & Cavaleriera'. By the latter, WG must mean 'caballería', cavalry horses.

figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: gateWG's drawing bears some similiarities to, and some differences from, David Roberts's painting of the same view, but the latter did not appear in Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835). It seems to have been first published in Roberts's own Picturesque Sketches in Spain (London, 1837), after WG's death.
